title: Weak Presidents
summary: This article investigates the phenomenon of "weak presidents" in American history, particularly in the decades surrounding Abraham Lincoln's presidency. It seeks to understand why the office was less powerful during certain periods, contrasting with the "Imperial Presidency" of later eras. The author posits that a strong Congress actively limited presidential power following robust presidencies like Andrew Jackson's and Abraham Lincoln's. The text draws on historical analyses and mentions Woodrow Wilson's dissertation, "Congressional Government," highlighting the ongoing interest in the balance of power between the executive and legislative branches.

title: Pathways to the Urban Community College Presidency
abstract: College presidents have multiple, complex roles. These roles have evolved to include an increased emphasis on external relations, regardless of institutional type, yet these leaders are also expected to hold traditional academic credentials. This study explored the experience base of urban community college presidents and found that they hold remarkably similar skill sets and experience backgrounds to other college presidents
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Community College Education Administration, Community College Leadership, Educational Assessment Evaluation and Research
summary: This study investigates the evolving roles of college presidents, particularly focusing on the increased emphasis on external relations despite expectations for traditional academic credentials. It specifically explores the experience base of urban community college presidents, finding that they possess remarkably similar skill sets and backgrounds to presidents of other institutional types. This research contributes to understanding leadership pathways and essential competencies for higher education administration, especially within community colleges.

title: Do Trustees and Administrators Matter? Diversifying the Faculty Across Gender Lines
abstract:
Our paper focuses on the role that the gender composition of the leaders of American colleges and universities – trustees, presidents/chancellors, and provosts/academic vice presidents – plays in influencing the rate at which academic institutions diversify their faculty across gender lines. Our analyses make use of institutional level panel data that we have collected for a large sample of American academic institutions.
We find, other factors held constant including our estimate of the “expected” share of new hires that should be female, that institutions with female presidents/chancellors and female provosts/academic vice presidents, as well as those with a greater share of female trustees, increase their shares of female faculty at a more rapid rate. The magnitudes of the effects of these leaders are larger at smaller institutions, where central administrators may play a larger role in faculty hiring decisions. A critical share of female trustees must be reached before the gender composition of the board matters
summary: This paper investigates how the gender composition of leaders in American colleges and universities influences the rate of faculty diversification across gender lines. Using institutional-level panel data, the authors found that institutions with female presidents/chancellors, provosts, or a greater share of female trustees increased their female faculty representation more rapidly. These effects were more pronounced in smaller institutions where central administrators have a larger role in hiring. A critical mass of female trustees was necessary for board gender composition to matter, highlighting the importance of leadership diversity in promoting gender equity in academic hiring.

title: Courts and Executives
abstract: William Howard Taft was both our twenty-seventh president and the tenth Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court -- the only person to have ever held both high positions in our country. He once famously commented that  presidents may come and go, but the Supreme Court goes on forever  (Pringle 1998). His remark reminds us that presidents serve only four-year terms (and are now limited to two of them), but justices of the Supreme court are appointed for life and leave a legacy of precedent-setting cases after departing the High Court. Of course, presidents also leave a legacy of important decisions, not the least of which being their appointment of federal judges. [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: Politics, American Politics, Courts, Judges, Legal
summary: This work explores the distinct and overlapping legacies of U.S. presidents and Supreme Court justices, highlighting William Howard Taft's unique dual role as both president and Chief Justice. It emphasizes that while presidents serve limited terms, justices hold lifetime appointments, leaving enduring legal precedents. The text suggests that presidents also significantly influence the judiciary through federal judge appointments. This analysis delves into American politics, legal institutions, and the interplay between executive and judicial branches, with a focus on their enduring impact and decision-making processes, as well as the long-term impact of Supreme Court decisions. This scholarly work uses citations to emphasize the historical and legal aspects of the roles.

title: Rational Speculative Bubbles in the US Stock Market and Political Cycles
abstract: This paper tests the existence of rational speculative bubbles during Democratic and Republican presidential terms, which has not been systematically researched in existing studies. With monthly real returns on equally-weighted and value-weighted portfolios in the U.S. from January 1927 to December 2012, we find that there are rational speculative bubbles under Republican Presidents but not under Democratic Presidents. Our results are robust to different specifications
summary: This paper investigates the existence of rational speculative bubbles in the U.S. stock market during different presidential terms, a topic not systematically explored previously. Utilizing monthly real returns from equally-weighted and value-weighted portfolios spanning January 1927 to December 2012, the study reveals that rational speculative bubbles are present under Republican Presidents but absent during Democratic Presidencies. These findings are consistent across various model specifications, providing novel insights into the interplay between political cycles and financial market anomalies. Keywords: rational speculative bubbles, political cycles, U.S. stock market, presidential terms, real returns, portfolio analysis.

title: Past Presidents Keep Active Lives
abstract: Brief biographies about four previous Linfield presidents
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Education, Higher Education Administration, Biographies
summary: This article presents brief biographies of four former Linfield University presidents, highlighting their post-presidency activities and contributions. It discusses the careers of Vivian A. Bull, Charles Walker, and Gordon C. Bjork, focusing on their continued involvement in academia, public service, and community leadership. The text emphasizes their enduring impact and commitment to education, featuring details like Bjork's work at Claremont McKenna College and his economic publications. The article aims to inform readers about the continued active lives of these prominent figures after their tenures at Linfield, providing keywords for biographical and educational history searches.

title: Notes on AJCU presidents
summary: This article from "Conversations on Jesuit Higher Education" discusses the evolving role of leadership in Jesuit colleges and universities, specifically focusing on the increasing number of lay presidents within the Association of Jesuit Colleges and Universities (AJCU). It notes that as of September 2017, exactly half of the 28 Jesuit institutions in the U.S. are led by lay individuals, a trend endorsed by Father General Peter-Hans Kolvenbach's 2000 vision. The text highlights recent appointments, including Dr. Mark Nemec at Fairfield University and Dr. Jo Ann Rooney at Loyola University Chicago, emphasizing their contribution to the tradition and future of Jesuit education. Keywords: Jesuit Higher Education, AJCU, lay presidents, university leadership, Catholic education.

title: Job Stability Among U.S. University Presidents
abstract: This paper examines job duration among U.S. university presidents from 2001 to 2006. Using data from the American Council of Education’s Survey of American College Presidents, this analysis finds that public university presidents are approximately 50 percent more likely to leave office than are their private university counterparts. This turnover translates into average job spells that are approximately 20 percent shorter for public university presidents. This job instability appears primarily to be driven by the higher propensity for public university presidents to leave one institution to become president at another institution
summary: This paper examines job duration among U.S. university presidents from 2001 to 2006, utilizing data from the American Council of Education's Survey of American College Presidents. The analysis reveals that public university presidents are approximately 50 percent more likely to leave office, resulting in job spells 20 percent shorter than their private university counterparts. This instability is primarily driven by public university presidents' higher propensity to transition to another presidential role. Keywords: job duration, university presidents, job stability, public universities, private universities, turnover.

title: Is the Political Business Cycle for Real?
abstract: This paper constructs and examines a macroeconomic model which combines features from both real and political business cycle models. We augment a standard real business cycle tax model by allowing for varying levels of government partisanship and competence in order to replicate two important empirical regularities: First, that on average the economy expands early under Democratic Presidents and contracts early under Republican Presidents. Second, that Presidents whose parties successfully retain the presidency have stronger than average growth in the second half of their terms. The model generates both of these features that conform to U.S. Post World War II data.Political business cycle
summary: This paper develops and analyzes a macroeconomic model integrating real and political business cycle elements. It extends a standard real business cycle tax model by incorporating varying government partisanship and competence. The model aims to reproduce two empirical regularities: economic expansion under Democratic presidents and contraction under Republican presidents early in their terms, and stronger growth in the second half of terms for presidents whose parties retain the presidency. The model successfully generates these features, consistent with U.S. Post World War II data, offering insights into political business cycles and macroeconomic dynamics.

title: Is the political business cycle for real?
abstract: This paper's macroeconomic model combines features from both real and political business cycle models. It augments a standard real business cycle tax model by allowing for varying levels of government partisanship and competence in order to replicate two important empirical regularities: First, that on average the economy expands early under Democratic presidents and contracts early under Republican presidents. Second, that presidents whose parties successfully retain the presidency have stronger-than-average growth in the second half of their terms. The model generates both of these features in conformity with U.S. post-World War II data.Business cycles
summary: This paper presents a macroeconomic model integrating real and political business cycle theories. It expands a standard real business cycle tax model by incorporating varying government partisanship and competence levels. The model successfully replicates two empirical regularities: economic expansion early under Democratic presidents and contraction under Republican presidents, and stronger growth in the second half of terms for presidents whose parties retain power. These findings align with U.S. post-World War II data, offering insights into how political factors influence economic cycles. Key concepts include political business cycles, government partisanship, economic growth, and macroeconomic modeling.

title: UA45/5 County Delegation Presidents Club Documents
abstract: Three documents related to the WKU County Delgation Presidents Club.  The first is a brief history and description of the club.  The second is a check list for forming a county club. The third is a checklist for county club sponsors.  The County Delegation clubs were a forerunner of the current WKU Alumni Association
summary: This document compiles three items related to the Western Kentucky University (WKU) County Delegation Presidents Club, a precursor to the WKU Alumni Association. It includes a historical overview of the club, a checklist for forming new county clubs, and guidelines for county club sponsors. These organizations, active since the early days of Western Teachers College, played a significant role in promoting education and garnering community support for WKU's progress in Kentucky, with students actively fostering connections on campus and extending outreach into their home counties.

title: African American Advisors to Presidents
fieldOfStudy: Politics, American Executive, African American History
summary: This article celebrates Black History Month by compiling short biographies of influential African American leaders who significantly contributed to American life and the American executive. It highlights individuals like Benjamin Banneker, an astronomer and mathematician who advised George Washington, and explores the careers of notable figures such as Condoleezza Rice, who served as National Security Advisor and Secretary of State, and Rod Paige, the first African American Secretary of Education. The article underscores their invaluable impact on American society and presidential administrations, offering insights into their diverse talents and public service.

title: President's perspective
abstract: Federal Reserve banks - Presidents ; Federal Reserve System
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Economics, Finance, Federal Reserve System
summary: This text outlines the multifaceted roles of a Federal Reserve Bank president, extending beyond policymaking to include essential operational duties as CEO of a regional Fed bank. Key responsibilities involve attending Federal Open Market Committee meetings to set monetary policy, overseeing financial infrastructure (credit, check processing, currency circulation), supervising and regulating banks, and conducting economic research. The author emphasizes the crucial, often overlooked, role of educating the public to demystify Fed actions and economic policies, requiring careful communication. The piece highlights the power of information to inform and reassure during uncertain economic times.

title: Public versus Private University Presidents Pay Levels and Structure
abstract: A number of existing studies have examined the determinants of private university presidents\u27 compensation, but none have estimated the recent earnings differential between public and private university presidents. This paper fills this void and estimates that public university presidents earn approximately 50 percent less than observably comparable private university presidents. This salary discount is robust to controls for institutional size, quality, wealth, individual characteristics of the office holder, and estimation technique
summary: This study addresses a gap in existing literature by estimating the recent earnings differential between public and private university presidents. Utilizing a robust methodology, the paper finds that public university presidents earn approximately 50 percent less than their observably comparable counterparts in private institutions. This significant salary discount persists even after controlling for factors such as institutional size, quality, wealth, individual office holder characteristics, and various estimation techniques. The research contributes to the understanding of compensation structures within higher education leadership, highlighting key disparities.

title: Pork for Policy: Executive and Legislative Exchange in Brazil
abstract: The Brazilian Constitution of 1988 gave relatively strong powers to the President. We model and test Executive-Legislative relations in Brazil and demonstrate that Presidents have used pork as a political currency to exchange for votes on policy reforms. In particular Presidents Cardoso and Lula have used pork to exchange for amendments to the Constitution. Without policy reforms Brazil would have had greater difficulty meeting their debt obligations. The logic for the exchange of pork for policy reform is that Presidents typically have greater electoral incentives than members of Congress to care about economic growth, economic opportunity, income equality and price stabilization. Members of Congress generally care more about redistributing gains to their constituents. Given the differences in preferences and the relative powers of each, the Legislative and Executive benefit by exploiting the gains from trade.
summary: This paper models and tests Executive-Legislative relations in Brazil, demonstrating that Presidents have historically utilized pork-barrel spending as a strategic political currency to secure votes for policy reforms, particularly constitutional amendments. Focusing on Presidents Cardoso and Lula, the research highlights how such exchanges were crucial for meeting debt obligations and fostering economic stability. The study argues that Presidents, driven by broader electoral incentives like economic growth and price stabilization, exploit differences in preferences with members of Congress, who prioritize constituent gains, to achieve mutually beneficial policy outcomes through this "pork for policy" dynamic. Key concepts include Brazilian politics, executive-legislative relations, fiscal policy, and political economy.

title: Introduction: The Adequacy of the Presidential Succession System in the 21st Century: Filling the Gaps and Clarifying the Ambiguities in Constitutional and Extraconstitutional Arrangements
abstract:
Inevitably, the events of the day dominate the political agenda. The issues of presidential succession have been attended to in our national history only sporadically because, at most times, the question of who succeeds the President in cases of death, resignation, or incapacity does not have immediate relevance: the President is in good health, the presumption is he will serve out the term of his office for which he was elected, and political leaders ignore succession issues as if they were of only theoretical interest. And yet, again and again, succession questions have become of the most immediate consequence in times of crisis. Strikingly, of the forty-four men who have served as President of the United States, nine were Vice Presidents who succeeded to the office. Eight of those Vice Presidents took office as a result of the death of the President, and one took office after the resignation of a President. Perhaps equally significant, with remarkable frequency Presidents have confronted disabilities that impeded their ability to serve as President. Indeed, since the adoption of the Twenty-Fifth Amendment in 1967, Presidents have already invoked its disability provision on three occasions. Given the terrible frequency with which Presidents fail to complete their terms of office and the frequency with which they are disabled, any ambiguities concerning presidential succession and any flaws in the rules governing succession have the capacity to lead to national disaster.
In view of the profound importance of questions of presidential succession and the lack of attention paid to them, this issue of the Fordham Law Review is, very simply, a great public service. It presents the papers produced by The Adequacy of the Presidential Succession System in the 21st Century Symposium, which was held at Fordham Law School on April 16 and April 17, 2010. The Symposium took place just one week after the horrific plane crash that killed the President of Poland and a number of the top political and military leaders in Poland, an event that starkly showed the necessity of having a comprehensive system of presidential succession in place in the event of an unexpected tragedy. Sitting in the audience during the Symposium and listening to the papers presented there, the author was struck by how many gaps there are in our current system and what dangers those gaps pose
summary: This paper highlights the critical, yet often overlooked, issue of presidential succession in the United States, emphasizing its profound importance given the historical frequency of presidential deaths, resignations, and incapacities. It introduces a symposium held at Fordham Law School in 2010, which aimed to address gaps and ambiguities in the existing constitutional and extraconstitutional arrangements for succession. The discussion reveals numerous flaws in the current system, posing potential national disasters. The symposium encouraged scholars and political actors to continue working with institutions like the American Bar Association to reform the process and avert future crises.

title: Do Federal Reserve Presidents Communicate with a Regional Bias?
abstract: In this paper, we analyze the determinants of U.S. monetary policy stance as expressed in speeches by Federal Reserve (Fed) officials over the period January 1998 to September 2009. Econometrically, we use a probit model with regional and national macroeconomic variables to explain the content of these speeches. Our results are, first, that Fed governors and presidents follow a Taylor rule when expressing their opinions: a rise in inflation or the Leading Index makes a hawkish speech more likely. Second, when Fed presidents make a speech in their home district, its content is influenced by both regional and national macroeconomic variables, whereas speeches given outside the home district are influenced solely by national information. Third, the influence of regional variables increases during (i) Ben Bernanke’s tenure as Fed Chairman, (ii) recessions, and (iii) the financial crisis. Finally, speeches by nonvoting presidents reflect regional economic development to a greater extent than those by voting presidents.Central Bank Communication, Disagreement, Federal Reserve, Monetary Policy, Regional Representation, Speeches
summary: This paper analyzes the determinants of U.S. monetary policy stances expressed in Federal Reserve (Fed) officials' speeches from 1998 to 2009. Using a probit model with regional and national macroeconomic variables, the study finds that Fed governors and presidents generally follow a Taylor rule, with inflation or the Leading Index increasing the likelihood of a hawkish speech. Speeches given in a president's home district are influenced by both regional and national variables, while those outside are solely national. Regional variable influence increased during Ben Bernanke's tenure, recessions, and the financial crisis. Nonvoting presidents' speeches reflect regional economic development more than voting presidents'.

title: Weak Presidents, Treaty Ratification, and Presidential Leadership Style
abstract: Traditionally, the president is seen as getting his way when it comes to foreign-policy issues; however, with treaty making, an aspect very much related to foreign policy, things are different. Treaties are seen as salient, high-profile, and requiring direct positive action by the Senate. Presidents with high approval ratings would expect to have a relatively easy job at getting treaties approved by the Senate, but when a president is faced with low public approval, one of the most useful tools at his disposal to get Senate approval is not in play. The authors look at a case study of President Carter and the ratification of the Panama Canal Treaties to suggest what “weak” presidents can do to get their way
summary: This article investigates how "weak" presidents, characterized by low public approval, can achieve treaty ratification in the face of Senate requirements for direct positive action on salient foreign-policy issues. Using a case study of President Carter and the ratification of the Panama Canal Treaties, the authors suggest strategies for presidential leadership when traditional tools like high public approval are not available. The study explores the dynamics between presidential approval, Senate treaty approval, and foreign policy decision-making, offering insights into political maneuvering and the influence of presidential leadership style on international agreements.

title: Book review: enemies of the American way: identity and presidential foreign policymaking
abstract: Why do presidents, when facing the same circumstances, focus on different threats to national security? Enemies of the American Way attempts to answer this question by investigating the role of identity in presidential decision making. The book explains why presidents disagree on what constitutes a threat to the US security via the study of three US presidencies in the 19th century (Cleveland, Harrison, and McKinley). Paul Brighton values the author’s contribution for reminding us of how individual presidents’ own preconceptions shape global foreign policy
publisher: Blog post from London School of Economics & Political Science
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Presidential Studies, Foreign Policy, International Relations
summary: This book review examines "Enemies of the American Way: Identity and Presidential Foreign Policymaking" by David Bell Mislan, which investigates why presidents identify different national security threats despite similar circumstances. The study focuses on the role of identity in presidential decision-making, using case studies of three 19th-century US presidencies (Cleveland, Harrison, and McKinley). The reviewer, Paul Brighton, highlights the author's valuable contribution in demonstrating how individual presidential preconceptions influence global foreign policy, emphasizing the enduring relevance of this insight for understanding contemporary international relations and threat definition.

title: Former Presidents: Pensions, Office Allowances, and Other Federal Benefits
abstract:
[Excerpt] The Former Presidents Act (FPA; 3 U.S.C. §102 note) charges the General Services Administration (GSA) with providing former Presidents a pension, support staff, office support, travel funds, and mailing privileges. The FPA was enacted to “maintain the dignity” of the Office of the President. The act provides the former President—and his or her spouse—certain benefits to help him respond to post-presidency mail and speaking requests, among other informal public duties often required of a former President. Prior to enactment of the FPA in 1958, former Presidents leaving office received no pension or other federal assistance.
This report provides a legislative and cultural history of the Former Presidents Act. It details the benefits provided to former Presidents and their costs. Congress has the authority to reduce, increase, or maintain the pension and benefits provided to former Presidents of the United States. This report considers the potential effects of maintaining the FPA or amending the FPA in ways that might reduce or otherwise modify a former President’s benefits
summary: This report examines the legislative and cultural history of the Former Presidents Act (FPA), which tasks the General Services Administration (GSA) with providing pensions, support staff, office support, travel funds, and mailing privileges to former U.S. Presidents and their spouses. Enacted in 1958 to uphold the dignity of the presidential office and assist with post-presidency public duties, the FPA ensures benefits that were not available prior to its passage. The study details the benefits and associated costs, while also considering Congress's authority to modify these provisions and the potential implications of maintaining or amending the FPA. Keywords: Former Presidents Act, FPA, General Services Administration, GSA, presidential benefits, U.S. Presidents, pensions, legislative history.

title: Perspectives on Time Commitment to Fundraising by Community College Presidents
abstract: All types of higher education institutions have come to rely on some element of revenue diversification, and fundraising from private sources has become increasingly common and popular among community college presidents. Yet despite the growth in attention to fundraising, community colleges collectively only garner 2% of all philanthropic support to higher education. With the growing demand for private funds, community college presidents must understand how they are using their time for fundraising, and ultimately, the consequence of these fundraising efforts. The current study explored the time commitment of college presidents, finding that they spend as much as 30% of their workplace time each month on development related activities
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Community College Education Administration, Community College Leadership, Educational Assessment Evaluation and Research, Educational Leadership
summary: This study investigates the increasing reliance of higher education institutions, particularly community colleges, on revenue diversification through private fundraising. It highlights that despite growing attention, community colleges receive only 2% of philanthropic support to higher education. The research explores the time commitment of community college presidents to fundraising activities, revealing they spend as much as 30% of their monthly workplace time on development. Key findings include specific hours dedicated to event-based fundraising, donor stewardship, gift solicitation, and administrative tasks, offering insights for community college leadership and strategic planning in fundraising.

title: Welfare Implications of the Design of a Currency Union in Case of Member Countries of Different Sizes and Output Persistence
abstract: In the study, the relevance of several optimum-currency-area (OCA) criteria is formally worked out in a welfare approach. The optimum monetary-policy rules of the supranational central bank are derived within the Barro-Gordon framework, and consideration is given to how the welfare of the member countries of a currency union is affected by symmetric and asymmetric national output shocks. The welfare implications are deduced both analytically and with the use of simulations. In a twocountry framework, the countries are allowed to differ in size, and different degrees of labour mobility are addressed. Also the issue of output persistence is taken up. The central-bank council may consist of a central-bank board and of a group of national central-bank presidents, where the national presidents are assumed to focus on their home economies. It is shown that relatively small member countries favour a situation where the group of national central bank presidents is in a strong position while large countries prefer decisions to be taken by the central-bank board. The preferences are the less strong the higher the degree of labour mobility. With output persistence, labour migration also moderates the disadvantages of the decisions taken by a central-bank board for a relatively small country. Furthermore, for output persistence in conjuncture with labour migration, monetary policy by a small country within the group of national presidents may negatively affect its future welfare. Besides, differences in the national monetary transmission processes as well as divergent national inflation and output preferences affect welfare. --monetary union,voting power,shocks,output persistence,monetary transmission process,central bank council,labour mobility
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Monetary Union, Voting Power, Central Banking, Economics
summary: This study analyzes the welfare implications of currency union design, focusing on optimum-currency-area criteria within a Barro-Gordon framework. It derives optimal monetary-policy rules for a supranational central bank, examining how symmetric and asymmetric national output shocks affect member country welfare. Using analytical methods and simulations in a two-country model, it addresses differences in country size, labor mobility, and output persistence. A key finding is that smaller member countries favor strong national central bank presidents, while larger countries prefer decisions by the central bank board. These preferences diminish with higher labor mobility. The study also explores how output persistence, labor migration, and divergent national preferences and monetary transmission processes impact welfare within the union.

title: "How central should the central bank be?" a comment
abstract: The Reserve Bank presidents are fully accountable to our democratic institutions and the decentralized structure promotes healthy debate on monetary policy and regulatory issues.
summary: This essay discusses the structure of the Federal Reserve, specifically addressing criticisms from Alan Blinder regarding the decentralized nature of its district banks. The author argues that while technically private corporations, these banks serve the public interest and ensure democratic accountability for Reserve Bank presidents. The Federal Reserve System's decentralized structure promotes healthy debate on monetary policy and regulatory issues, a system that has historically served the country well. Key topics include monetary policy, regulatory issues, and the Federal Reserve structure.

abstract: This report examines the country's most prestigious liberal arts colleges. Despite endowments soaring as high as $1.8 billion, nearly all institutions increased tuition during the Great Recession to finance bloated administrative spending, with many college presidents enjoying salaries higher than Barack Obama's. This report peels back reputation to find out what students are really getting for their diploma's $240,000 price ta
publisher: American Council of Trustees and Alumni
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Higher Education, Educational Policy, Economics
summary: This report by the American Council of Trustees and Alumni (ACTA) investigates the financial practices and educational value of top-ranked liberal arts colleges in the U.S. It critiques institutions for increasing tuition despite large endowments, often to fund administrative bloat and high presidential salaries. The study aims to evaluate what students genuinely receive for their significant investment, focusing on academic quality and institutional accountability rather than just reputation. It seeks to inform alumni, donors, and education leaders about supporting academic freedom, excellence, and affordability in higher education.

title: Do Federal Reserve Bank presidents pursue regional or national interests? New evidence based on speeches
abstract: In this paper, we analyze the determinants of speeches by Federal Reserve (Fed) officials over the period January 1998 to September 2009. Econometrically, we use a probit model with regional and national macroeconomic variables to explain the subjectively coded content of these speeches. Our results are, first, that Fed Governors and presidents follow a Taylor rule when expressing their opinions: a rise in expected inflation (unemployment) makes a hawkish speech more (less) likely. Second, the content of speeches by Fed presidents is affected by both regional and national macroeconomic variables. Third, speeches by nonvoting presidents are more focused on regional economic development than are those by voting presidents. Finally, voting presidents and Governors are less backward-looking in their wording than are nonvoting presidents
publisher: Marburg: Philipps-University Marburg, Faculty of Business Administration and Economics
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Economics, Monetary Policy, Central Banking
summary: This paper analyzes the determinants of Federal Reserve (Fed) officials' speeches from January 1998 to September 2009 using a probit model with regional and national macroeconomic variables. Findings indicate that Fed Governors and presidents follow a Taylor rule, with expected inflation and unemployment influencing speech tone. The content of Fed presidents' speeches is affected by both regional and national macroeconomic variables. Nonvoting presidents focus more on regional economic development, while voting presidents and Governors are less backward-looking in their wording. This study contributes to understanding Fed communication and monetary policy signals.

title: Bailing out the markets is not a goal of Fed policy
abstract: Monetary policy ; Financial markets
summary: President William Poole addresses concerns that the Fed bails out greedy investors, particularly regarding subprime mortgages. He clarifies that the Fed's monetary policy tools, like adjusting interest rates, are used to stabilize the overall economy, not to rescue specific market segments or imprudent lenders. The speech emphasizes that the Fed's role in addressing financial instability aims to foster confidence for risk-taking and innovation, ultimately leading to economic growth. The 1929 stock market crash and the Great Depression are cited as a historical example to provoke thought on the benefits of expansionary monetary policy during crises, reinforcing the Fed's focus on broad economic stability rather than individual investor bailouts.

title: Exiting Congressional-Executive Agreements
abstract: Commentators have argued that, even if the president has the unilateral authority to terminate Article II treaties concluded with the Senate’s advice and consent, the president lacks the unilateral authority to terminate “congressional-executive agreements” concluded with majority congressional approval, such as the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). This Article challenges that claim. If one accepts a presidential authority to terminate Article II treaties, this Article contends, there is no persuasive reason to conclude differently with respect to congressional-executive agreements. Congressional-executive agreements have become largely interchangeable with Article II treaties as a matter of domestic law and practice. For example, either instrument can be used to address matters relating to international commerce and trade. Moreover, while presidents cannot unilaterally terminate statutes, congressional-executive agreements are not mere statutes. They are, like Article II treaties, binding international instruments that can be concluded by the United States only through presidential action. These agreements also typically contain withdrawal clauses similar to those contained in Article II treaties, which presidents have long invoked unilaterally, and Congress has never indicated that presidents have less withdrawal authority for such agreements. Indeed, in its trade legislation, Congress appears to have accepted that presidents may invoke such clauses unilaterally
summary: This article challenges the claim that the president lacks unilateral authority to terminate congressional-executive agreements, such as NAFTA, even if they have the power to terminate Article II treaties. It argues that if presidential authority to terminate Article II treaties is accepted, there's no persuasive reason to conclude differently for congressional-executive agreements, as they are largely interchangeable in domestic law and practice, both binding international instruments concluded by presidential action. The article highlights that these agreements typically contain withdrawal clauses, unilaterally invoked by presidents, and Congress has not indicated less withdrawal authority for such agreements, even appearing to accept this in trade legislation. Key terms include presidential authority, treaty termination, congressional-executive agreements, NAFTA.

title: Presidents and Jobs
fieldOfStudy: Politics, U.S. Presidents, Job Growth, Economic Policy
summary: This article examines job growth under various U.S. presidents from 1929 onwards, aiming to identify which administrations presided over the most significant increases in employment, expressed as a percentage. It presents a ranking of presidents, with Bill Clinton's two terms leading, followed by Ronald Reagan, Jimmy Carter, Lyndon Johnson, and Franklin Roosevelt. The author notes that presidents influence the economy primarily through fiscal policy, not monetary policy. The piece also discusses how economic stewardship is measured, including job growth, unemployment rate, and inflation rate (Misery Index), concluding with a reflection on public perception of economic performance.

title: Choose Your Laws Carefully: Executive  Authority to Unilaterally Withdraw the United States Outer Continental Shelf from Leasing Disposition
abstract:
Congress enacted the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) to both exert federal jurisdiction over the submerged lands of the U.S. Outer Continental Shelf and establish the legal framework for America’s offshore energy production regime. Section 12(a) of OCSLA is a short yet potent provision that grants a president the authority to withdraw unleased offshore lands from leasing disposition, effectively banning any form of energy exploration or production. In recent decades, presidents have embraced section 12(a) not only to ban offshore energy production, but also to protect the marine environment itself. Presidents have also utilized a different federal law, the Antiquities Act of 1906 (Antiquities Act), to create marine national monuments, providing general protection for areas of rich biodiversity, scientific interest, and cultural heritage. Interestingly, both OCSLA and the Antiquities Act achieve the same end results: offshore energy production is prohibited and the marine environment is protected. The crucial distinction between the two laws, though, is the ability to provide permanent protection. A close study of these laws reveals that only one indeed provides the intended lasting protection that presidents have sought: the Antiquities Act.
This Note probes the theory of executive authority to unilaterally remove America’s submerged lands from leasing disposition. Specifically, it centers on President Barack Obama’s twin December 2017 offshore withdrawals in the Atlantic and Arctic Oceans. President Obama utilized OCSLA to ban offshore energy production, but he framed the withdrawals as a way to permanently protect each area’s unique marine biodiversity, scientific value, and cultural significance to indigenous inhabitants. This Note concludes that a president seeking such lasting protection must use the Antiquities Act in lieu of OCSLA. The Note examines the relevant statutory histories, judicial inquiries, and precedential usage of these laws and argues that OCSLA’s protection falls incredibly short. This Note is particularly relevant given the Trump administration’s effort to roll back the Obama administration’s bans on offshore energy production. President Donald Trump’s recent executive actions will surely test the conclusions of this Note
summary: This Note examines presidential authority to withdraw submerged lands from offshore energy leasing, focusing on President Obama's 2017 Atlantic and Arctic Ocean withdrawals. It compares the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act (OCSLA) Section 12(a) and the Antiquities Act of 1906, both used to prohibit energy production and protect marine environments. The study concludes that only the Antiquities Act provides lasting protection, arguing that OCSLA's provisions fall short. This analysis is particularly relevant given the Trump administration's efforts to reverse Obama's offshore energy bans, and it probes statutory histories and judicial inquiries regarding these environmental protection laws.

title: Inaugural Address Inaugural Address
abstract: I am honored and humbled to accept the designation of the Nominating Committee and membership to become president of this venerable Association. I feel especially privileged to be the first member of the academic community to be chosen since Robert McKay, who was for me a role model and special friend. In accepting this designation, I become heir to a tradition of remarkable service by the presidents of this Association for more than 120 years. Their names are synonymous with the best of the American legal profession in so many ways, and especially if judged by a standard of commitment to the public good. I know this from personal experience of having served with some of these lawyers, beginning with Herbert Brownell in the early 1960s and continuing most recently with Cyrus Vance. Their particular careers in public service have set a special benchmark for all Presidents of this Association. It is a very high honor for me to be chosen as Conrad Harper\u27s successor. His leadership of the Association has been truly inspiring. He has been eloquent and forceful in articulating the high expectations of the legal profession, in reaching out to members of the profession who carry special burdens, and in moving this Association to greater heights of service to the community. He has earned the gratitude of everyone for a job exceptionally well done
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Law, Public Service, Legal Profession
summary: This inaugural address by John D. Feerick details his acceptance of the presidency of a venerable legal association, highlighting the institution's 120-year tradition of public service by its leaders. Feerick acknowledges the significant contributions of past presidents, including Robert McKay and Conrad Harper, emphasizing their commitment to the public good and the high expectations for the legal profession. He expresses gratitude for the opportunity to lead and outlines his dedication to upholding the association's legacy, serving the community, and exploring alternative funding sources beyond membership dues to ensure its future health. This address underscores themes of leadership, tradition, public service, and the legal profession.

title: The Presidency in Black and White
abstract: WCVB-TV's April Ryan talks about three presidents and race and politics in America
authors: Boston University Howard Thurman Center for Common Ground
publisher: Boston University Howard Thurman Center for Common Ground
summary: This document outlines an event titled "The Presidency in Black and White" featuring April Ryan, a WCVB-TV correspondent, who discussed three presidents and the intricate relationship between race and politics in America. The event, held at Boston University's Metcalf Ballroom and moderated by Karen Holmes Ward, explored a critical view of these topics. It was hosted by the Howard Thurman Center for Common Ground. This flyer provides key details for an event focusing on contemporary American political discourse, racial dynamics, and the legacies of presidential administrations.

title: Challenges and Opportunities Facing the Community College President in the 21st Century
abstract: The significant problems we face cannot be solved at the same level of thinking we were at when we created them” Albert Einstein. The quote by Albert Einstein indicates where community college presidents are in solving the issues facing their institutions. The 21st Century has brought new challenges and opportunities to college presidents. A college leader is no longer just concerned about academic matters. While there are significant challenges facing community college leaders, opportunities are available for them to make changes to adapt to the changing landscape of higher education
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Community College Education Administration, Community College Leadership, Educational Assessment Evaluation and Research
summary: This article explores the significant challenges and opportunities facing community college presidents in the 21st century. Drawing inspiration from Albert Einstein's quote on problem-solving, it argues that contemporary college leaders must adapt their thinking to address new issues beyond traditional academic concerns. The study highlights how the changing landscape of higher education presents both substantial hurdles and unique opportunities for presidents to implement transformative changes within their institutions, moving beyond conventional leadership paradigms to foster innovation and resilience. Key themes include leadership adaptation, institutional challenges, and strategic opportunities for community colleges.

title: Party Leader or Party Reputation Concerns? How Vertical Partisan Alignment Reins in Subnational Fiscal Profligacy
abstract: Some scholars argue that party leader considerations drive governors copartisan with presidents toward fiscal discipline, while others argue that party reputation concerns guide their behavior. To demonstrate how to assess whether either of these mechanisms is at work, I extend this analysis to the municipal level. If mayors aligned with both governors and presidents are more disciplined than mayors aligned with presidents only, copartisan governors affect mayoral fiscal behavior through party leader considerations. If mayors aligned with both governors and presidents are just as fiscally disciplined as those aligned with presidents only, party reputation concerns drive mayoral fiscal behavior. Cross-sectional time-series analysis of debt used to finance fiscal excess in municipal Mexico reveals support for the party-leader-concern logic in this nation, but the party reputation logic (or both logics or neither logic) may be at work in others
summary: This study examines whether party leader considerations or party reputation concerns drive fiscal discipline among subnational officials. It extends existing analysis to the municipal level, proposing that if mayors aligned with both governors and presidents are more disciplined than those aligned only with presidents, party leader considerations are at play. Conversely, if discipline is similar, party reputation concerns are dominant. Using cross-sectional time-series analysis of municipal debt in Mexico, the research finds support for the party-leader-concern logic in this context, while acknowledging that other logics may apply elsewhere. This contributes to understanding vertical partisan alignment and fiscal profligacy.

title: The College Presidency: An Interview with Stephen J. Nelson
abstract: College presidents continue to fill prominent critical roles in colleges and universities and society. Thus an examination of the reasons for their success and failure is vital. Four major criteria are presented as a baseline for fair judgments of presidents and their leadership. Current trends in the presidency and presidential selection are explored and presented in order to increase understanding about how presidents can best  fit  the demands of these important leadership posts
summary: This paper examines the critical roles of college presidents, emphasizing the need to understand factors contributing to their success and failure. It proposes four major criteria for evaluating presidential leadership and explores current trends in presidential selection to inform how leaders can effectively meet institutional demands. The author stresses the importance of presidents upholding the university's foundational values, rather than focusing solely on business aspects, and suggests that continuing to teach can bolster their connection to academic principles. The article ultimately offers recommendations for shaping the future of the college presidency.

title: The Courage to Lead: The Leadership Legacies of American Presidents John Fitzgerald Kennedy and Theodore Roosevelt
abstract: Prolific writer Iodice chronicles the legacies of former American presidents John F. Kennedy and Theodore Roosevelt whose accomplishments, both domestic and international, shaped constituencies then and now. From the Panama Canal ― which opened up trade routes for global commerce — to the preservation of lands for environmental purposes and public enjoyment, to the enactment of civil rights legislation that would collectively create a template for future world leaders, Iodice emphasizes that these specific political icons blazed indelible trails
summary: This article explores the enduring leadership legacies of American presidents John F. Kennedy and Theodore Roosevelt, emphasizing their significant domestic and international accomplishments. Iodice chronicles how their actions, from establishing the Panama Canal and preserving natural lands to enacting civil rights legislation, created a template for future world leaders. The work highlights their indelible impact on constituencies and global commerce, underscoring their roles as influential political icons whose leadership continues to resonate. This study offers valuable insights for understanding historical presidential influence and its relevance for modern leadership.

title: Presidents Club
abstract: http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/89156/1/1990_Presidents_Club_5-13-90.pd
summary: This document outlines the "Public Challenge" faced by higher education in Michigan, focusing on issues such as tuition affordability, financial aid, program efficiency, and the impact of new initiatives like the Michigan Education Trust. Presidents and chancellors of Michigan's public universities convened joint forums to address the erosion of public support for higher education, which has led to the state's decline in national rankings. The text urges alumni, taxpayers, and citizens to engage with political candidates about this crisis and consider their responses when deciding support, aiming to rekindle faith in education for future generations. Key concerns include access to quality education, public funding, and state leadership.

title: Do federal reserve bank presidents have a regional bias?
abstract: This paper examines whether the interest rate preferences of Federal Reserve Bank Presidents are subject to a regional bias. In order to evaluate the regional bias hypothesis, we augment individual Taylor rules for the Federal Reserve Bank Presidents (sample 1989 to 2006) with regional variables and test for their influence on the Presidents’ interest rate preferences. These preferences stem from FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) transcripts. Estimates based on the augmented Taylor rules reveal that the preferences of some Federal Reserve Bank Presidents were not free of a regional bias. Augmented Taylor rules with inertia, however, show that this finding could also be due to the presence of an interest rate smoothing motive
publisher: Frankfurt a. M.: European Central Bank (ECB)
summary: This paper investigates whether Federal Reserve Bank Presidents' interest rate preferences exhibit a regional bias. Utilizing augmented individual Taylor rules for Presidents from 1989 to 2006, the study incorporates regional variables to test their influence, drawing data from FOMC transcripts. Findings suggest that some Presidents' preferences were not free of regional bias. However, the presence of an interest rate smoothing motive, when augmented Taylor rules include inertia, indicates this finding could also be attributable to smoothing. The research explores Federal Reserve policy, regional economics, and monetary policy decision-making.

title: Presidents and parties in regional politics : Italy and Spain compared
abstract: This article examines the relationship between political parties and regional presidents in Italy and Spain, adopting a comparative case study approach based on extensive archival analysis and in-depth interviews with regional politicians. The findings confirm a strong pattern of growing presidentialism at regional level, regardless of whether there are formal mechanisms for direct election, and regardless of the partisan composition of regional government. Regional presidents tend to exert their growing power through a personalised control of regional party organisations, rather than governing past parties in a direct appeal to the electorate. Nevertheless, parties can still present a significant constraint on regional presidents, so successful regional presidents tend to maintain a mediating form of leadership and fully exploit the opportunities for party patronage to build up their support and smooth governing tensions. An autonomist drive helps presidents hold together disparate coalitions or loose parties at regional level, but their lack of internal coherence presents major problems when it comes to political succession
authors: Institut de Ciències Polítiques i Socials. Barcelona, Catalunya
publisher: Institut de Ciències Polítiques i Socials (Barcelona, Catalunya)
summary: This article investigates the interplay between political parties and regional presidents in Italy and Spain using a comparative case study approach, archival analysis, and interviews. It reveals a trend of growing presidentialism at the regional level, irrespective of formal direct election mechanisms or government partisan composition. Regional presidents often exert power through personalized control of party organizations rather than direct appeals to the electorate. Parties can constrain presidents, leading successful leaders to adopt mediating leadership styles, utilizing party patronage to build support. An autonomist drive helps presidents manage coalitions, though succession poses challenges due to a lack of internal coherence. Keywords: regional politics, presidentialism, political parties, Italy, Spain, comparative politics.

title: Gender, caste, and public goods provision in Indian village governments:
abstract: "This paper seeks to contribute to the literature on village governance and local public goods provision. Using data from 144 village-level governments in India's Tamil Nadu state, we examine whether the gender and caste of village government leaders influence village public goods provision. In particular, we examine: 1) whether public goods are provided in accordance with gender or caste preferences; and 2) whether public goods provision differs based on the knowledge level of the village government leader. We find evidence of different preferences for public goods between men and women, and between Scheduled Caste (SC) and non-SC persons. Additionally, a test of knowledge regarding the village government reveals that female and SC presidents receive lower scores relative to male and non-SC presidents, with women scoring lowest overall. We find that preferences and knowledge have little effect on public goods provision by female presidents, and hypothesize that this may be due to the influence of their male spouses. In the context of SC presidents, we find evidence that SC presidents provide more drinking water access—a location-specific public good—to SC-inhabited village areas." from authors' abstractLocal governance, public goods provision, Gender, Caste,
summary: This paper examines how the gender and caste of village government leaders influence public goods provision in 144 Indian villages in Tamil Nadu. Using data from village-level governments, the study investigates whether public goods align with gender or caste preferences and if leaders' knowledge levels play a role. Findings indicate differing public goods preferences between men and women, and between Scheduled Caste (SC) and non-SC individuals. Female and SC presidents scored lower on governance knowledge, with women scoring lowest. The study suggests that female presidents' public goods provision is minimally affected by preferences and knowledge, potentially due to spousal influence, while SC presidents increase drinking water access in SC-inhabited areas. Keywords: village governance, local public goods, gender, caste, India, Tamil Nadu.

title: Tips for Retirement
abstract: Four former Linfield College presidents have suggestions for President Hellie as he settles into retirement
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Retirement Planning, Higher Education Leadership
summary: This article offers retirement advice from four former Linfield College presidents to President Hellie, drawing on their personal experiences. Gordon Bjork emphasized finding a new life and engaging in it, continuing a career in teaching and research, and enjoying family and physical activities. Charles Walker advised staying active, engaging in community work, enjoying live music, and traveling. Vivian Bull suggested continuing to work on projects, focusing on social-responsibility investing, and consulting for higher education institutions globally. Marvin Henberg highlighted staying busy with diverse interests and intellectual pursuits. The collective advice centers on maintaining engagement, pursuing new endeavors, and prioritizing well-being after demanding presidencies.

summary: This appendix details the history of George Fox College, later George Fox University, from its Quaker origins in seventeenth-century England through its development. Willcuts, Arthur and Gwen Winters, Amanda Woodward, and Evangeline Martin, highlighting their contributions to the college.

title: Comment on Jobs and Profits in Steel
abstract:
[Excerpt]As Tom DuBois and Jack Metzgar point out in their articles, the American steelworker is approaching an important crossroads. In the next decade, the enormous changes the steel industry started in the late seventies will continue at a greater pace.
How steelworkers and their union will respond to these developments is still unclear, but already it has caused a major rejection by the local union presidents of a contract supported by the entire International Executive Board. This division over the direction of the union is not likely to disappear soon
fieldOfStudy: Politics, labor relations, industrial sociology, trade unions
summary: This article discusses the critical juncture faced by American steelworkers and their union (USWA) amidst significant industrial changes initiated in the late 1970s and continuing into the 1980s. It highlights the growing division within the union, evidenced by local presidents rejecting a contract supported by the International Executive Board, concerning the future direction of labor negotiations and responses to industry developments. The text advocates for a return to traditional unionism, demanding a fair share of productivity gains for workers through mechanisms like reduced work hours or earlier retirement, and comprehensive training to adapt to technological changes and protect jobs and living standards.

title: Mimicking war: how presidents coordinate the American State
abstract: 'Mimicking war', that is declaring war on some undesirable phenomenon - such as crime, poverty, illegal drugs, illegal immigration, terrorism and so forth - is a recurring strategy employed by White House incumbents from the beginning of the twentieth century. This paper examines the strategy and argues that the appeal to presidents of such war like exhortations are threefold. First, they provide a means by which the political executive can overcome the great problem of American governance - separated powers. Mimicking war, that is declaring a particular problem 'public enemy number one' constitutes a means of inducing coordinated government expansion. Second, mimicking war is a means of signalling a singular priority to bureaucrats and key policy makers thereby effecting a reallocation of scarce public resources to the new priority. Last, the strategy enables a president to set a political agenda and to justify the expansion of national standards of government in a political culture inherently hostile to federal governmental activity. -- Als-Ob-Kriegsführung bedeutet, dass irgendeinem unerwünschten Phänomen wie Verbrechen, Armut, Drogen, illegale Immigration, Terrorismus politisch der Krieg erklärt wird. In immergleicher Weise wird diese Kriegserklärung von den Amtsinhabern des Weißen Hauses seit Anfang des zwanzigsten Jahrhunderts strategisch eingesetzt. In diesem Arbeitspapier wird diese Strategie untersucht und der dreifachen Anziehungskraft nachgegangen, die ein derartiges kriegsähnliches Vorgehen für den Präsidenten hat. Erstens kann die politische Exekutive so das große Problem überwinden, dass sich der amerikanischen Regierung immer in den Weg stellt: die Gewaltenteilung. Einem Problem den Als-Ob-Krieg zu erklären bedeutet, es wird zum 'öffentlichen Feind Nummer eins' und jede Koordinierung des Regierungshandelns und Ausweitung staatlichen Tuns zielt auf seine Beseitigung. Zweitens bietet eine solche Kriegserklärung ein Mittel, um der Beamtenschaft und den politischen Hauptentscheidungsträgern eine einzigartige Priorität zu signalisieren; so lässt sich eine Neuverteilung der knappen allgemeinen Betriebsmittel hin zur neuen Priorität bewirken. Drittens ermöglicht es diese Strategie einem Präsidenten, überhaupt eine politische Rangordnung durchzusetzen und nationale Gestaltungsansprüche des Regierens in einer politischen Kultur auszuweiten, die einem Tätigwerden des Bundesstaates an sich von Anfang an feindlich gegenübersteht.
summary: This paper examines the recurring strategy of "mimicking war" employed by White House incumbents since the early twentieth century to address undesirable phenomena like crime and terrorism. The author argues that this strategy appeals to presidents for three main reasons: it helps overcome the problem of separated powers in American governance, signals a singular priority to bureaucrats to reallocate public resources, and enables presidents to set political agendas and justify federal government expansion in a culture often hostile to it. Keywords: mimicking war, American presidency, separated powers, public policy, government expansion, political strategy.

title: In deciding how to exercise power via Executive Orders, US Presidents appeal to Congress only if it can be united
abstract: Recent months have seen Republican attacks on President Obama, accusing him of presiding over an ‘imperial presidency’, but to what extent do presidents actually operate completely outside of Congress’ powers? By looking at 5,000 executive orders issued by presidents over the last 80 years Jeremy D. Bailey and Brandon Rottinghaus find that when issuing these orders, presidents tend to appeal back to Congress when the majority party is strong, and act unilaterally when the majority is weak and divided
publisher: Blog post from London School of Economics & Political Science
summary: This study examines the extent to which US presidents operate outside Congress's powers, specifically regarding unilateral action via executive orders. Analyzing 5,000 executive orders over 80 years, Jeremy D. Bailey and Brandon Rottinghaus find that presidents strategically appeal to Congress when the majority party is strong, but act unilaterally when the majority is weak and divided. This challenges the common perception of an "imperial presidency," highlighting the nuanced interplay between executive power and legislative strength. Keywords: executive orders, presidential power, Congress, unilateral action, political science, US politics.

title: Dwight Eisenhower, The Warrior, & John Kennedy, The Cold Warrior: Foreign Policy Under Two Presidents
abstract: This paper presents a comparison between President Eisenhower and President Kennedy\u27s foreign affairs policies, specifically regarding the Cold War, by examining the presidents\u27 interactions with four distinct Cold War regions
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: Politics, American Politics, Political History, United States History
summary: This paper compares the foreign policy approaches of President Dwight D. Eisenhower and President John F. Kennedy during the Cold War. It specifically examines their interactions and strategies concerning four distinct Cold War regions, providing insights into their leadership styles and decision-making processes regarding international relations. The study highlights key differences and continuities in US foreign policy during a critical period, focusing on American presidents, Cold War diplomacy, and international relations.

title: Presidential Name Games
abstract: As familiar as we my think we are with the name of the U.S. presidents, a listing of their fully names might still provide some surprises.  For example, how many of us can name, offhand, the three presidents whose first names are known to few these days?  And who among us can rattle off, without consulting a reference, the middle names of Rutherford B. Hayes, James A. Garfield, and Gerald R. Ford?  In this article, we explore the roster of the full names of the U.S. presidents in search of amusement, amazement, and perhaps an occult revelation or two
summary: This article delves into the full names of U.S. presidents, highlighting surprising facts and lesser-known details. It explores the comprehensive roster of presidential names, including those with unfamiliar first names or often-omitted middle names. The author seeks to uncover amusing, astonishing, and possibly 'occult' revelations within this historical data, presenting the list in a compact, structured format. This unique exploration provides a novel perspective on a familiar subject, offering insights beyond conventional presidential history.

title: Presidential Leadership in the Space Age
abstract: Mankind’s quest to reach the moon consisted of many people in leadership positions. In the US, however, many of the decisions behind the space race, especially funding for it, were made by four men: Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Baines Johnson, and Richard Nixon. While some presidents (namely Kennedy) receive more credit than others for their work on bringing man to the moon, each of them passed influential policy that was vital in the development of Apollo: Eisenhower founded NASA and began research on the Saturn V, Kennedy gave vision and urgency to the program, Johnson gave massive funding to it, and Nixon oversaw the program and decided what would come next
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
summary: This paper examines the pivotal roles of four US presidents—Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy, Lyndon Baines Johnson, and Richard Nixon—in leading the American space race to the moon. It details how each president contributed essential policies and decisions, from Eisenhower founding NASA and initiating Saturn V research, to Kennedy providing vision and urgency, Johnson ensuring massive funding, and Nixon overseeing the program's conclusion. The study highlights their individual contributions to the Apollo program's development, challenging the common perception that Kennedy alone deserves primary credit. This historical analysis of presidential leadership in the space age offers insights into policy, funding, and program management.

title: America's pyramids: Presidents and their libraries
abstract: Review of the purpose, history, and debates about the presidential library system, with a recommendation to end the system
summary: This review examines the purpose, historical development, and ongoing debates surrounding the U.S. presidential library system. It discusses the establishment of new libraries, such as the William Jefferson Clinton Presidential Library, and the complexities of managing presidential records, including compensation issues related to the Richard M. Nixon estate. The article highlights how the system, initiated over sixty years ago with the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Library, has faced both praise and criticism. The author ultimately recommends ending the current presidential library system, focusing on its history, controversies, and future implications for archival practice and federal record management.

title: Presidents Club Finale
abstract: http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/89157/1/1990_Presidents_Club_Finale_5-17-90.pd
summary: This document, likely a speech, outlines the significant challenges and transformations facing the United States in its transition from a 20th-century industrial, homogeneous society to a 21st-century pluralistic, knowledge-based global nation. It emphasizes the shift to a knowledge-based economy driven by educated individuals and competitive world markets. The text calls upon the University of Michigan community to embrace this profound transition, defining the future of American higher education for the 21st century and demonstrating leadership and excellence in education and research, leveraging alumni support and the "Go-Blue" spirit.

title: Still mere figureheads? Why the Eurozone crisis has led to the growth of presidential power across Europe
abstract: Presidents are a relatively common feature in the political systems of European states, yet their powers vary substantially from country to country. Macdara Dwyer writes that while many presidents are intended to act largely as figureheads, with only limited responsibilities over government formation, the Eurozone crisis has led to a growth in presidential power in several states, including Greece, Ireland, Italy and Portugal. He argues that although this may be a temporary development brought on by a unique set of circumstances, the precedent that has been set for presidents to play a more active role in politics could nevertheless generate lasting problems for the stability of European governments
publisher: London School of Economics and Political Science
summary: This article explores the evolving role of presidents in European states, focusing on how the Eurozone crisis has led to a growth in presidential power, despite many initially serving as figureheads with limited government formation responsibilities. It examines examples from Greece, Ireland, Italy, and Portugal, arguing that while this might be a temporary development, the precedent set for presidents to play a more active role in politics could create lasting problems for governmental stability. The analysis considers the potential for a 'dual executive' reality, where heads-of-state and heads-of-government contest power, impacting European politics.

title: NASULGC Presidents Address
abstract: http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/89024/1/2009_APLU_Presidents_Address.pd
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Public Policy, Higher Education Administration
summary: This address discusses the challenges facing public research universities in the United States. It highlights the incompatible demands placed on these institutions: broadening higher education participation, conducting world-class research, producing skilled graduates, and reducing taxpayer burden. The speaker argues that these pressures risk the future of public research universities, emphasizing their unique role as national assets despite being state-bound. The text proposes strategies such as enhanced federal research funding, internal faculty development, and modifications to federal tax policy affecting wealthy private institutions to ensure public universities remain world-class.

title: Can the president really affect economic growth?  Presidential effort and the political business cycle
abstract:
The article of record as published may be located at http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/ecin.12111Presidential elections are often seen as referendums on the health of the economy; however, little evidence exists on the president’s ability to influence gross domestic product (GDP). This study examines the effect of the incentive to be reelected and the
resulting increase in presidential effort on GDP growth. Growth is found to rise in reelection years for first-term presidents after 1932 and to fall in election years before 1932, when reelection was uncommon, and for second-term presidents generally. This
effect is largest for high-quality presidents—who probably have the highest return to effort—and is spread across multiple sectors of the economy
summary: This study investigates how presidential reelection incentives and increased presidential effort influence Gross Domestic Product (GDP) growth. It examines whether the president's ability to affect economic growth is contingent on their term and the political business cycle. The research found that GDP growth rises in reelection years for first-term presidents after 1932, but falls in election years before 1932 (when reelection was uncommon) and for second-term presidents. This effect is most pronounced for high-quality presidents and impacts multiple economic sectors, highlighting the political business cycle and presidential effort as key economic drivers.

title: Tenure reform and presidential power: The single, six-year term proposal"
abstract: During the twentieth century, a series of rapid changes transformed the office of the presidency, affecting not only its raw power and influence upon other political institutions but also, crucially for an office defined as much by image as by constitutional authority, its status in the eyes of the American public and news media. From the turn-of-the-century administration of Theodore Roosevelt to the Lyndon Johnson presidency in the 1960s, George Reedy notes, “commitment to the presidential concept” by politicians, voters and the news media became so pronounced that Americans were "virtually incapable of thinking of the United States in other terms."1 Progressives frequently encouraged the trend toward greater presidential influence as a useful means of bypassing entrenched conservatism in national and state legislatures but many on the political right were disturbed by the expansion of executive power, viewing it as both cause and consequence of liberal interventionism and as a threat to the equilibrium of constitutional government
publisher: Institute for the Study of the Americas
fieldOfStudy: Politics, American Presidency, Executive Power, Constitutional Law, Political Science
summary: This text examines the transformation of the American presidency during the twentieth century, focusing on its evolving power, influence, and public perception. From Theodore Roosevelt to Lyndon Johnson, the office's status grew significantly, encouraged by Progressives but alarming conservatives who viewed executive expansion as a threat to constitutional balance. The Vietnam and Watergate eras spurred calls for restraining presidential power. The analysis discusses proposals for a single, six-year presidential term, evaluating whether such reforms could address the challenges of modern executive authority or if they represent an impractical return to an earlier, paternalistic leadership model.

title: The Trump Presidency and the Press
abstract: [Excerpt]  It is not difficult to understand why presidents frequently voice frustration with the press. Imagine being subjected to critical analysis 24/7 by reporters, bloggers and pundits who often lack complete and accurate information but face competitive pressure to publish quickly
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
fieldOfStudy: Politics, American Politics, Constitutional Law, First Amendment, Journalism Studies, Law and Politics, Mass Communication, President/Executive Department
