It serves as an executive summary of a larger report on designing and implementing e-government policies within multi-level governance contexts. The text discusses how the pursuit of integrated, user-focused e-government services increasingly challenges traditional public sector organization, emphasizing the need for intergovernmental collaboration in e-governance, decentralization, and federalism.

title: Improving the education of looked after children : a guide for local authorities and service providers
abstract: This guide for practice is based on the key findings of research of Scottish Government-funded pilot projects in 18 Scottish local authorities carried out by the University of Strathclyde between 2006 and 2008. The guide focuses on four aspects of practice: raising the profile of looked after children; monitoring educational outcomes; advice on setting up a project with the aim of raising the educational attainment and achievement of looked after children; focusing on achievement and aspiration
summary: This guide, based on research from Scottish Government-funded pilot projects (2006-2008), aims to improve the educational outcomes of looked after children in Scotland. It focuses on four key aspects: raising the profile of these children, monitoring their educational progress, advising on setting up projects to boost attainment, and emphasizing achievement and aspiration. The research, conducted by the University of Strathclyde, provides practical guidance for local authorities and service providers, highlighting effective strategies and practices for supporting the education of vulnerable young people.

title: Which Government to trust?
summary: This press release by Katarina Ott questions the consistency of the Croatian Government's economic policies, highlighting two contradictory programs adopted within days. The first, "Guidelines for Aid to Ailing Companies," proposes converting government claims into equity, increasing state intervention. The second, a "Economic Recovery Programme," aims to reduce government involvement and implement structural reforms. The author critiques the former for potential market distortion, arbitrary decisions, and increased state participation, contrasting it with the latter's positive proposals, which align with the Institute of Public Finance's long-standing recommendations. This raises concerns about government credibility and effective economic governance in Croatia.

title: Cultural Values and Government
abstract: Mr. Dellinger Mr. Dellinger originally delivered these remarks for the panel entitled The Role of Government in Defining Our Culture, at the Federalist Society’s 2006 National Lawyers Convention, on Saturday, November 18, 2006, in Washington, D.C.  commenting on the  Ninth Circuit decision Finley v. National Endowment for the Arts.  The case involved the constitutionality of the Helms Amendment which required that the National Endowment for the Arts take decency into account in choosing who should be awarded artistic grants
summary: This article, based on remarks by Walter E. Dellinger III, discusses the 1996 Ninth Circuit decision in *Finley v. National Endowment for the Arts*. As Acting Solicitor General, Dellinger addressed the constitutionality of the Helms Amendment, which mandated that the NEA consider "decency" in artistic grant awards. Karen Finley's grant non-renewal under these criteria led to the lawsuit. Despite the NEA's initial reluctance to appeal their favorable Ninth Circuit loss, Dellinger emphasized the obligation to defend acts of Congress. The piece also touches on government funding neutrality and private choice, particularly regarding religion, highlighting Justice O'Connor's consistent view.

title: Regulating Government
abstract: Federal, state, and local governments are major polluters of the environment. They account for more than 7% of SO2 air pollution emissions and more than 5% of all NO2 air emissions in the United States. Public entities are more likely than private ones to be in violation of the Clean Water Act, and they account for two-thirds of all major facilities in significant noncompliance with the act. Department of Energy nuclear sites are the worst hazardous waste problems in the nation. A lack of adequate data makes it difficult to fully characterize the extent of pollution caused by government agencies and to compare the performance of the public and private sectors. There are many reasons why government pollution is difficult to regulate. The paper discusses political dimensions, legal problems, resource constraints, psychological dimensions, and public opinion. Further research is urgently needed, and the paper delineates areas that require more investigation.pollution control, federal facilities, regulation, intergovernmental relations
fieldOfStudy: Politics, pollution control, federal facilities, regulation, intergovernmental relations
summary: This paper investigates the significant environmental pollution caused by federal, state, and local governments in the United States, which are major emitters of SO2 and NO2 and frequently violate the Clean Water Act, with Department of Energy nuclear sites posing severe hazardous waste problems. The authors highlight the difficulties in regulating government pollution due to political, legal, resource, and psychological dimensions, as well as public opinion, emphasizing the need for further research to better characterize the extent of public sector pollution and compare its environmental performance against the private sector. Keywords include pollution control, federal facilities, regulation, and intergovernmental relations.

title: Fiscal illusion and cyclical government expenditure: State government expenditure in the United States
abstract: © 2016 Scottish Economic Society. A well-established literature argues that fiscal illusion increases the level of government expenditure. This article focuses on the proposition that fiscal illusion also influences the cyclicality of government expenditure. Predictions are formed with reference to government reliance on high income elasticities of indirect tax revenues and on intergovernmental transfers. Predictions are tested with reference to the expenditures of 36 states in the United States from 1980 to 2000. Government expenditures are more likely to be procyclical when citizens systematically underestimate the cost of taxation
summary: This article investigates the influence of fiscal illusion on the cyclicality of government expenditure, extending existing literature that primarily links it to the level of expenditure. The study forms predictions based on government reliance on income-elastic indirect tax revenues and intergovernmental transfers. These predictions are tested using expenditure data from 36 U.S. states between 1980 and 2000. The key finding is that government expenditures are more likely to be procyclical when citizens consistently underestimate the true cost of taxation, offering insights into public finance and economic cycles.

title: The Quasi Government: Hybrid Organizations with Both Government and Private Sector Legal Characteristics
abstract:
[Excerpt] This report provides an overview of federally related entities that possess legal characteristics of both the governmental and private sectors. These hybrid organizations (e.g., Fannie Mae, National Park Foundation, In-Q-Tel), collectively referred to in this report as the “quasi government,” have grown in number, size, and importance in recent decades.
A brief review of executive branch organizational history is followed by a description of entities with ties to the executive branch, although they are not “agencies” of the United States as defined in Title 5 of the U.S. Code. Several categories of quasi governmental entities are defined and discussed: (1) quasi official agencies, (2) government-sponsored enterprises (GSE), (3) federally funded research and development corporations, (4) agency-related nonprofit organizations, (5) venture capital funds, (6) congressionally chartered nonprofit organizations, and (7) instrumentalities of indeterminate character.
The quasi government, not surprisingly, is a controversial subject. To supporters of this trend toward greater reliance upon hybrid organizations, the proper objective of governmental management is to maximize performance and results, however defined. In their view, the private and governmental sectors are alike in their essentials, and thus subject to the same economically derived behavioral norms.They tend to welcome this trend toward greater use of quasi governmental entities.
Critics of the quasi government, on the other hand, tend to view hybrid organizations as contributing to a weakened capacity of government to perform its fundamental constitutional duties, and to an erosion in political accountability, a crucial element in democratic governance. They tend to consider the governmental and private sectors as being legally distinct, with relatively little overlap in behavioral norms.
Congress is increasingly engaged with the quasi government. The issues run the gamut from enacting legislation to encourage the creation of nonprofit organizations to promote individual national parks, to proposals to strengthen regulation of government- sponsored enterprises such as Fannie Mae, to oversight hearings respecting national security issues at Los Alamos Laboratory. There is nothing modest about the size, scope, and impact of the quasi government.
Time will tell whether the emergence of the quasi government is to be viewed as a symptom of decline in our democratic government, or a harbinger of a new, creative management era where the purportedly artificial barriers between the governmental and private sectors are breached as a matter of principle.
This report will be updated at the beginning of each Congress
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government, Public Administration, Organizational Studies
summary: This report examines the rise and implications of "quasi government" organizations, which blend governmental and private sector legal characteristics, such as Fannie Mae and the National Park Foundation. It reviews executive branch organizational history and categorizes these hybrid entities, including government-sponsored enterprises, federally funded research and development corporations, and agency-related nonprofits. The report contrasts supporters, who see these organizations as maximizing performance and results, with critics, who argue they erode governmental capacity and political accountability. It highlights congressional engagement with these entities, from creating nonprofits to regulating GSEs. The analysis delves into the ongoing debate about whether this trend signifies a decline in democratic governance or a new era of creative management.

title: Moderating Government
abstract: We consider a model where policy motivated citizens vote in two simultaneous elections, one for the President who is elected by majority rule, in a single national district, and one for the Congressmen, each of whom is elected by majority rule in a local district. The policy to be implemented depends not only on who is elected President but also on the composition of the Congress. We characterize the equilibria of the model using a conditional sincerity concept that takes into account the possibility that some voters may be simultaneously decisive in both elections. Such a concept emerges naturally in a model with trembles. A crucial feature of the solution is the moderation of Government.voting, proportional rule, majority, parliament.
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government, Voting, Elections, Majority Rule
summary: This paper examines a model where policy-motivated citizens vote in simultaneous Presidential and Congressional elections, both decided by majority rule. The implemented policy depends on both the President and Congress's composition. The authors characterize model equilibria using a conditional sincerity concept that accounts for voters being simultaneously decisive in both elections, a concept emerging naturally with trembles. A crucial feature of the solution is the moderation of government outcomes, even when voters are strategic. This theoretical framework provides insights into voting behavior and government moderation in dual election systems.

title: Government publications: Human rights
summary: This article examines the concept of human rights, distinguishing it from civil rights despite Library of Congress subject headings often conflating the two. It traces the origin of "human rights" to the 1948 United Nations Charter and discusses former President Jimmy Carter's significant human rights foreign policy initiative. The piece highlights the close relationship between respecting human rights and maintaining international peace, critiquing the U.S. for not being a party to key UN human rights treaties, while still viewing the initiative positively.

title: Government Relief for Risk Associated with Government Action
abstract: A significant source of risk arises from uncertainty concerning future government policy. Government action - - tax reform, deregulation, judicial decisions, budgetary shifts - - produces gains and losses for those who invested under preexisting rules. The effects of government relief - - compensation, grandfathering, phase-ins - - on ex ante incentives and risk bearing are examined in a model in which private insurance is taken into account. It is demonstrated that government relief is inefficient, even when private insurance is subject to moral hazard, because relief shields individuals from some of the effects of their actions.
summary: This paper examines the efficiency of government relief mechanisms, such as compensation or phase-ins, in mitigating risks associated with future government policy changes, including tax reform or deregulation. Using a model that incorporates private insurance, the study demonstrates that such government relief is inefficient. This inefficiency persists even when private insurance is subject to moral hazard, because relief inadvertently shields individuals from the full consequences of their actions, distorting ex ante incentives and risk bearing. Keywords: government policy, risk, private insurance, moral hazard, economic efficiency, public economics, tax reform, deregulation.

title: U.S. Government Manual 2008-2009 Edition: Social Security Administration
abstract: [Excerpt] The Social Security Administration manages the Nation’s social insurance program—consisting of retirement, survivors, and disability insurance programs—commonly known as Social Security. It also administers the Supplemental Security Income program for the aged, blind, and disabled. The Administration is responsible for studying the problems of poverty and economic insecurity among Americans and making recommendations on effective methods for solving these problems through social insurance. The Administration also assigns Social Security numbers to U.S. citizens and maintains earnings records for workers under their Social Security numbers
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government, Social Welfare, Public Administration
summary: This document details the functions of the Social Security Administration (SSA) as presented in the U.S. Government Manual 2008-2009 Edition. It outlines the SSA's management of national social insurance programs, including retirement, survivors', and disability insurance, alongside the Supplemental Security Income program. The agency is also tasked with studying poverty and economic insecurity to recommend solutions through social insurance, and it assigns Social Security numbers while maintaining earnings records. This serves as a key resource for understanding the SSA's operational scope and its role in U.S. social welfare.

title: Government By and For Millenial America: A Blueprint for 21st Century Government
abstract: Using this generation's unique ethos and commitment to pragmatic problem-solving, Millennials across the country have collaborated to design their vision for a 21st century democracy and reject the idea that our system is too broken, too stagnant, and too outdated. They have identified the parts of the system that need to be fixed while articulating what a true democracy should look like. Government By and For Millennial America, the third installment of our blueprint series, tackles some of the most fundamental, divisive, and difficult questions on the purpose of government in furthering our country's progress: how can we hear from more voices? How can we be more transparent? How can government be more egalitarian? How can we both support individual communities and the common good of every American? Most importantly, this pursuit is grounded in one fundamental idea that defines America's distinctive pursuit of self-governance: in the words of our namesake, Let us never forget that government is ourselves and not an alien power over us. The ultimate rulers of our democracy are not a President and senators and congressmen and government officials, but the voters of this country. - President Franklin D. Roosevelt We set out to craft a blueprint, and discovered, in conversations with over a thousand young people across the country, that the Millennial generation is not yet ready to give up on America's ever evolving experiment in a government by and for the people
summary: This document, "Government By and For Millennial America," explores the Millennial generation's vision for a 21st-century democracy, rejecting the notion of a broken system. It identifies areas for reform and articulates principles for a true democracy, focusing on transparency, egalitarianism, and balancing community support with the common good. Based on conversations with over a thousand young people, the blueprint emphasizes the fundamental idea of self-governance, echoing President Franklin D. Roosevelt's belief that government is "ourselves and not an alien power over us." Key themes include democratic reform, youth engagement, government purpose, and civic participation.

title: Small Business and Government Procurement
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government Procurement, Small Business Policy
summary: This paper examines the federal government's policy of special treatment for small businesses in procurement, as mandated by Congressional declaration. It details the role of the Small Business Administration and the implementation of these policies through regulations like the Armed Services Procurement Regulation. The study explores the challenges in precisely determining if small businesses secure a fair share of government purchases due to conceptual issues and data limitations. Findings suggest that while advertised bidding is preferred by policy, small businesses favor negotiated bidding and participation as subcontractors. This information is crucial for understanding government contracting and small business support.

title: Inequality under the Labour government
abstract: This Briefing Note will provide a brief analysis of changes to income inequality since the Labour government came to power in 1997.1 The most recent data from 2001-02 show that there has been little change in income inequality since 2000-01. An implication of this is that there has been little impact upon the slight upward trend in inequality that has been experienced over Labour's term in government
summary: This briefing note analyzes changes in income inequality under the Labour government since 1997, utilizing data up to 2001-02. It aims to demonstrate that despite the government's tenure, there has been minimal change in income inequality since 2000-01, contributing to a slight upward trend over Labour's term. The research presents an income distribution picture, detailing weekly household income grouped by decile and adjusted for family size, and outlines where different family types fit within these income deciles, considering varying financial requirements. This study provides key insights into income distribution, economic inequality, and government policy impact.

title: Building community through self-government
summary: This text examines the current crisis within the European Union, marked by economic challenges, social communication inadequacies, the rise of populism and nationalism, and the refugee problem. It questions whether a united Europe is failing and considers Brexit as a significant upheaval. The author suggests that these crises might serve as a painful shock therapy, forcing a re-evaluation of the concept of a 'united' Europe. The role of self-government in building community and representing citizens' interests is highlighted, criticizing the curtailment of self-governance in Poland as contradictory to EU policy and democratic principles.

title: Commercialisation of government communications:submission to the Government Communications Review Group, Stirling Media Research Institute
abstract: Much of the debate around government communications has focused on the use of special advisers, the lobby system and the centralisation of the system under Alastair Campbell. This is a legitimate focus and much has been said on this topic which is borne out by our own research.2 However the purpose of this submission is to raise a different set of issues which are less often discussed. These relate in particular to the organisation of the civil service and government communications and to the increased role of commercial agencies and commercial criteria in running and evaluating government communications. I wish to concentrate on six aspects. These do not fit very neatly under the headings of the review but are most relevant to the issues of context, politicisation and organisation
summary: This submission examines the often-overlooked issues within government communications, moving beyond the common focus on special advisers, the lobby system, and centralization under Alastair Campbell. The paper specifically addresses the organization of the civil service and government communications, alongside the increasing influence of commercial agencies and criteria in managing and evaluating these communications. It concentrates on six key aspects relevant to the context, politicization, and organizational structure of government communication. Keywords: government communications, civil service, commercialization, special advisers, lobbying, public relations.

title: Administrative remedies for government abuses
summary: This policy research paper investigates the widespread issue of government abuses at national and local levels, identifying contributing factors such as inadequate legislation, historical contexts, and inexperience. It aims to define administrative abuse, categorize types of government misconduct (e.g., political patronage, nepotism), and analyze current regulations. The study explores reasons for these abuses and proposes administrative remedies, distinguishing between internal and external approaches. A key focus is on improving accountability, outlining where and for what accountability should be exercised, and suggesting enhancements to enforcement mechanisms, culminating in specific policy recommendations.

title: The Changing Shape of Government
abstract: Gillian E. Metzger, Alfred C. Aman Jr., Charles F. Sabel, Lester M. Salamon, E.S. Savas and Elliot D. Sclar participate in panel discussions focusing on the question of how to secure government accountability in the context of the expansion of privatization in government? This panel discusses some of the changes we are seeing in government institutions and in the ways government operates. The panelists describe ways in which the move toward privatization and the expansion of the gray area between public and private is occurring, but also will talk about changes we may see as being particularly useful in dealing with some of the challenges this expansion of privatization presents
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
summary: This panel discussion explores the complex issue of securing government accountability amid the expanding privatization of public services. Featuring scholars like Gillian E. Metzger and Lester M. Salamon, the conversation delves into how this shift alters governmental institutions and operations. Panelists analyze the increasing gray area between public and private sectors, discussing both the challenges and potential benefits—like increased accountability—presented by privatization. Key topics include political accountability, the impact on traditional controls and public participation, and the evolving nature of contracting and public oversight in public/private partnerships.

title: Fair Labor Standards Act: The Department of Labor Should Adopt a More Systematic Approach to Developing Its Guidance
abstract: The FLSA sets federal minimum wage and overtime pay requirements applicable to millions of U.S. workers and allows workers to sue employers for violating these requirements. Questions have been raised about the effect of FLSA lawsuits on employers and workers and about WHD\u27s enforcement and compliance assistance efforts as the number of lawsuits has increased. This report (1) describes what is known about the number of FLSA lawsuits filed, and (2) examines how WHD plans its FLSA enforcement and compliance assistance efforts. To address these objectives, GAO analyzed federal district court data from fiscal years 1991 to 2012 and reviewed selected documents from a representative sample of lawsuits filed in federal district court in fiscal year 2012. GAO also reviewed DOL’s planning and performance documents and interviewed DOL officials, as well as stakeholders, including federal judges, plaintiff and defense attorneys who specialize in FLSA cases, officials from organizations representing workers and employers, and academics about FLSA litigation trends and WHD\u27s enforcement and compliance assistance efforts
summary: This report examines the increasing number of Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) lawsuits, focusing on their effects on employers and workers, and the Wage and Hour Division's (WHD) enforcement and compliance assistance efforts. It describes the volume of FLSA lawsuits filed and analyzes WHD's strategic approach to enforcement and assistance. The study utilized federal district court data from 1991-2012, reviewed selected lawsuit documents from 2012, and included interviews with Department of Labor officials and various stakeholders, providing insights into FLSA litigation trends, federal minimum wage, and overtime pay requirements.

title: Jewish communal government in Spain
summary: This essay surveys Jewish communal government in Spain during the thirteenth century, primarily using the She'elot u T'shuvot of Solomon ibn Adret. It examines the organization of Spanish Jewish communities, focusing on the governmental structures and the functions of organized communal units. The study reveals a varied political machinery with no single, uniform system in the "Aljama," but highlights the presence of legislative, executive, and judicial forces. This work provides insight into the social and political conditions of Jews in medieval Spain, contributing to the understanding of historical communal governance and Jewish law.

title: Labor, Management, and Government Interactions
abstract: [Excerpt] Labor, management, and government engage in complex interactions in emerging countries, and these interactions strongly influence the evolution of labor relations in those countries. For example, unions and other workers’ movements in some countries have aligned with a particular political party or in some cases are the core constituents of a labor party that is active in the political arena. This chapter will discuss cases where particular unions were aligned with the governing leaders or party. Another way unions and workers have influenced governments is through their involvement in protests or other political actions that are part of democratization campaigns or movements. As will be discussed in this chapter, some of these efforts to promote democracy have succeeded in recent years and have led to major political transformations in particular countries
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Collective Bargaining, Human Resources Management, International and Comparative Labor Relations, Labor Economics, Unions
summary: This chapter examines the complex interactions among labor, management, and government in emerging countries, highlighting their profound influence on labor relations. It explores instances where unions and workers' movements align with political parties or form the core of labor parties, actively participating in the political arena. The discussion includes cases of unions aligning with governing leaders and examines how unions and workers influence governments through protests and political actions during democratization campaigns. The chapter details successful efforts to promote democracy in recent years, leading to significant political transformations in various countries, emphasizing the interplay of labor, politics, and governance.

title: Government size and output volatility: should we forsake automatic stabilisation?
abstract: In this working paper, Xavier Debrun, Jean Pisani-Ferry and André Sapir explore the relationships between government size and output volatility. Whilst government size contributes to macroeconomic stabilisation, the slow down in output volatility of the 1980s and 90s was due more to a combination of monetary policy improvements and financial developments. That this decline was especially pronounced in small-government countries showed a reduction in the variance of primary income was more important than government transfers and that other channels of stabilisation were available for small-government countries. For most countries in the euro area, the impact of a marginal change in the size of government is bound to be small.
summary: This working paper investigates the relationship between government size and output volatility, particularly in the context of the euro area and the 'great moderation' of the 1980s and 1990s. The authors, Xavier Debrun, Jean Pisani-Ferry, and André Sapir, explore whether large government sectors function as effective automatic stabilizers. Their findings suggest that while government size contributes to macroeconomic stabilization, the observed decline in output volatility was more attributable to improvements in monetary policy and financial developments, rather than government size. The study implies that for most euro area countries, the marginal impact of changes in government size on volatility is likely to be small.

title: Making science count in government
abstract: Science is an essential component of policy-making in most areas of government, but the scientific community does not always understand its role in this process.Publisher PDFPeer reviewe
summary: This article discusses the crucial, yet often misunderstood, role of the scientific community in government policy-making. Drawing on experience as a Chief Scientific Adviser, the author highlights the challenges scientists face in influencing policy effectively, particularly in distinguishing scientific evidence from political viewpoints. It emphasizes the need for scientists to focus on evidence, articulate risks, and engage through established advisory mechanisms to maximize their contribution. The text suggests that effective scientific engagement can ensure science's voice is heard in complex decision-making processes, which also incorporate social, ethical, and economic considerations.

title: Administrative remedies for government abuses
summary: This policy research paper investigates the widespread issue of government abuses at national and local levels, asserting that these are largely uncontrolled due to inadequate legislation, enforcement failures, historical factors, and public sector inexperience. It defines administrative abuse, outlines types like political patronage and nepotism, and examines reasons for their occurrence. The paper proposes internal and external administrative remedies, along with strategies for improving accountability and enforcement. Key recommendations aim to address systemic deficiencies and enhance governmental integrity and public trust.

title: Government Speech on Unsettled Issues
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
summary: This article examines the constitutional restrictions on government speech, specifically addressing the distinction between consensus and controversy in governmental communication. The author argues that government is largely free to express its views and fund speech, provided it neither coerces nor monopolizes a speech market. It critiques the Supreme Court's ruling in *Legal Services Corporation v. Velazquez*, asserting that the decision inappropriately favors settled issues over controversial ones and misinterprets the government's role in shaping speech markets through funding. The paper suggests that the First Amendment should not prevent the government from altering the nature of government-funded legal representation.

title: Climate Change Adaptation and Mitigation: Implications for land acquisition and population relocation
abstract: In response to the challenge of climate change, governments of developing countries are evolving adaptation and mitigation programmes for which they are seeking international financing. This paper presents the findings of a review of national action programmes and other interventions to assess their likely societal impacts with an emphasis on land-use change, future land acquisitions, population displacement and resettlement. Evidence presented suggests there is likely to be additional and large-scale resettlement related to adaptation and mitigation investments in the coming decades. It describes such climate change-related projects as infrastructure development projects and the population displacement they may generate as a form of development-created involuntary resettlement. The article considers the policy and development challenges such involuntary resettlement will pose and assesses the robustness of current governance arrangements to manage that resettlement. It is argued that the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change process presents opportunities for improving the national and international management of land acquisition and resettlement, particularly in least developed countries and small island states, but cautions that, at present, the financing arrangements do not prioritise the legal protection of affected populations
summary: This paper reviews national action programs in developing countries to assess societal impacts of climate change adaptation and mitigation, focusing on land-use change, acquisitions, population displacement, and resettlement. It argues that significant large-scale resettlement will likely occur due to climate change-related infrastructure projects, resembling development-created involuntary resettlement. The study examines policy and development challenges posed by such displacement and evaluates current governance arrangements. It suggests the UNFCCC process offers opportunities for improving land acquisition and resettlement management, especially in least developed and small island states, but cautions that current financing doesn't prioritize legal protection for affected populations. Key terms: climate change, adaptation, mitigation, involuntary resettlement, land acquisition, population displacement, UNFCCC.

title: Breaking the cycle : Government response
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government Policy, Justice Reform, Youth Justice
summary: This document, "Breaking the Cycle: Government Response," presented by the Lord Chancellor and Secretary of State for Justice in June 2011, outlines the government's approach to creating a firm and fair justice system. It details proposed reforms aimed at enhancing public safety and ensuring appropriate consequences for law-breakers. Key methods involve restructuring youth justice services, including the transfer of Youth Justice Board functions to a new Youth Justice Division within the Ministry of Justice, and establishing an advisory board. The new approach emphasizes locally determined, value-for-money, and accountable youth justice services, targeting underperforming teams while empowering high-achievers.

title: The Perils of Government Investing
abstract: The current Social Security system is unsustainable. As President Clinton has pointed out, the only alternative to tax increases or benefit cuts is to increase the rate of return to investment of Social Security funds. That means either allowing individuals to invest their own Social Security taxes or allowing the government to invest them. Supporters of government investing claim that it would allow the government to reap the benefits of the higher returns available in private capital markets, incur lower administrative costs than individual accounts, and allow the government to spread the risk of poor investment performance. On the surface, that approach may have some appeal; in reality it is fraught with peril. It could potentially make the federal government the largest shareholder in American corporations, raising the possibility of government control of American business. In addition, there are serious questions about what types of investment the government would make. Political considerations and "social investing" are likely to influence the government's investment decisions, allowing the government to manipulate economic markets
summary: This paper argues that the current Social Security system is unsustainable and explores the perils of government investing as an alternative. While proponents suggest it could yield higher returns and lower administrative costs, the author contends that such an approach risks making the federal government the largest shareholder in American corporations, potentially leading to government control of businesses and manipulation of economic markets through politically influenced investment decisions. The discussion centers on the potential for "social investing" to skew government choices, highlighting the dangers over perceived benefits. This analysis emphasizes the importance of evaluating government's role in capital markets and Social Security reform.

title: Competition, Cooperation, and Local Government
abstract: Inspired by the best-selling "Reinventing Government", governments at all levels have decentralized programs and services and introduced market-based competition into operations. The goal of decentralization and privatization is to enhance civic participation and harness the market efficiencies that competition can offer.Decentralization and competition have certainly led to efficiencies and innovation. However, as Mildred Warner argues in her chapter in "Challenges for Rural America in the Twenty-First Century", many rural communities with limited resources have been overwhelmed by this new focus on market competition and decentralization.These two forces have reduced small local governments' ability to produce and deliver services, administer municipal functions, and plan and execute strategies for further development. The pressures risk exacerbating inequality between rural and urban areas as rural governments with limited means fall even farther behind wealthier communities that can compete more successfully for development, tax base, and contracts with private-sector service providers.This issue brief is a joint product of the Rural Sociological Society and the National Coalition for Rural Entrepreneurship, a collaboration of four Regional Rural Development Centers: The Northeast Regional Center for Rural Development, the Southern Rural Development Center, the North Central Regional Center for Rural Development, and the Western Rural Development Center. Funding was also made available from the Ford Foundation.This brief is part of a policy brief series by the Rural Sociological Society and the Regional Rural Development Centers that stresses the importance of community collective action and developing the capacity of people and organizations to meet the community's needsThe Rural Sociological Society and the Regional Rural Development Centers creates new Public Policy Issue Brief series based on its recent book, "Challenges for Rural America in the Twenty-First Century".The briefs synthesize the context and substance of important issues raised in the book and address alternative policy options, with the goal of bringing important research to the policy community
summary: This issue brief examines the impact of government decentralization and market-based competition on rural communities, inspired by "Reinventing Government." While intended to boost civic participation and efficiency, these policies have overwhelmed many resource-limited rural governments, hindering their ability to provide services and plan development. The brief argues this risks widening inequality between rural and urban areas. It emphasizes the need for community collective action, capacity building, and ensuring accountability and equity in cooperative and competitive systems. Key themes include rural governance, local government finance, public policy, and rural development.

title: (Mis)Attribution Symposium: Government Speech
abstract: In this Essay, I evaluate three issues of attribution and misattribution that arise in the so-called area of  government speech. \u27 First, I explore when an individual might have a constitutional claim for misattribution by the state. Second, I discuss the citizen\u27s interest in proper attribution by the government when it is speaking. Third, I consider the government\u27s interest in avoiding expression being improperly attributed to it. This concern arises less often than is commonly assumed; what many scholars (and governments) claim to be a state interest in avoiding attribution or endorsement is in fact a state interest in not providing a platform for certain types of private speech. As such, the matter cannot be resolved according to the categories of  public forum  or  government speech,  and instead we must decide how much content-based decision- making is appropriate for the state when creating speech opportunities that fall into neither of these more doctrinally understandable forms
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
summary: This essay evaluates three core issues concerning attribution and misattribution within the domain of "government speech." The author first examines when an individual might assert a constitutional claim for state-induced misattribution. Second, it discusses the citizen's interest in accurate governmental attribution when the state expresses itself. Third, the paper considers the government's interest in preventing improper attribution to itself, arguing this concern is often overstated. It suggests that many perceived state interests in avoiding attribution are actually interests in controlling private speech platforms. The analysis concludes that these matters often cannot be resolved by traditional "public forum" or "government speech" categories, necessitating a re-evaluation of content-based decision-making for state-created speech opportunities.

title: Government publications: Women and work
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Library and Information Science, Women's Studies
summary: This bibliography compiles recent government publications on women and work, highlighting their significance as a primary source for studying women's roles in the workforce. It details major U.S. government agencies such as the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights and the Federal Women's Program, which address women's rights and employment opportunities. The collection includes various reports, studies, and bibliographies on topics ranging from civil/women's rights to international efforts in women's education and economic integration, serving as a valuable resource for research in women's studies and public policy.

title: Midwesterners Consider State Government Reform
abstract: Provides results from a survey of Illinois, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin residents. Includes views on the impact of money in state politics and the choice of available candidates, and support for education, healthcare, and jobs reform
summary: This survey explores Midwestern residents' attitudes toward state government and political reform in Illinois, Michigan, Minnesota, Ohio, and Wisconsin. Conducted via telephone interviews with 2,040 adults, the study reveals significant concern about the influence of money in politics and a belief that limiting this influence is crucial for elected officials to fulfill promises on key issues like education, healthcare, and jobs. While many distrust government, they maintain faith in its ability to change. The findings indicate that while citizens value reform, they are more motivated by candidates focusing on direct policy improvements rather than just procedural changes in government structure. Political reform and public opinion are key themes.

title: Open Access/Open Research/Open Government: The Full Cycle of Access to Government Information
abstract:
Stephanie Braunstein, Head Government Documents Librarian at Louisiana State University, and Maggie Kauffman, Senior Librarian and Housing Resource Coordinator at the California Department of Housing and Community Development, will describe the who, what, why, and how of current initiatives that promote the sharing of government-funded research--at both the federal and state levels. Emphasis will be placed on recent legislative efforts (such as the Fair Access to Science and Technology Research Act [FASTR]) and on the recommendations of various professional library organizations that support academic research (such as the Association of Research Libraries [ARL]). While much of the current discussion surrounding this issue takes place at the federal level, open access to information at the state level is vital in order to insure an educated and informed local population.
After the informational portion of the presentation, the presenters will open up the floor for discussion with the intention of sharing a variety of perspectives on the government\u27s funding of research and how best to provide fair and equitable access to it
summary: This presentation by Stephanie Braunstein and Maggie Kauffman explores current initiatives promoting the sharing of government-funded research at both federal and state levels. It emphasizes legislative efforts like the Fair Access to Science and Technology Research Act (FASTR) and recommendations from library organizations such as the Association of Research Libraries (ARL). The discussion highlights the Federal Depository Library Program (FDLP) as a historical precursor to open access, tracing its evolution since 1813. The presenters also address contemporary open access legislation, including California Assembly Bill 609, and the differing perspectives of publishers and advocates on ensuring equitable access to public information.

title: Towards a network government? A critical analysis of current assessment methods for e-government
abstract: Contemporary public administrations have become increasingly more complex, having to cordinate actions with emerging actors in the public and the private spheres. In this scenario the modern ICTs have begun to be seen as an ideal vehicle to resolve some of the problems of public administration. We argue that there is a clear need to explore the extent to which public administrations are undergoing a process of transformation towards a netowork government linked to the systematic incorporation of ICTs in their basic activities. Through critically analysing a selection of e-government evaluation reports, we conclude that research should be carried out if we are to build a solid government assessment framework based on network-like organisation characteristics
summary: This paper investigates the transformation of public administrations towards a network government model, driven by the systematic incorporation of modern Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs). The authors critically analyze existing e-government evaluation reports to explore the extent of this transformation. They conclude that further research is essential to develop a robust government assessment framework, specifically one based on the characteristics of network-like organizations. Key concepts include public administration complexity, e-government, ICT integration, network government, and assessment frameworks.

title: DPJ Government and Climate Change Policy
abstract:
The monograph provides knowledge on the complex nature of both external and internal determinants influencing foreign policies of East Asian countries. Through a range of case studies on Japan, China, Taiwan and North Korea, the authors analyze international relations in East Asia as a mosaic of intertwining processes of globalization and regionalization, interests of global and regional powers, local social and economic conditions, national institutional arrangements, and even personal factors. They argue that sometimes a sudden change of one small element in this mosaic suffices to influence the whole system. Instead of providing a simplified interpretation of the analyzed processes, the monograph tries to illustrate them in their entire complexity.In 2009 election manifesto Democratic Party of Japan (DPJ) leaders voiced their decisive support for stronger engagement in international climate negotiations. The promises were realized by an ambitious climate mitigation proposal presented by Prime Minister Hatoyama Yukio at COP 15 in Copenhagen. 25% CO2 levels reduction commitment was heavily criticized by Japanese opposition, METI bureaucrats and business circles. Despite strong domestic opposition Prime Minister Hatoyama decided to place climate mitigation among priorities of his foreign policy. Next DPJ administration quickly backtracked from the position of climate leader. The head of the Japanese delegation at COP 16 in Mexico stated that Japan would not be a part of new Kyoto Protocol commitment period. The aim of the article is to identify changing factors in decision–making process that led to quick change in DPJ’s approach to international climate mitigation efforts.This article is a result of research conducted as a part of a project financed
by the Polish National Science Centre based on decision No. DEC–
2013/11/B/HS5/04005
summary: This article investigates the shifting factors influencing the Democratic Party of Japan's (DPJ) approach to international climate mitigation efforts. It highlights the DPJ's initial strong support for climate negotiations in its 2009 election manifesto, leading to Prime Minister Hatoyama Yukio's ambitious 25% CO2 reduction commitment at COP 15. Despite domestic criticism, Hatoyama prioritized climate mitigation. However, subsequent DPJ administrations quickly reversed this stance, notably at COP 16, where Japan declined to participate in a new Kyoto Protocol commitment period. The study aims to identify the changing decision-making elements behind this rapid policy shift, focusing on Japan's environmental politics and foreign policy in climate negotiations.

title: The role of trust in e-government adoption: A systematic literature review
abstract:
Electronic government (e-government) is a concept that has been adopted in most countries for the
purposes of providing government services digitally, improving transparency between government and
citizens and enabling additional communication channels with the government. Although e-government
readiness in most countries is at a high level, adoption of e-government services is still considered
tentative. A critical review of the literature suggests that this may be linked to citizens’ trust in
government and e-government. As such, there is a need to investigate the role of trust in e-government
adoption. For this purpose, a systematic literature review was conducted in order to observe research
design, methodologies and approaches adopted in these studies as well as limitations identified and
recommendation for future studies. The findings highlight that quantitative techniques and survey
research methods appear to have been much preferred over other available alternatives such as qualitative
techniques and interview methods or mixed methods in studies relating to trust in e-government
adoption
summary: This systematic literature review investigates the critical role of trust in the adoption of e-government services, addressing the disparity between high e-government readiness and tentative citizen adoption. The study's purpose was to analyze research designs, methodologies, and limitations in existing literature concerning trust in e-government. Findings indicate a strong preference for quantitative techniques and survey research methods over qualitative or mixed methods in studies examining citizen trust and e-government adoption. This research contributes to understanding the factors influencing e-government success and citizen engagement with digital government services, highlighting trust as a key enabler.

title: Government Property and Government Speech
abstract:
The relationship between property and speech is close but complicated. Speakers use places and things to deliver their messages, and rely on property rights both to protect expressive acts and to serve as an independent means of expression. And yet courts and scholars have struggled to make sense of the property-speech connection. Is property merely a means of expression, or can it be expressive in and of itself? And what kind of “property” do speakers need to have – physical things, bundles of rights, or something else entirely?
In the context of government property and government speech, the ill-defined relationship between property and speech creates a massive but under appreciated theoretical and doctrinal problem, that threatens the very existence of the public forum. The arc of First Amendment jurisprudence, particularly as manifested in public forum doctrine, has been towards limiting the government’s right to exclude unwanted private speakers. Government speech doctrine, however, effectively reinvigorates the government’s right to exclude unwanted speakers by transforming speech regulations into governmental expressive conduct, which under current government speech doctrine is entirely exempt from constitutional review. The government can therefore invoke not only its property rights, but the expressive nature of their exercise.
Something has to give. Either not all property is expressive, or else not all expressive uses of government property are government “speech” exempt from constitutional scrutiny. Part I of this Article explores the first of these propositions, arguing that the relationship between speech and property requires a more nuanced treatment than it has heretofore received, and that property – whether conceived of as a thing, a legal entitlement, or a social relationship – both enables and is expression. But, as Part II of the Article shows, that conclusion cannot easily be extended into the context of government property and government speech. In government property/government speech cases such as Town of Pleasant Grove v. Summum, the question should be whether the government has the right to exclude unwanted speakers, not whether the exercise of such a right (assuming the government has it) is expressive. And the best way to answer the correct question is by looking not to formal property rights, but to social understandings of property
summary: This article explores the complex relationship between property and speech, particularly in the context of government property and government speech. It addresses whether property serves merely as a means of expression or can be expressive inherently, and the types of property essential for speakers. The author argues that an ill-defined connection creates a significant theoretical and doctrinal problem for the public forum, as government speech doctrine effectively allows the government to exclude private speakers by transforming speech regulations into governmental expressive conduct. The article proposes that not all property is expressive, nor are all expressive uses of government property government speech exempt from constitutional scrutiny, advocating for a nuanced treatment based on social understandings of property rather than formal rights to determine the government's right to exclude.

title: Evaluating the transition of e-Government: A review of local authorities in England
abstract: The goal of e-Government is seen as a panacea for governmental authorities. The emerging needs of citizens, their inclusion and engagement in policy development, political and participatory processes have meant new perspectives on e-Government are required. This paper seeks to identify and evaluate the preparedness of 10 UK-based local authorities to transition from basic e-Government to a more sophisticated and integrated e-Government. A categorical assessment of e-Government characteristics is made and these authorities are ranked accordingly.  Our findings reveal the majority of local authorities sampled had reached a high percentage of informational and transactional e-Government but few had reached the interactional level and none had achieved assimilation. This suggests that local authorities seem to have focused on basic e-Government services. There is a need now to forge ahead to integration and assimilation of e-Government in order to address the critical objectives of citizen inclusion and engagement, and alignment of institutional processes to provide an infrastructure for the transition to e-governance and e-knowledge
summary: This paper evaluates the preparedness of 10 UK-based local authorities to transition from basic e-Government to a more sophisticated and integrated e-Government. Using a categorical assessment of e-Government characteristics, the study ranks these authorities. Findings indicate that most sampled local authorities achieved high percentages in informational and transactional e-Government but few reached interactional levels, and none achieved assimilation. This suggests a focus on basic services, highlighting a need for integration and assimilation to address citizen inclusion, engagement, and institutional process alignment for e-governance and e-knowledge. Keywords: e-Government, local authorities, citizen engagement, digital government, public administration.

title: Government policy and the gray economy
summary:
This project, conducted from 2001-2002 by the Centre for Social Practices 
													– Sofia, defines and analyzes the 
													"gray economy" 
													as illegal or semi-legal exchange of otherwise legitimate services and goods. The goal is to reduce 
													the gray economy from a primary developmental obstacle to just one of many problems. 
													The study implicates government policy, specifically highlighting examples from 1997-2003 in Bulgaria 
													where state interference stimulated specific businesses, creating new problems rather than solutions, 
													and discusses barriers to market entry. Keywords: gray economy, government policy, Bulgaria, informal economy, black economy.

title: Direct and Indirect U.S. Government Debt
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government Debt, Public Finance, Special Purpose Entities, Sovereign Debt
summary: This paper examines the nature of U.S. government debt, focusing on both direct and indirect forms. It critically analyzes Professor Charles W. Mooney, Jr.'s draft paper on restructuring U.S. Treasury Securities, addressing specific terms of debt that should be restructured. Furthermore, the paper delves into indirect U.S. government debt, specifically financing raised through special-purpose entities (SPEs), and explores the potential ramifications of such financing. The discussion highlights the lack of covenants in federal debt compared to corporate debt and the limited monitoring incentives for citizens and creditors, emphasizing the importance of national-SPE accountability and reputation costs for the federal government.

title: Social Security: The Government Pension Offset
abstract: CRS ReportCRSGovtPensionOffset.pdf: 383 downloads, before Oct. 1, 2020
summary: This report, published by the Congressional Research Service, examines the Government Pension Offset (GPO) provision of Social Security, which affects individuals receiving both Social Security spousal benefits and a non-Social Security-covered government pension. It outlines the GPO's purpose, historical background, and current impact on beneficiaries. The document also analyzes the potential costs and implications of various legislative proposals (S. 363, H.R. 887) aimed at modifying or eliminating the GPO, including estimates from the CBO and SSA on long-range deficits and costs over a decade. The Social Security Subcommittee's hearing on GPO modifications is also mentioned.

title: Trends in Government Financing
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Economics, Government Finance, Fiscal Policy
summary: This chapter provides a detailed historical review of government expenditures, receipts, and deficits, along with the growth of government functions over recent decades, to enhance understanding of government financial requirements. Building on the previous chapter's argument that debt growth cannot be solely attributed to specific expenditures, the analysis emphasizes the time patterns of total nonfinancial expenditures and receipts. It examines federal fiscal operations, including trends in receipts, expenditures, and deficits, and discusses the increasing ratio of tax and nonfinancial receipts to GNP. Key findings include an upward trend in the number of different taxes, often reflecting political expediency, and significant shifts in government's share of the national product.

title: Financing Government Expenditures Optimally
abstract: In a simple cash-credit model, I study the effects of the combination of costly tax collection and tax evasion on fiscal and monetary policy for optimal resource allocation. Allowing the informal sector to use cash more intensively than the formal sector, I compute the optimal interest and tax rates for eleven OECD countries to finance their exogeneously given government spending. A comparison of the actual and optimal interest rates reveals that tax collection costs and tax evasion together can partly explain the cross-country differences in monetary policy, also rationalizing deviations from the Friedman Rule in the long-run.
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Fiscal Policy, Monetary Policy, Economics
summary: This paper investigates the interplay of costly tax collection and tax evasion on fiscal and monetary policy, focusing on optimal resource allocation within a cash-credit model. The study allows the informal sector to utilize cash more intensively and calculates optimal interest and tax rates for eleven OECD countries to fund government spending. Key findings indicate that the combined effect of tax collection costs and tax evasion partially explains cross-country differences in monetary policy and rationalizes long-term deviations from the Friedman Rule. This research contributes to understanding fiscal policy, monetary policy, tax evasion, and informal economy dynamics.

title: Trends in Government Financing
summary: This chapter, "Capital Requirements and the Budget," from a 1961 NBER volume by Morris A. Copeland, explores the historical and contemporary drivers of government debt, particularly distinguishing between war financing and tangible asset expenditures. It highlights that while war-related borrowing still dominates the federal debt, state and local governments have increasingly borrowed for tangible assets over the past fifty to sixty years. The document questions why public debt has grown, noting discrepancies such as increased state and local tangible asset investments alongside reduced net indebtedness between 1929 and 1946. It includes detailed tables on cash income and outgo, and flow of funds for 1947, sourced from the Federal Reserve Flow of Funds study, offering insights into public finance and budgeting practices. Key terms include government debt, war financing, public finance, state and local borrowing, and tangible assets.

title: U.S. Government Manual 2008-2009 Edition: National Labor Relations Board
abstract: [Excerpt] The National Labor Relations Board is vested with the power to prevent and remedy unfair labor practices committed by private sector employers and unions and to safeguard employees’ rights to organize and determine whether to have unions as their bargaining representative
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Government Printing Office, Federal Register, U.S. Government Manual, National Labor Relations Board
summary: This document, the "U.S. Government Manual 2008-2009 Edition: National Labor Relations Board," outlines the National Labor Relations Board's (NLRB) function and authority. It details the NLRB's power to prevent and remedy unfair labor practices by private sector employers and unions, and to safeguard employees' rights to organize and choose union representation. The publication also describes the Board's public information services and outreach efforts, including various manuals, reports, and speaking engagements by personnel to explain the National Labor Relations Act and the Board's procedures. Key terms include unfair labor practices, labor unions, and employee rights.

title: From the Grabbing Hand to the Helping Hand
abstract: I present a study of ownership of firms under government rent seeking.   Using its control of regulated inputs, a government agency extracts rents from a manager who undertakes an investment.  Such a government rent seeking activity leads to a typical hold-up problem.  Government ownership is shown to serve as a second best commitment mechanism through which the government agency will restrain itself from the rent seeking activity and even offer the manager support and favor such as tax breaks and subsidies.  This mechanism works at a cost as government ownership compromises ex post managerial incentives and creates distortion in resource allocation.  Nevertheless, under some fairly general conditions, government ownership Pareto dominates private ownership.  The analysis corresponds to a host of stylized empirical observations concerning local government-owned firms during China's transition to a market economy.  Based on this analysis, I suggest that local government owned firms will be   transformed to private ownership as China's input markets become more liberalized.http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/39448/3/wp58.pd
summary: This study examines firm ownership under government rent-seeking, where a government agency extracts rents from a manager through regulated inputs, creating a hold-up problem. It proposes that government ownership acts as a second-best commitment mechanism, restraining rent-seeking and offering support like tax breaks. Although government ownership compromises managerial incentives and distorts resource allocation, it can Pareto dominate private ownership under certain conditions. The analysis aligns with observations of local government-owned firms during China's market transition, suggesting a shift to private ownership as input markets liberalize. Keywords include Corruption, Bribery, Government Ownership, and China's Non-State Sector.

title: The Declaration of Independence and the American Theory of Government: “First Come Rights, and Then Comes Government”
abstract: The topic of this panel is the Declaration of Independence, to which I devoted a chapter of my recent book, Our Republican Constitution. I want to draw on that book to make five points
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Constitutional Law, Jurisprudence, Legal History
summary: This paper examines the Declaration of Independence as the true founding document of the United States, predating the Constitution and outlining the American theory of government where rights precede government. Drawing from the author's book "Our Republican Constitution," it makes five key points, challenging the notion that the Constitution is the primary foundational text. It argues that the principles justifying the Constitution are articulated in the Declaration, emphasizing the inherent rights of individuals as the basis for governmental legitimacy. This work is crucial for understanding American constitutional theory and the historical evolution of its governmental framework.

title: The relationship between government revenue and expenditure in Malaysia
abstract: The study examines the relationship between government revenue and expenditure in Malaysia. The results of the Dickey and Fuller (1979) and Phillips and Perron (1988) unit root test statistics show that government revenue and expenditure are integrated of order one. The results of the Johansen(1988) and Gregory and Hansen (1996) cointegration methods show that government revenue and expenditure are cointegrated. Thus, there is a longrun relationship between the government revenue and expenditure. The intertemporal budget constraint is not violated and the budget deficit of the Malaysian government is generally said to be sustainable. The results of the Granger-causality test generally show that the government revenue leads to government expenditure in Malaysia
summary: This study examines the long-run relationship between government revenue and expenditure in Malaysia using unit root tests (Dickey and Fuller, Phillips and Perron) and cointegration methods (Johansen, Gregory and Hansen). Findings indicate that revenue and expenditure are integrated of order one and cointegrated, signifying a sustainable budget deficit and adherence to intertemporal budget constraints. Granger-causality tests suggest that government revenue leads to government expenditure. This research contributes to understanding fiscal policy and budget sustainability in Malaysia, with keywords including budget deficit, government revenue, government expenditure, and cointegration.

title: Electronic transformation of government in the U.K.: a research agenda
abstract:
This paper presents the findings of an exploratory research project into future
e-Government (electronic Government) initiatives. The Virtual Institute for
Electronic Government Research (VIEGO) project aimed at identifying and
further developing the research agenda of e-Government based on a solid
practical ground. As such, the paper offers a novel methodology in identifying
the road map for future e-Government initiatives based on a series of
workshops organised around the U.K. hosting a mixture of stakeholders
involving both academics and parishioners. The analysis of the VIEGO
workshops depicted that an e-Government research agenda involves a
combination of social, technological and organisational issues at both
governmental and individual citizen level, ultimately driven by empirical
case-based experience and active participation in e-Government processes.
Unlike other propositions for the future of e-Government offered in the e-
Government literature, raised research questions not only originated from an
analysis of e-Government literature but also on the outcome of brainstorming,
reflections and contemplations throughout the duration of the project
summary: This paper presents an exploratory research project into future e-Government initiatives, specifically the Virtual Institute for Electronic Government Research (VIEGO) project. It introduces a novel methodology to identify a roadmap for e-Government based on workshops with academics and citizens across the U.K. The findings indicate that an e-Government research agenda encompasses social, technological, and organizational aspects at both governmental and individual levels, driven by empirical case-based experience and active participation. This approach contrasts with existing literature by incorporating brainstorming and project reflections beyond just literature analysis.

title: Trends in Government Financing
summary: This appendix provides a comprehensive compilation of statistical resources, books, and other documents cited in the volume "Trends in Government Financing." It primarily lists federal documents and publications, including annual reports from various government agencies such as the Department of Agriculture, Bureau of the Budget, and Bureau of the Census, covering topics like agricultural finance, government budgets, wealth, debt, and city government finances. The compilation also includes references to key academic works and historical studies on American public finance, state debts, and economic trends, serving as a foundational bibliography for research into government financial statistics.

title: Government-Mandated Discriminatory Policies
abstract: This paper provides a simple explanation for why some minority groups are economically successful, despite being subject to government-mandated discriminatory policies. We study an economy with private and public sectors in which workers invest in imperfectly observable skills that are important to the private sector but not to the public sector. A law allows native majority workers to be employed in the public sector with positive probability while excluding the minority from it. We show that even when the public sector offers the highest wage rate, it is still possible that the discriminated group is, on average, economically more successful. The reason is that the preferential policy lowers the majority's incentive to invest in imperfectly observable skills by exacerbating the informational free riding problem in the private sector labor marketDiscrimination; Informational Free Riding; Income Distribution
summary: This paper offers an explanation for the economic success of certain minority groups despite government-mandated discriminatory policies. The authors study an economy with private and public sectors where workers invest in imperfectly observable skills. A law allows majority workers into the public sector while excluding minorities. The key finding is that the discriminated group can be, on average, more successful because preferential policies reduce the majority's incentive to invest in skills by exacerbating informational free riding in the private labor market. This research provides insights into Discrimination, Informational Free Riding, and Income Distribution.

title: Constraining Public Employee Speech: Government’s Control of Its Workers’ Speech to Protect Its Own Expression
abstract: This Article identifies a key doctrinal shift in courts\u27 treatment Of public employees\u27 First Amendment claims-a shift that imperils the public\u27s interest in transparent government as well as the free speech rights of more than twenty million government workers. In the past, courts interpreted the First Amendment to permit governmental discipline of public employee speech on matters of public interest only when such speech undermined the government employer\u27s interest in efficiently providing public services. In contrast, courts now increasingly focus on-and defer to-government\u27s claim to control its workers\u27 expression to protect its own speech. More specifically, courts increasingly permit government to control its employees\u27 expression at work, characterizing this speech as the government\u27s own for which it has paid with a salary. This trend frustrates a meaningful commitment to republican government by allowing government officials to punish, and thus deter, whistleblowing and other valuable on-the-job speech that would otherwise facilitate the public\u27s ability to hold the government politically accountable for its choices. Courts also increasingly consider government workers to be speaking as employees even when away from work, deferring to the government\u27s assertion that its association with employees who engage in certain off-duty expression undermines its credibility in communicating its own contrary views. Implicit in courts\u27 reasoning is the premise that a public entity\u27s employment relationship with an individual who engages in certain expression communicates a substantive message to the public that the government is entitled to control. Courts\u27 unfettered deference to such claims would permit government agencies to fire workers for any unpopular or controversial off-duty speech to which the public might object, potentially enforcing orthodox expression as a condition of public employment. To be sure, government speech is as valuable as it is inevitable. But taken together, these trends lead to the rejection of government workers\u27 First Amendment claims in a growing number of cases that undermine workers\u27 free speech rights as well as the public\u27s interest in transparent government. Because of this shift\u27s normatively troubling implications, this Article proposes a new constitutional framework for public employee speech cases that attends more carefully to what it is that government seeks to communicate and whether that message is actually impaired by employee speech. It thus proposes a less deferential approach to assessing government\u27s expressive claims to its workers\u27 speech both on and off the job, exploring both categorical and contextual frameworks for identifying more precisely the comparatively small universe of workers\u27 speech that actually threatens government\u27s own expression
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Law, First Amendment, Public Administration
summary: This article analyzes a significant doctrinal shift in how courts handle public employees' First Amendment claims, arguing that this shift jeopardizes both transparent government and the free speech rights of government workers. Historically, courts allowed discipline only when speech hindered public services, but now increasingly defer to the government's asserted need to control employee expression, framing it as the government's own speech or protecting its credibility. This trend deters whistleblowing and off-duty speech, undermining public accountability. The article proposes a new constitutional framework to assess government's communicative interests more precisely, advocating a less deferential approach to protect employee speech rights and public transparency.

title: U.S. Government Manual 2008-2009 Edition (Appendix B): Terminated and Transferred Agencies
abstract: 233AA354d01.pdf: 85 downloads, before Oct. 1, 2020
summary: This document, the "U.S. Government Manual 2008-2009 Edition (Appendix B): Terminated and Transferred Agencies," serves as a comprehensive reference detailing the history of federal executive agencies. It meticulously lists governmental bodies that have been terminated, transferred, or reorganized, including their establishment and dissolution dates, and the executive orders or acts facilitating these changes. Key methods involve historical cataloging and cross-referencing official government publications. This resource is invaluable for understanding the evolution and restructuring of the United States federal government, providing critical data for researchers in political science and public administration.

title: Privatizing Public Litigation
abstract:
