These online services enable users to construct groups of contacts, referred to as friends, with which they can share digital content and communicate. This sharing is actively encouraged by the social networking services, with users privacy often seen as a secondary concern. In this paper we first propose a privacy-aware social networking service and then introduce a collaborative approach to authoring privacy policies for the service. In addressing user privacy, our approach takes into account the needs of all parties affected by the disclosure of information and digital content. © 2010 Crown
summary: This paper proposes a privacy-aware social networking service and a collaborative approach to authoring privacy policies. The purpose is to address user privacy concerns, often secondary in existing social networking services, by considering the needs of all parties affected by information disclosure. The methodology involves designing a service that promotes privacy and implementing a collaborative policy-making framework. This research is significant for improving user control over personal data and digital content sharing in online social environments. Keywords include social networking, privacy policies, collaborative authoring, and user privacy.

title: Global public policy, transnational policy communities, and their networks
abstract: Public policy has been a prisoner of the word "state." Yet, the state is reconfigured by globalization. Through "global public–private partnerships" and "transnational executive networks," new forms of authority are emerging through global and regional policy processes that coexist alongside nation-state policy processes. Accordingly, this article asks what is "global public policy"? The first part of the article identifies new public spaces where global policies occur. These spaces are multiple in character and variety and will be collectively referred to as the "global agora." The second section adapts the conventional policy cycle heuristic by conceptually stretching it to the global and regional levels to reveal the higher degree of pluralization of actors and multiple-authority structures than is the case at national levels. The third section asks: who is involved in the delivery of global public policy? The focus is on transnational policy communities. The global agora is a public space of policymaking and administration, although it is one where authority is more diffuse, decision making is dispersed and sovereignty muddled. Trapped by methodological nationalism and an intellectual agoraphobia of globalization, public policy scholars have yet to examine fully global policy processes and new managerial modes of transnational public administration
summary: This article explores the concept of "global public policy," arguing that traditional public policy analysis, constrained by the notion of the "state," fails to account for new forms of authority emerging through globalization. It identifies "global agora" as new public spaces for policy and adapts the conventional policy cycle to global and regional levels, revealing increased actor pluralization and multiple-authority structures. The paper examines the role of transnational policy communities in delivering global public policy, highlighting that this policymaking space is characterized by diffuse authority, dispersed decision-making, and muddled sovereignty, advocating for a more comprehensive examination of global policy processes and transnational public administration.

title: Policy vs. Ethics
fieldOfStudy: Ethics and Political Philosophy, Medicine and Health Sciences, Bioethics
summary: This article by Warren T. Reich examines the 1971 revision of the Ethical and Religious Directives for Catholic Health Facilities. Reich questions the strict insistence on their acceptance and application, arguing that the primary issue is the directives' emphasis as hospital policy rather than ethical statements. He explores the implications of this policy-versus-ethics framework, considering how exceptions should be managed to prevent harm and maintain the Catholic health facility's communal role and the moral welfare of others, particularly regarding issues like hysterectomy and moral applicability doubts.

title: Is European climate policy the new CAP?
abstract:
In its third phase (2013-20) the European Union's emissions trading system (ETS) will issue allowances for around two billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent each year. The emission rights are valued at around Â?30-35 billion at current prices, between one-half and two-thirds of the amount the EU spends on the Common Agricultural Policy. The redistributive effects of the allocation of emission allowances are therefore potentially significant. Quantitative indicators for the relative degree to which individual countries will be affected by the ETS suggest that economic consequences for the member states will be quite different. In this policy brief, Georg Zachmann finds that countries with less favourable initial conditions are eventually largely compensated. 
 Click here here  to download the ETS indicators by country 
 Bruegel also produced a video of the author Georg Zachmann commenting on the findings of his policy brief.Watch the video
summary:
This policy brief examines the redistributive effects of the European Union's Emissions Trading System (ETS) during its third phase (2013-20), where allowances for around two billion tonnes of CO2 equivalent are issued annually, valued at 
	
30-35 billion. The study uses quantitative indicators to assess how individual countries are affected economically by the ETS, finding that countries initially facing less favorable conditions are largely compensated through the allocation of free emission rights and auction revenues. The author argues against additional exceptions that could compromise ETS efficiency and advocates for a faster shift from free allowances to auction revenue allocation.

title: Policy 13 : Policy on Student Conduct and Discipline Procedures
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Student Conduct, Education Policy, Discipline Procedures
summary: This policy document, adopted on September 15, 2009, outlines the regulations concerning student conduct and discipline procedures. It defines student rights and responsibilities, establishes a student code of conduct, and details the disciplinary processes, including sanctions and appeal mechanisms. Key roles are assigned to the Director of Student Services and the Director of Continuing Education, with final appeals directed to the Director General or the Executive Committee of the Board of Governors. The Student Union is highlighted as a resource for students involved in disciplinary cases. This policy aims to ensure fairness and transparency in handling student behavioral issues.

title: Sustainability Policy and Environmental Policy
abstract: A representative agent economy with a resource stock, polluting emissions, productive, abatement and foreign capital, trade, and technical progress, is used to contrast environmental policy, which internalises amenity and productivity values, with sustainability policy, which achieves some form of intergenerational equity. Environmental policy comprises a tax on emissions and a subsidy on the resource stock equal to the respective externalised costs or benefits. Sustainability policy comprises a capital and/or consumption tax to change the effective utility discount rate. Environmental policy can reduce the strength of sustainability policy needed. More specialised results are derived in a closed economy with a non-renewable resource and no technical progress, and in a small open economy with few environmental effects.
summary: This study contrasts environmental policy, which internalizes amenity and productivity values through emission taxes and resource subsidies, with sustainability policy, focused on intergenerational equity via capital/consumption taxes altering the utility discount rate. Using a representative agent economy model encompassing resource stocks, emissions, capital, trade, and technical progress, the research demonstrates that environmental policy can reduce the necessity for strong sustainability measures. Specialized findings are also presented for closed economies with non-renewable resources and small open economies with limited environmental impacts, providing insights into optimal policy design for economic growth and environmental quality.

title: Sustainability Policy and Environmental Policy
abstract: A theoretical, representative agent economy with a depletable resource stock, polluting emissions and productive capital is used to contrast environmental policy, which internalises externalised environmental values, with sustainability policy, which achieves some form of intergenerational equity. The obvious environmental policy comprises an emissions tax and a resource stock subsidy, each equal to the respective external cost or benefit. Sustainability policy comprises an incentive affecting the choice between consumption and investment, and can be a consumption tax, capital subsidy or investment subsidy, or combination thereof. Environmental policy can reduce the strength of sustainability policy needed. More specialised results are derived in a closed economy with a non-renewable resource, and in a small open economy with no environmental effects on utility.sustainability, optimality, externalities, tax, policy
summary: This paper uses a theoretical, representative agent economy with a depletable resource, polluting emissions, and productive capital to differentiate environmental policy from sustainability policy. Environmental policy aims to internalize external environmental values, typically through an emissions tax and resource stock subsidy. Sustainability policy, in contrast, focuses on intergenerational equity, using incentives like consumption taxes or capital subsidies to influence consumption-investment choices. The research finds that environmental policy can reduce the need for strong sustainability policies. More specific results are derived for a closed economy with non-renewable resources and a small open economy.

title: Security Policy Consistency
abstract:
With the advent of wide security platforms able to express simultaneously all
the policies comprising an organization's global security policy, the problem
of inconsistencies within security policies become harder and more relevant.
  We have defined a tool based on the CHR language which is able to detect
several types of inconsistencies within and between security policies and other
specifications, namely workflow specifications.
  Although the problem of security conflicts has been addressed by several
authors, to our knowledge none has addressed the general problem of security
inconsistencies, on its several definitions and target specifications.Comment: To appear in the first CL2000 workshop on Rule-Based Constraint
  Reasoning and Programmin
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Security Policy, Constraint Handling Rules, Workflow Specifications
summary: This paper addresses the growing problem of inconsistencies within global security policies, especially with the advent of wide security platforms. The authors introduce a tool based on the CHR (Constraint Handling Rules) language designed to detect various types of inconsistencies. This tool identifies conflicts within and between security policies and other specifications, notably workflow specifications. While security conflicts have been explored, this work aims to tackle the broader issue of general security inconsistencies across diverse definitions and target specifications, providing a comprehensive approach to policy management and conflict resolution. This is crucial for robust security platforms.

title: National Health Policy
authors: Ministry of Health and Social Welfare, (MoHSW)
summary: This document outlines the National Health Policy of the United Republic of Tanzania, developed by the Ministry of Health in October 2003. It details the health sector's administrative structure, the Ministry's role, and the country's demographic and economic context impacting health. The policy articulates its vision, mission, objectives, and strategies for health services in Tanzania, including decentralization, health sector reform advocacy, and inter-sectoral cooperation. It also emphasizes basic essential healthcare, national standards for facilities and staff, and data collection requirements, ensuring patient confidentiality.

title: Subject: Public Policy
abstract: Compiled by Susan LaCette.PublicPolicy.pdf: 695 downloads, before Oct. 1, 2020
summary: This document, compiled by Susan LaCette in 2006 for Cornell University's ILR School, presents a bibliography of theses and dissertations related to public policy. It serves as a comprehensive listing of graduate research from the ILR School, focusing on various aspects of public policy, industrial and labor relations. Key topics include the influence of government policy on wages in specific industries, the development of labor policy and legislation in different countries, and public policy concerning the employment and rehabilitation of veterans. The collection offers valuable resources for researchers in labor, industrial relations, and public policy.

title: Policy for Maori: values, assumptions and closing the gap
abstract:
This paper looks at the issue of what it is about the way in which policy is developed which
influences whether or not policy meets the needs of Maori. To do this I will focus on one component
of policy making; the role of the values and assumptions of policy makers. Assumptions about the
nature of policy making and the way in which policy can be used to maintain and modify norms and
standards, determine values and define problems are briefly investigated. These issues are
highlighted using the Code of Family and Social Responsibility as an example of the way in which
dominant cultural value bases and assumptions have influenced the way in which policy issues are
framed and presented. The paper concludes by asking why the consideration of the values of policy
makers is important for Maori and how can I, as a Maori policy analyst working within the
Government policy making sector, contribute to the development of policy which is based on Maori
assumptions, realities, values and world views
publisher: Maori and Psychology Research Unit, University of Waikato
summary: This paper examines how policy development influences its effectiveness for Māori, focusing on the values and assumptions of policymakers. It investigates how these assumptions impact the framing of policy issues, using the Code of Family and Social Responsibility as an example of dominant cultural influences. The study highlights the importance of considering policymakers' values for Māori and explores how a Māori policy analyst can contribute to policy based on Māori assumptions, realities, values, and worldviews. Key concepts include policy making, cultural values, Māori needs, and policy analysis.

title: Inequality as Policy: The United States Since 1979
abstract: Since the end of the 1970s, the United States has seen a dramatic increase in economic inequality. While the United States has long been among the most unequal of the world’s rich economies, the economic and social upheaval that began in the 1970s was a striking departure from the movement toward greater equality that began in the Great Depression, continued through World War II, and was a central feature of the first 30 years of the postwar period. This is not due to chance circumstances but is the direct result of a set of policies designed first and foremost to increase inequality.inequality
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Economic Policy, Labor Relations, Income Inequality
summary: This document examines the dramatic increase in economic inequality in the United States since the late 1970s, presenting it not as a chance occurrence but as the direct result of deliberate policies. It contrasts this trend with the movement towards greater equality observed from the Great Depression through the post-World War II period. The analysis challenges the neoclassical economics framework, arguing that wage levels are influenced by factors beyond skill, such as unionization, minimum wage, regulatory frameworks, public sector size, and market competition. The key finding is that the rise in inequality stems from a shift in the balance of power between workers and employers, rather than a preference for inequality or an inherent historical trend, offering insights into economic policy and labor relations.

title: The processes of reform in Victoria’s alcohol and other drug sector, 2011-2014
abstract:
This paper explores issues and concerns related to the 2014 alcohol and other drug sector recommissioning process in Victoria.

Overview

In mid-2014, the Victorian Alcohol and Drug Association approached the Drug Policy Modelling Program, at the National Drug and Alcohol Research Centre, University of New South Wales to undertake a project exploring and describing issues and concerns related to the 2014 alcohol and other drug sector recommissioning process in Victoria. This project commenced in July 2014 and concluded in November 2014. Policy documents and allied material were reviewed, and 20 stakeholders from 18 alcohol and other drug sector organisations were consulted. These stakeholders were CEOs/senior managers during the reform period
summary: This paper investigates the 2014 alcohol and other drug sector recommissioning process in Victoria, Australia. The project, conducted by the Drug Policy Modelling Program, reviewed policy documents and consulted 20 stakeholders from 18 organizations to identify key issues and concerns. It aims to describe the reform's stages and activities, focusing on the competitive tendering approach, funding, contract management, and transitional arrangements. The study also seeks to identify strengths and areas for improvement in the recommissioning process. Keywords: alcohol and drug policy, sector reform, recommissioning, Victoria, public health.

title: Russia's military policy
publisher: Boston University Center for the Study of Conflict, Ideology, and Policy
summary: This paper, written by Col. General D.I. Volkogonov in 1992, analyzes the complex challenge of defining Russia's military policy in the wake of the USSR's dissolution. It addresses the division of the former Soviet armed forces, the presence of nuclear weapons across new states, and Russia's need to establish a new defense doctrine focused on sovereignty and conflict prevention, in cooperation with allies. The article highlights the shift towards a humanistic worldview within the Russian military, marked by the establishment of a Humanistic Academy and the retirement of old generals, signaling a new, younger army committed to democratic development.

title: Extension research policy
summary: This paper discusses extension research policy and its integration into extension education curricula, drawing on ten years of experience in the field. It outlines three career paths for extension education graduates—extension officers/administrators, specialists in extension methods, and extension research workers—and details the curriculum requirements for each. The author emphasizes the need for practical apprenticeship in research for aspiring extension research workers and advocates for dedicated research time for senior staff in extension education departments to facilitate junior staff participation. The document underscores the importance of problem-solving skills and effective communication within university administration.

title: Differential Pricing Policy
abstract: Differential pricing is a valid means of improving profits, keeping the total cost of air transportation down, and making it possible for more people to use air transportation
summary: This paper discusses differential pricing policies within the airline industry, specifically focusing on passenger pricing. Drawing from monopolistic theory, the author explains how successful market discrimination can increase total profits without expanding investment. The discussion covers two main methods: discriminating among markets (more complex) and matching peak demand with peak pricing (simpler, often more effective in practice). The author emphasizes the challenges of aligning theoretical applications with actual practice, stressing the need for caution and restraint from carriers and regulators when implementing promotional pricing, and advocating for thorough evaluation of pricing experiments. Differential pricing can enhance profits and make air travel more accessible.

title: Early years policy
abstract: We analyze the role that early years policy might play in narrowing educational attainment gaps. We begin by examining gaps in school readiness between low-, middle-, and high-income children, drawing on data from new large and nationally representative birth cohort studies in the USA and UK. We find that sizable income-related gaps in school readiness are present in both countries before children enter school and then decompose these gaps to identify the factors that account for the poorer scores of low-income children. We then consider what role early years policy could play in tackling these gaps, drawing on the best available evidence to identify promising programs
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Early Childhood Education, Public Policy
summary: This study analyzes the role of early years policy in narrowing educational attainment gaps, drawing on data from nationally representative birth cohort studies in the USA and UK. Researchers identify sizable income-related gaps in school readiness before children enter school and decompose these gaps to understand factors contributing to poorer scores for low-income children. The paper then considers promising programs and policy interventions to address these disparities. Key findings highlight significant early educational inequalities and the potential of targeted early years policy.

title: The $746 Million A Year School-to-Prison Pipeline: The Ineffective, Discriminatory, and Costly Process of Criminalizing New York City Students
abstract: This report, released by the Center for Popular Democracy and Urban Youth Collaborative, reveals the staggering yearly economic impact of the school-to-prison pipeline in New York City, $746.8 million. In addition, it presents a bold "Young People's School Justice Agenda," which calls on the City to divest from over-policing young people, and invest in supportive programs and opportunities for students to thrive. New evidence of the astronomical fiscal and social costs of New York's school-to-prison pipeline demand urgent action by policymakers. The young people who are most at risk of harm due to harsh policing and disciplinary policies are uniquely situated to lead the dialogue about developing truly safe and equitable learning environments. This report highlights the vision for safe, supportive, and inclusive schools developed by these youth leaders
summary: This report by the Center for Popular Democracy and Urban Youth Collaborative quantifies the substantial yearly economic impact of the school-to-prison pipeline in New York City, estimated at $746.8 million. It proposes a "Young People's School Justice Agenda," advocating for divesting from over-policing and investing in supportive student programs. The report emphasizes the critical need for policymakers to address these fiscal and social costs, highlighting the vision of youth leaders for safe, supportive, and inclusive learning environments. Keywords: school-to-prison pipeline, New York City, youth justice, policing, education policy, economic impact, student support, social costs.

title: China's e-democracy in information age
abstract: E-democracy is a new type of democracy in Information Age. At first, the paper discusses the definitions of democracy and e-democracy, and then the paper analyzes the advantages and problems of E-democracy in China. Finally the paper investigates the future of e-democracy in China
summary: This paper explores the concept of e-democracy within the context of China, defining both democracy and e-democracy in the Information Age. It analyzes the advantages and disadvantages of e-democracy in China, examining specific challenges like authentication and information disclosure. The study then investigates the future prospects of e-democracy in the country, suggesting that continuous improvement will lead to a positive trajectory despite current imperfections. Keywords include E-democracy, Information Age, and China.

title: Developmental Democracy in Africa: A Review
abstract: Democracy is one of the virtues we ache for, as many now observe an undemocratic society as a savage society. Richard L. Sklar built up a hypothesis called developmental democracy in which he opines that democracy will essentially prompts the improvement of African people and states. For the most part, there has been contention whether development precedes democracy or rather democracy helps development, which is very much unclear. Regardless of the answer, since the prodemocracy charges hit Africa since 1990s, democracy has not made substantial strides. There have still been huge issues of underdevelopment, corruption and mal-administration. Many have started scrutinizing the possibility of democracy been ideal for Africa. The purpose of this paper is to audit the possibility of developmental democracy within African context. This paper presents that democracy is not ideal for Africa, it likewise guarantees that, if democracy is really what it is said to be, there would not have been any requirement for polarization, for instance, developmental, liberal, social democracies and so on. This is because any democracy will essentially include all. It is on this background that the paper attempts to criticize Richard’s Sklar’s idea of developmental democracy
summary: This paper critically examines Richard L. Sklar's hypothesis of developmental democracy within the African context, challenging the notion that democracy inherently fosters development in African states. Despite pro-democracy movements since the 1990s, the continent continues to grapple with underdevelopment, corruption, and mal-administration. The authors argue that democracy may not be ideal for Africa, contending that a truly encompassing democracy would not necessitate various polarized forms (e.g., developmental, liberal, social). This review aims to audit and criticize Sklar's idea by highlighting the persistent issues and questioning democracy's suitability for Africa's unique challenges.

title: Democratisation in the Middle East and North Africa : perspectives from democracy support
abstract: This article offers perspectives on the prospects for democratisation in the Middle East North Africa (MENA) region in the light of political developments since 2010, with particular reference to international democracy support. An introduction shares certain assumptions about democracy support’s general record before threats and opportunities to democracy support arising from developments in the region are discussed. Next democracy support’s response to those developments is examined, while the fourth section highlights some challenges for democracy support in the region and beyond. Throughout, discussion is contextualised within the larger literature on democratisation. Final remarks lead to the conclusion that developments in the region both present challenges that should be viewed as opportunities, and offer opportunities that will be challenging to address, not just for democracy support in the region and further afield but in terms of the guidance that democratisation studies have to offer
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Democratization, Middle East, North Africa, Democracy Support
summary: This article examines the prospects for democratization in the Middle East North Africa (MENA) region, focusing on political developments since 2010 and the role of international democracy support. It discusses the general record of democracy support, along with threats and opportunities arising from regional events. The article analyzes the response of democracy support to these developments and outlines future challenges, contextualizing the discussion within existing literature on democratization. It concludes that regional changes present both challenges as opportunities and opportunities that will be challenging to address for democracy support and democratisation studies.

title: More Democracy Is Not Better Democracy: Cain's Case for Reform Pluralism
abstract:
This article is part of a symposium on Bruce Cain's "Democracy More or Less: America’s Political
          Reform Quandary." It identifies the basic normative framework of Cain's skeptical "reform pluralism" as a form of democratic instrumentalism rather than political realism, and then argues that a more optimistic instrumentalist alternative is available. The instrumentalist can accept that more democracy need not entail better democracy. But the instrumentalist account of better democracy also gives us reason to believe that significant reform efforts remain worth pursuing, for the simple reason that some of them have worked in the past
summary: This article, part of a symposium on Bruce Cain's "Democracy More or Less," analyzes Cain's "reform pluralism" as democratic instrumentalism, contrasting it with political realism. It argues that while more democracy does not necessarily mean better democracy, an optimistic instrumentalist perspective still justifies pursuing significant reform efforts. The author contends that historical successes in reform provide a strong basis for continued engagement in developing a better culture of democratic citizenship, moving beyond populist approaches focused solely on maximizing democratic participation.

title: Democratic Education in an Era of Town Hall Protests
abstract: One central aspect of a healthy democracy is the practice of democratic dissent. For the first time in many years, dissent is being widely practiced in town hall meetings and on street corners across the United States. Despite this presence, dissent is often suppressed or omitted in the prescribed, tested, hidden, and external curriculum of US schools. This article calls for a realignment of these aspects of curriculum with both a guiding vision of ideal democracy and a realistic interpretation of democracy as it is currently invoked in order to maximize this historic moment and work toward more robust democracy as a whole. This article will define dissent, show why it matters for healthy democracy, describe its role in the conscious social reproduction of citizens, reveal implications of the current more consensus-oriented forms of democracy portrayed in US schools, and call for new work on consensus and dissent in schools given changes in the present environment
summary: This article defines democratic dissent, argues for its importance in a healthy democracy, and examines its role in citizen social reproduction. It reveals the implications of current consensus-oriented democratic portrayals in US schools and advocates for a realignment of curriculum to embrace dissent, particularly during contemporary town hall protests. The paper proposes new work on consensus and dissent in educational settings, aiming to maximize this historic moment for a more robust democracy. Keywords: democratic dissent, curriculum, US schools, town hall meetings, political education.

title: Taiwan's Democracy: Towards a liberal democracy or authoritarianism?
abstract: This paper examines how Taiwan moved from being viewed as a model Asian democracy to one allegedly suffering from democratic reversal. The reasons for the declining domestic and international reputa- tion of Taiwan’s democracy are discussed. Lastly, some key political challenges facing Taiwan’s democracy are outlined
summary: This paper analyzes Taiwan's democratic trajectory, examining its transition from a perceived model Asian democracy to one facing allegations of democratic reversal. The study discusses the underlying reasons for the decline in Taiwan's domestic and international reputation regarding its democratic status. It concludes by outlining the significant political challenges currently confronting Taiwan's democracy, focusing on the debate between liberal democracy and potential authoritarianism. Keywords: Taiwan, democracy, democratic reversal, political challenges, authoritarianism, liberal democracy.

title: Relationship between Income and Emergence of Democracy Reexamined, 1820-2000: A non-parametric approach
abstract: The paper contrasts Lipset’s modernization hypothesis and Przeworski- Limongi hypothesis that entries into democracy are random with respect to income. We use data on income and democracy going back to 1820, multiple definitions of democracy, and non-parametric testing focusing on the distribution of entrants’ incomes. We find that income matters for entry into higher levels of democracy; but if we control for the previously achieved level of democracy, the income effect vanishes. This means that countries that enter into higher levels of democracy are not a random draw from the universe of all country incomes but are a random draw from the joint distribution of previous level of democracy and income. These results are compatible with the presence of a subgroup of (low) income and (low) democracy countries from which recruitment into democracy is seldom made. But for other countries, accession to higher levels of democracy is income-random. Income seems therefore both to matter (probably explaining why poor countries cannot improve their democracy levels) and not matter (explaining why for other countries improvements in democracy are income-random).Democracy, income, modernization
summary: This paper reexamines the relationship between income and the emergence of democracy, contrasting Lipset's modernization hypothesis with the Przeworski-Limongi hypothesis. Utilizing data on income and democracy from 1820 and multiple definitions of democracy, the study employs non-parametric testing to analyze the distribution of entrants' incomes. Findings indicate that income matters for achieving higher levels of democracy, but this effect vanishes when controlling for previously attained democracy levels. This suggests that countries entering higher democracy are not a random draw from all incomes, but rather from the joint distribution of prior democracy and income, implying income explains why poor countries struggle to improve democracy, yet for others, improvements are income-random. Keywords: democracy, income, modernization, political science.

title: From evaluating democracy assistance to appraising democracy promotion
abstract: Organisations involved in delivering international democracy assistance are engaging increasingly with questions about how to assess their activities. A double shift in the terms of reference, from the ex post evaluation of assistance projects or programmes to ex ante appraisal of the broader democracy promotion strategies, could make democracy promotion more effective. This does not mean abandoning the former; on the contrary its status would be enhanced. Improving the chain of learning that leads from assistance evaluations to the formulation of promotion strategies could improve decision-making over how and whether to promote democracy abroad. Because strategies for democracy promotion are constitutive of the political relationship with countries, different strategies have different implications for the possibilities of political self-determination. For that reason and because democratisation and hence effective democracy promotion may be beneficial for human development, international peace and national security, strategies that reflect informed appraisal would be an improvement on a defective status quo. The challenges include: more systematic data gathering; innovative ways of comparing the various democracy promotion options; and institutional changes that connect the research findings to the high politics of policy-making
summary: This paper argues for a shift in assessing international democracy assistance, moving from ex post evaluation of projects to ex ante appraisal of broader democracy promotion strategies. This 'double shift' aims to enhance effectiveness by improving the learning chain from evaluations to strategy formulation, thereby informing decision-making on promoting democracy abroad. The authors emphasize that different strategies impact political self-determination and can benefit human development, peace, and security. Key challenges include systematic data gathering, comparing promotion options, and integrating research findings into policy-making, advocating for informed appraisal over the current status quo.

title: Pers, Demokrasi Dan Negara Indonesia Post-Soeharto: Sebuah Perspektif
abstract: The resignation of President Soeharto in May 1998 marked the end of new order era and started a fundamental change within democracy in Indonesia. As a democratic state, Indonesia arguably provides a system to guarantee the freedom of press and good environment of mass media; as the media is supposedly not to be power driven. Several factors have been observed to understand the relationship between press and democracy. Those are democratic revolution, freedom of press, political oligarchy, the role of students, and criminal democracy practice in Indonesia. This article found that under  the President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono-Boediono (SBY-Boediono) era, newspeople freedom in journalism was gripped by the practice of "criminal democracy" which continues to undermine the development of press freedom. To conclude, democracy in Indonesia is decayed by unjust practices from the political elites; it further affects the way press and mass media in performing their roles as the fourth pillar of democracy
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Democracy, Press Freedom, Oligarchy, Governance
summary: This article examines the evolution of press freedom and democracy in post-Soeharto Indonesia, analyzing factors like democratic revolution, political oligarchy, and the role of students. It argues that despite a constitutional guarantee for press freedom, the period under President Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono-Boediono saw "criminal democracy" practices gripping journalism, undermining its development. The study concludes that unjust practices by political elites have decayed Indonesian democracy, consequently affecting the press and mass media's ability to function as the fourth pillar of democracy, highlighting issues of poor governance and oligarchy.

title: Proxy of democracy? : metaphors of connection as arguments against representation
abstract: This paper aims to assess the arguments that claim representative democracy may be enhanced or replaced by an updated electronic version. Focusing on the dimension of elections and electioneering as the core mechanism of representative democracy I will discuss: (1) the proximity argument used to claim the necessity of filling the gap between decision-makers and stakeholders; (2) the transparency argument, which claims to remove obstacles to the publicity of power; (3) the bottom-up argument, which calls for a new form of legitimacy that goes beyond classical mediation of parties or unions; (4) the public sphere argument, referred to the problem of hierarchical relation between voters and their representatives; (5) the disintermediation argument, used to describe the (supposed) new form of democracy following the massive use of ICTs. The first way of conceptualizing e-democracy as different from mainstream 20th century representative democracy regimes is to imagine it as a new form direct democracy: this conception is often underlying contemporary studies of e-voting. To avoid some of the ingenuousness of this conception of e-democracy, we should take a step back and consider a broader range of issues than mere gerrymandering around the electoral moment. Therefore I shall problematize the abovementioned approach by analyzing a wider range of problems connected to election and electioneering in their relation with ICTs
summary: This paper assesses arguments for enhancing or replacing representative democracy with an electronic version, focusing on elections. It discusses five arguments: proximity (bridging gap between decision-makers and stakeholders), transparency (publicity of power), bottom-up legitimacy (beyond traditional mediation), public sphere (voters-representatives hierarchy), and disintermediation (democracy via ICTs). The author critiques the direct democracy conception often underlying e-voting studies, advocating for a broader analysis of election-related issues in relation to Information and Communication Technologies (ICTs) to avoid naive interpretations and update political categories.

title: Statement of Richard Bensinger Before the Commission on the Future of Worker-Management Relations
abstract: Includes author's essay "When a democracy isn't a democracy".Testimony_Bensinger_081094.pdf: 402 downloads, before Oct. 1, 2020
summary: Richard Bensinger's statement to the Commission on the Future of Worker-Management Relations critiques the decline of worker protections and union organizing rights in the United States. He argues that legal loopholes, weak enforcement, and union-busting tactics have undermined collective bargaining, leading to a significant drop in union elections despite consistent public approval for unions. Bensinger emphasizes the disparity between US support for workers' rights abroad and the suppression of such rights domestically, advocating for stronger protections to enable workers' voices to be heard, linking this to broader economic issues like the decline of the middle class.

title: E-democracy and values in information systems design
abstract: In this paper I demonstrate the utility of a Values in Design (VID) perspective for the assessment, the design and development of e-democracy tools. In the first part, I give some background information on Values in Design and Value-Sensitive Design and their relevance in the context of e-democracy. In part 2, I analyze three different e-democracy tools from a VID-perspective. The paper ends with some conclusions concerning the merits of VID for e-democracy as well as some considerations concerning the dual tasks of philosophers in assessing and promoting value-sensitive technology design
summary: This paper explores the utility of a Values in Design (VID) perspective for evaluating, designing, and developing e-democracy tools. It provides background on Values in Design and Value-Sensitive Design, analyzing three e-democracy tools through a VID lens. The author concludes by highlighting the merits of VID for e-democracy and discussing the dual role of philosophers in assessing and promoting value-sensitive technology design. The research suggests that philosophical analyses of ICT and e-democracy can extend beyond textual or conceptual levels to include the material and technical aspects.

title: Promoting democracy backwards: looking forward
abstract: A typology of the diverse ways in which international dimensions of democratization and democracy assistance itself actually retard and undermine democracy’s progress around the world provides a salutary response to currently fashionable ideas of democracy promotion as a world value. The detailed typology presented here offers an aid to thinking and practice concerning what approaches to take to the international promotion of democracy in the future. But as is the case with the already well established idea of ‘democratization backwards’, so it is equally true when looking forward that ‘promoting democracy backwards’ implies no one determinate eventual outcome. The analysis implicitly raises the question whether the time has now come not just for the practice of democracy promotion to widen its lens but for studies of it to broaden their horizons too
publisher: Fundación para las Relaciones Internacionales y el Diálogo Exterior (FRIDE)
summary: This paper presents a typology of how international dimensions of democratization and democracy assistance can inadvertently hinder democracy's global progress. It challenges prevailing ideas of democracy promotion as a universal value by offering a detailed framework for future approaches to international democracy promotion. Drawing parallels with 'democratization backwards,' the analysis suggests that 'promoting democracy backwards' does not guarantee a specific outcome. The work implicitly calls for a broader perspective in both the practice and study of democracy promotion, providing a critical aid for thinking and practice in the field.

title: Two Cheers for Czech Democracy
abstract: The paper discusses the state of Czech democracy and current research agendas on democracy in the Czech Republic, focusing in particular on the role of political parties. It considers Czech democracy both in relation to Central and Eastern Europe (CEE) and in the light of the evolving relationship between CEE and Western Europe. It suggests that current CEE states such as the Czech Republic gradually approximating to models of West European-style party politics may need rethinking. It then examines democracy in the Czech Republic in relation to debates on democratic “backsliding”, arguing that in the Czech cases the principal “backsliding” risks lie less in the rise of authoritarian populists than a potential crisis of democratic representation driven by perceptions of corruption. The paper concludes with some suggestions about future avenues for research on Czech and CEE democracy
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Czech Republic, Central and Eastern Europe, democracy, political parties
summary: This paper examines the state of Czech democracy and current research agendas, focusing on the role of political parties within Central and Eastern Europe (CEE). It challenges the assumption that CEE states are merely approximating West European party politics models. The authors argue that the primary risks to Czech democracy stem from a potential crisis of democratic representation driven by perceptions of corruption, rather than the rise of authoritarian populists. The study concludes with suggestions for future research on Czech and CEE democracy, offering insights into political parties, democratic backsliding, and corruption.

title: We are not ‘all in this together’: British democracy is suffering from the disconnect between politicians and the wider public
abstract: Recent failures of British democracy lead voters to feel that being ignored by Government is the most likely consequence of casting a vote and participating in democracy, writes Mary Evans
publisher: Blog post from London School of Economics & Political Science
summary: This article by Mary Evans examines the growing disconnect between British politicians and the public, leading to voter disenfranchisement. It argues that recent failures of British democracy, such as policies like NHS reorganization and spending cuts, make voters feel ignored despite their participation. The author questions the efficacy of elections when public concerns are overlooked, citing a lack of integration of expert opinion and a rhetorical focus on "listening" without genuine engagement. The piece highlights the absence of connections between social issues and political economy, and between knowledge and its application, resulting in an unrepresentative government. Keywords: British democracy, political disconnect, voter disenfranchisement, public opinion, government accountability.

title: International democracy promotion: a role for public goods theory?
abstract: The state of international democracy promotion is in flux. After more than fifteen years of increasing activity and with more organisations and resources devoted to promoting democracy than ever before, a mood of uncertainty surrounds democracy support's current performance and future prospects. The last decade has also seen the emergence of a new literature on global public goods theory, offering fresh analytical perspectives on pressing issues in international affairs like peace, security, development, and environmental sustainability. The future of democracy promotion will be determined chiefly by the realities of the political market place, in societies on both sides of the relationship. But could recent theorising about the market for global public goods offer some analytical support for making sense of its current condition and, by identifying the democratic peace as a global public good strengthen the case for greater international cooperation in promoting democracy as means to achieve that end
fieldOfStudy: Politics, International Relations, Global Public Goods
summary: This paper examines the evolving landscape of international democracy promotion, noting increased activity but also a prevailing mood of uncertainty regarding its performance and future. It explores how global public goods theory, a new analytical framework in international affairs, could offer fresh perspectives. The author investigates whether conceptualizing the democratic peace as a global public good might strengthen the rationale for greater international cooperation in democracy promotion. This theoretical lens aims to help make sense of the current condition and future prospects of democracy support within the international political marketplace, identifying avenues for enhanced collaborative efforts.

title: Teachers of Secondary School as democracy coaches: study of their conceptions during their initial formation
abstract: This study has been developed within the framework of a European Erasmus + project called ELEF†. The aim of this project is to develop, implement, evaluate and replicate innovative democratic learning environments. With this purpose, the Democracy Coaches are trained as agents of citizen participation and generators of democracy, both in educational centres and in informal educational settings. In this context, and during various training sessions, the Democracy Coaches work with the knowledge and skills they need to acquire. This paper focuses on the study and analysis carried out on the concepts expressed by these teachers of secondary education during their training. In order for them to become democracy coaches in the formal educational field, we address concepts such as democracy, citizenship and the most appropriate teaching-learning methodology for illustrating these concepts and competences, bearing in mind that they should educate citizens with full awareness of their rights and duties
summary:
This study, part of the European Erasmus+ ELEF
 project, investigates the conceptions of secondary education teachers undergoing training to become "Democracy Coaches." The project aims to foster innovative democratic learning environments. Researchers analyzed teachers' understanding of concepts like democracy, citizenship, and effective teaching-learning methodologies to educate citizens about their rights and duties. The findings highlight diverse interpretations of these fundamental concepts among educators, stressing the need for robust training to establish consistent approaches to civic education and democratic participation in schools.

title: The United States after unipolarity: American democracy promotion and the ‘Arab Spring’
abstract: In the aftermath of the 11 September 2001 terrorist attacks the United States increasingly sought to promote democracy in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA). However, although this strategy came to be largely associated with the invasion of Iraq, and the belief that a benign domino effect would spread throughout the region, there was far more nuance to the policy President Obama inherited. President George W. Bush’s democracy promotion legacy is one of institutional construction within the US foreign policy bureaucracy, creating the Middle East Partnership Initiative (MEPI), the Middle East Free Trade Area (MEFTA), and the Broader Middle East and North Africa initiative (BMENA). Furthermore, it was President Bush who codified his democracy promotion strategy in National Security Presidential Directive 58, entitled Institutionalising the Freedom Agenda, and who signed the ADVANCE Democracy Act of 2007 into law.1 By the time that President Bush left office hundreds of millions of dollars had been spent on promoting democracy in the MENA, and the US had declared with the force of law that it would prioritise, along with other foreign policy goals, the promotion of democracy and human rights around the world
publisher: LSE IDEAS, London School of Economics and Political Science
fieldOfStudy: Politics, American Foreign Policy, Democracy Promotion, Middle East, North Africa, Arab Spring
summary: This report examines the evolution of United States democracy promotion in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) following the 9/11 terrorist attacks, particularly under President George W. Bush's administration. It details the institutional construction within US foreign policy, including the creation of initiatives like MEPI, MEFTA, and BMENA, and the codification of strategy through NSPD 58 and the ADVANCE Democracy Act of 2007. The study highlights the substantial financial investment and legal prioritization of democracy and human rights promotion. It also touches upon the American influence during the ‘Arab Spring’ and the calls for freedom rooted in both American ideals and indigenous understandings of citizenship and social justice.

title: Book review: accelerating democracy: transforming governance through technology
abstract: John O. McGinnis demonstrates how new technologies combine to address a problem as old as democracy itself: how to help citizens better evaluate the consequences of their political choices. Ana Polo Alonso thinks we can support or dismiss McGinnis’s proposals, but we cannot deny that the author makes a major effort to bring forth ingenious measures to really ‘accelerate democracy.’ Accelerating Democracy: Transforming Governance through Technology. John O. McGinnis. Princeton University Press. December 2012
publisher: The London School of Economics and Political Science
summary: John O. McGinnis's book, "Accelerating Democracy: Transforming Governance through Technology," addresses the perennial problem of helping citizens make informed political choices. The book proposes innovative measures leveraging current technological breakthroughs to improve governance and citizen engagement. Key methods discussed include the use of predictive markets, aiming to enhance the acquisition of sound and reliable information for political action. While acknowledging potential pitfalls, McGinnis's work is praised for expanding the spectrum of technological possibilities for democratic improvement, offering valuable insights for enhancing policymaking and citizen participation through efficient technology use. This book is relevant for those interested in political science, technology, and governance.

title: The Neoliberal Assault on Australian Universities and the Future of Democracy: The Philosophical Failure of a Nation
abstract:
The transformation of universities from public institutions to transnational business enterprises has met with less resistance in Australia than elsewhere. Yet this transformation undermines the founding principles of Australian democracy. This democracy emerged in opposition to the classical form of free market liberalism
          that the neo-liberals have revived. The logical unfolding of social liberalism in Australia underpinned the development of both the system of wage fixing and the idea of public education as conditions for democracy. The lack of resistance to the destruction of democracy, as it was originally understood in Australia, by successive neoliberal
          governments has been due largely to the decadent state of Australian universities. These had come to be dominated by a crude form of empiricist utilitarianism, making Australia peculiarly vulnerable to the ideologues of global free markets and the power of transnational corporations who have sought to transform language to equate the dominance of all facets of life by markets as a defence of democracy. Only through a recovery of the philosophical tradition upon which Australia was founded and the development of this tradition through process metaphysics, it is argued, can genuine democracy and Australia’s public institutions, be defended
summary: This paper argues that the transformation of Australian universities into transnational business enterprises undermines the nation's democratic principles, a shift that has met with less resistance compared to other countries. It posits that Australia's original democracy emerged in opposition to free-market liberalism, with social liberalism underpinning wage fixing and public education as democratic conditions. The lack of resistance is attributed to the universities' embrace of empiricist utilitarianism, making them susceptible to global free market ideologies. The author advocates for a recovery of Australia's philosophical tradition, developed through process metaphysics, to defend genuine democracy and public institutions.

title: Democracy: History of a Crisis Without End
abstract:
Over the last years it has been increasingly discussed about the crisis of democracy, a process that does not only concern the
new realities, but also and perhaps more surprisingly the Western world. This crisis of the Western world seems to be at the
root of the weakness of the democratic principle and the principles related to it. In particular, the following three seem to be the
events of the new millennium that led to the crisis of democracy, intimately connected to the loss of the cultural supremacy of
the West, the cradle of democracy: the globalization; the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001; the economic crisis that
began in 2008, which further weakened the West to the point of pushing the non-Western countries, all aiming at pursuing a
health unprecedented material, to favor new political solutions than the classical liberal democracy. Accepting democracy as a
concept semantically always open and, therefore, always in crisis, is the challenge awaiting the community of political
scientists
summary: This paper examines the contemporary crisis of democracy, which extends beyond new global realities to surprisingly impact the Western world. The authors argue that this weakening is rooted in the loss of Western cultural supremacy, influenced by three key events of the new millennium: globalization, the September 11, 2001 terrorist attacks, and the 2008 economic crisis. These events pushed non-Western countries towards alternative political solutions beyond classical liberal democracy. The paper concludes that accepting democracy as a semantically open and perpetually 'in crisis' concept is a crucial challenge for political scientists.

title: Iterative Delegations in Liquid Democracy with Restricted Preferences
abstract:
In this paper, we study liquid democracy, a collective decision making
paradigm which lies between direct and representative democracy. One main
feature of liquid democracy is that voters can delegate their votes in a
transitive manner so that: A delegates to B and B delegates to C leads to A
delegates to C. Unfortunately, this process may not converge as there may not
even exist a stable state (also called equilibrium). In this paper, we
investigate the stability of the delegation process in liquid democracy when
voters have restricted types of preference on the agent representing them
(e.g., single-peaked preferences). We show that various natural structures of
preferences guarantee the existence of an equilibrium and we obtain both
tractability and hardness results for the problem of computing several
equilibria with some desirable properties
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Liquid Democracy, Collective Decision Making
summary: This paper investigates the stability of iterative delegation in liquid democracy, a system combining direct and representative democracy. The authors study the process where voters can transitively delegate votes, acknowledging that this may not always converge to a stable state or equilibrium. The research focuses on scenarios where voters have restricted preference types, such as single-peaked preferences, on their representing agents. Key findings indicate that various natural preference structures guarantee the existence of an equilibrium. The paper also presents tractability and hardness results for computing desirable equilibria, contributing to the understanding of collective decision-making, voting systems, and computational social choice.

title: Philanthropy and the Renewal of Democracy: Is it Time to Step Up Our Game?
abstract: When Philanthropy Northwest and the Kettering Foundation published the first edition of this booklet in April 2014, the wounds and diseases afflicting our body politic were already causing concern among growing numbers of citizens, including many philanthropists. Our question about whether we in philanthropy should be stepping up our game in our efforts to strengthen democratic institutions and practices was already being answered in the affirmative by a growing number of philanthropists. That response has intensified as the challenges facing democracy have multiplied in the intervening months. As more of Philanthropy Northwest's members ask how they can contribute to strengthening democracy, we have responded by creating a discussion platform called "Democracy Northwest" and, in cooperation with the Kettering Foundation, revising and updating this monograph.In the Fall 2016 edition of this monograph, Daniel Kemmis explores the sometimes-fraught relationship between philanthropy and democracy. Beginning with a wide-ranging stroll through the shared history of philanthropy and democracy, Kemmis examines the current post-Citizens United landscape and asks whether philanthropy can and should do more to strengthen the infrastructure and practices of democracy.The 2016 edition features new graphics and other updates reflecting changes in philanthropy and democracy since 2014, as well as a new foreword by Remy Trupin, Philanthropy Northwest's Advocacy Catalyst Fellow
summary: This monograph, a collaborative effort by Philanthropy Northwest and the Kettering Foundation, explores the evolving relationship between philanthropy and democracy. The 2016 edition, authored by Daniel Kemmis with a foreword by Remy Trupin, updates the 2014 publication in response to increasing concerns about democratic institutions. It examines philanthropy's role in strengthening democracy's infrastructure and practices, especially in the post-Citizens United era, and asks whether philanthropists should enhance their engagement. The publication aims to provide a platform for discussion on how philanthropy can contribute to democratic renewal.

title: Social democracy is not the ideology we need in an economic downturn: even if the Left can sell social democracy to the UK electorate, it will have a hard time selling it to global markets
abstract: In our continuing series on social democracy, Lord Norton rejects Pete Redford’s idea that social democracy is the best way forward for the Left. But the appeal of social democracy is tarnished for three reasons: it rests on an inaccurate perception of the Conservatives as slavishly devoted to neo-liberalism; it focuses too strongly on the state’s ability to solve people’s problems, and it is wholly inadequate in dealing with globalised markets
publisher: Blog post from London School of Economics & Political Science
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Social Democracy, Neo-liberalism, Political Parties
summary: This analysis critiques social democracy as a viable path for the Left, particularly during economic downturns. It argues that social democracy is flawed due to an inaccurate view of Conservatives' neo-liberalism, an overreliance on state intervention, and its inadequacy in addressing globalized markets. The author contends that the Conservative party's success is partly due to opponents' missteps, and attempts by the Labour party to revert to social democracy are likely to fail on multiple levels, including a misunderstanding of current economic problems and the challenges posed by globalization.

title: Language Access in New York State: A Snapshot From a Community Perspective
abstract: [Excerpt] The state government provides New Yorkers with a multitude of services and benefits necessary for their survival and success: nutritional supports, health benefits, unemployment insurance and driver’s licenses, to name but a few. In order for these services to be equally accessible to all of the diverse residents of the state, it is essential that government agencies be linguistically accessible, providing interpretation and translation services for the over two million individuals in New York State who are limited English proficient (LEP). This report assesses the state of language access in New York, particularly access to state benefits that are critically important to low-income New Yorkers, such as public benefits, unemployment, and police protection. It examines the degree to which government agencies that administer state benefits programs and services are providing LEP New Yorkers with language assistance services required under a patchwork of federal, state and county-level policies
summary: This report assesses the state of language access in New York State for limited English proficient (LEP) individuals. It investigates the linguistic accessibility of government agencies providing critical services like nutritional support, health benefits, unemployment insurance, and driver's licenses. The study examines compliance with federal, state, and county-level language assistance policies, particularly for low-income New Yorkers accessing public benefits, unemployment support, and police protection. Key findings aim to highlight disparities and areas for improvement in ensuring equitable access to essential government services for all residents.

title: Maintaining positive
abstract: Maintaining positive work-force relationships includes in effective labor-management relations and making appropriate responses to current employee issues. Among the major current employee issues are protection from arbitrary dismissal, drug and alcohol abuse, privacy rights and family maters and they impact work. In our paper we discus two problems: first, the meanings of industrial democracy; second, the three principal operational concepts of industrial democracy (1) industrial democracy through collective bargaining, (2) integrative representative industrial democracy, (3) industrial democracy through direct “shop-floor participation”. Also we discus about workers’ ownership of the enterprise and some general landmarks towards industrial democracy.general management, industrial democracy
summary: This paper explores the concept of industrial democracy, emphasizing its role in maintaining positive labor-management relations and addressing contemporary employee issues such as arbitrary dismissal, substance abuse, and privacy. The authors discuss the meanings of industrial democracy and its three principal operational concepts: collective bargaining, integrative representative democracy, and direct "shop-floor participation." Additionally, the paper examines workers' ownership of enterprises and outlines general milestones toward achieving industrial democracy. Keywords include industrial democracy, labor-management relations, collective bargaining, employee participation, and worker ownership.

title: Corruption and Democracy
abstract: What is the impact of democracy on corruption? In most models, analysts assume a negative relationship, with more democracy leading to less corruption. But recent theoretical developments and case evidence support an inverted U relationship between corruption and democracy. By drawing on a panel data set covering a large number of countries between 1996 and 2003, substantial empirical support is found for an inverted U relationship between democracy and corruption. The turning point in corruption occurs rather early in the life of new democracies and at rather low per capita incomes.corruption, electoral democracy, consolidated democracy, rule of law, government effectiveness
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between democracy and corruption, challenging the common assumption of a simple negative correlation. Drawing on recent theoretical developments and empirical evidence, it proposes an inverted U-shaped relationship. The study utilizes a panel data set from 1996 to 2003, covering numerous countries, to provide substantial support for this inverted U hypothesis. Key findings indicate that the turning point for corruption occurs relatively early in the development of new democracies and at lower per capita income levels. Keywords: corruption, electoral democracy, consolidated democracy, rule of law, government effectiveness.

title: Income and democracy:Evidence from system GMM estimates
abstract: Does higher income cause democracy? Accounting for the dynamic nature and highpersistence of income and democracy, we find a statistically significant positive relationbetween income and democracy for a postwar period sample of up to 150 countries. Ourresults are robust across different model specifications and instrument sets.Income, democracy, dynamic panel estimators
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Income, Democracy, Dynamic Panel Estimators
summary: This paper investigates the causal relationship between higher income and democracy, considering the dynamic nature and high persistence of both factors. Utilizing a postwar period sample of up to 150 countries, the authors employ dynamic panel estimators to find a statistically significant positive relation between income and democracy. The robustness of these results is confirmed across various model specifications and instrument sets. Key terms include income, democracy, and dynamic panel estimators, providing valuable insights for political economy and development studies.

title: Income and Democracy
abstract: We revisit one of the central empirical findings of the political economy literature that higher income per capita causes democracy. Existing studies establish a strong cross-country correlation between income and democracy, but do not typically control for factors that simultaneously affect both variables. We show that controlling for such factors by including country fixed effects removes the statistical association between income per capita and various measures of democracy. We also present instrumental-variables using two different strategies. These estimates also show no causal effect of income on democracy. Furthermore, we reconcile the positive cross-country correlation between income and democracy with the absence of a causal effect of income on democracy by showing that the long-run evolution of income and democracy is related to historical factors. Consistent with this, the positive correlation between income and democracy disappears, even without fixed effects, when we control for the historical determinants of economic and political development in a sample of former European colonies.
summary: This paper revisits the empirical finding that higher income per capita causes democracy, a central tenet in political economy. The authors demonstrate that once country-specific factors are controlled for using fixed effects or instrumental variables, the statistical association between income and various measures of democracy disappears. They reconcile the observed positive cross-country correlation with the lack of a causal effect by showing that the long-run evolution of income and democracy is linked to historical determinants. This suggests that historical factors, rather than income, drive parallel economic and political development.

title: Democracy, Income, and Environmental Quality
abstract: This Working Paper considers the role of democracy in environmental quality and the Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC). Some studies in the EKC literature have examined the extent to which democratic nations are more or less apt to have improving environmental conditions, but they have drawn from static measures of a nation’s current regime. In this paper the authors examine panel data from 1960 to 2001 and analyze the extent to which both the current level and the stock of a country’s democracy have significant and independent effects on a nation’s sulfur and carbon dioxide emissions.While they find no evidence for the short-run effect of the current level of democracy, they do find strong evidence that long-term democracy stock helps lower sulfur and carbon dioxide emissions.Environmental Kuznets Curve; political economy of environment; sulfur emissions; carbon dioxide emissions; democracy; democracy stock; democracy and environment
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Environmental Economics, Political Economy of Environment, Democracy, Environmental Kuznets Curve
summary: This working paper investigates the role of democracy in environmental quality within the Environmental Kuznets Curve (EKC) framework.  Challenging static measures, the authors utilize panel data from 1960 to 2001 to analyze the independent effects of both current levels and the long-term stock of democracy on sulfur and carbon dioxide emissions.  Key findings indicate no short-run impact from current democracy levels, but strong evidence suggests that a sustained stock of democracy significantly lowers sulfur and carbon dioxide emissions.  This study contributes to understanding the political economy of the environment, democracy's long-term effects, and pollution reduction.

title: Identity and Democracy: Linking Individual and Social Reasoning
abstract: Following Amartya Sen\u27s approach, John Davis and Solange Regina Marin look at individual and social reasoning when examining the complex relationship between identity and democracy. They characterize democracy as a process of social or public reasoning that combines the individual reasoning of all citizens. Identity is explained in terms of personal identity, social identity, and individual identity. They argue that democracy in combining the individual reasoning of all citizens responds to individuals’ different personal identity concerns and needs, reflects their shared social identity interests and goals, and accords them rights and responsibilities associated with their many different individual identities
summary: John Davis and Solange Regina Marin explore the intricate relationship between identity and democracy, following Amartya Sen's framework. They conceptualize democracy as a process of public reasoning that integrates the individual reasoning of all citizens. Identity is delineated into personal, social, and individual dimensions. The authors contend that democracy, by combining individual reasoning, addresses diverse personal identity concerns, reflects shared social identity interests, and upholds rights and responsibilities associated with various individual identities. This work is crucial for understanding political philosophy, social reasoning, and the multifaceted nature of identity in democratic societies.

title: Challenging Direct Democracy
abstract: I want to argue today that direct democracy is undesirable and unconstitutional. I want to argue to you that the Supreme Court should find that the Michigan Civil Rights Initiative is unconstitutional, and strike it down. So I want to make two points. First, I am going to argue that direct democracy is undesirable. This is a normative argument; it’s not an argument about constitutional doctrine. Second, I want to argue that direct democracy is unconstitutional, and make a series of different arguments as to why
summary: This paper argues that direct democracy is both undesirable and unconstitutional, specifically challenging the Michigan Civil Rights Initiative. The author contends that direct democracy is inconsistent with constitutional structure, leads to faulty lawmaking, and distorts citizens' policy preferences. Furthermore, it is argued that direct democracy violates the Republican Form of Government Clause and that measures disadvantaging minorities through direct democracy should be subject to strict scrutiny under the Equal Protection Clause. The author, drawing on two decades of experience with ballot initiatives in California, advocates for striking down direct democracy measures that circumvent the political process for minorities.

title: Market, Social Cohesion, and Democracy
abstract: This paper offers three guiding principles for a better relationship between the economy and democracy: democracy as the extension of citizenship; democracy as diversity; and democracy as complementary to clear, strong macroeconomic rules. This view, it is argued, implies that economic and social institutions must be subject to democratic political choice. In this context, it analyses the role of both national and international institutions in improving the complementarity of the market, social cohesion and democracy. The central role of economic and social rights serves as the overarching framework for the analysis.citizenship, democracy, social cohesion, market economy, inequality, property rights
summary: This paper proposes three guiding principles for fostering a stronger relationship between the economy and democracy: extending citizenship, embracing diversity, and complementing macroeconomic rules. It argues that economic and social institutions must be subject to democratic choice. The analysis examines how national and international institutions can enhance the compatibility of markets, social cohesion, and democracy, with economic and social rights serving as the central framework. Keywords include citizenship, social cohesion, market economy, inequality, and property rights, crucial for semantic search regarding political economy and societal structures.

title: Democracy and Nobility
abstract: Americans love revolutions. Our national identity began with a revolution, and a revolutionary war that lasted for eight years; and we cheer on other people’s revolutions, as though we find satisfaction in multiplying our own. “I hold that a little rebellion now and then is a good thing & as necessary in the political world as storms in the physical,” wrote Thomas Jefferson. “No country should be long without one.” An excited James Garfield, in his maiden speech in the House of Representatives in 1864, asked whether his colleagues “forget that the Union had its origin in revolution.” Ralph Waldo Emerson thought of revolution as the authentic instinct of humanity. “Wherever a man comes, there comes revolution,” he said in his Harvard Divinity School address of 1838. “The old is for slaves.” [excerpt
publisher: The Cupola: Scholarship at Gettysburg College
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political History, Military History, United States History
summary: This text explores the American perception of revolutions, citing historical figures like Thomas Jefferson, James Garfield, and Ralph Waldo Emerson, who viewed rebellion as an intrinsic part of national identity and political evolution.
