It then analyzes whether the American Civil War was truly a revolution in warfare, challenging the common belief that modernized weapons or logistical innovations like railroads and the telegraph were unique to the conflict. The author argues that Civil War weapons were more akin to Napoleonic-era warfare and that military applications of railroads and telegraphs predated the Civil War, making it less revolutionary than often portrayed. This analysis recontextualizes the Civil War's military significance.

title: The performance of global democracy : parody and/as the political
abstract:
The article develops a critical analysis of the debate on global democracy. Departing from common post-structural IR critiques of global democracy as (merely) a metaphor of

escape that entrenches many of the sovereign logics it claims to contest, we explore what it would mean to engage the discourse of global democracy as an ongoing performative practice. After briefly outlining the relative positions of liberal reformist and cosmopolitan democrats – we argue that more attention can/should be paid to the ontopolitical foundations of global democracy. Drawing from William Connolly and Judith Butler, it is argued that fundamental (democratic) limits of the discourse are

overlooked/re-produced, and even in the more ambitious cosmopolitan positions. Ontopolitical closures in relation to a problematic global scale and the universal assumption of individual agency/rights highlight the necessity of democratising ‘actually existing’

discourses of global democracy. We explore these ideas via a discussion of the cultural governance of global trade and resistance to it, especially via the activities of a UK based anarchist group called The Space Hijackers. By deploying parody the Space Hijackers can

contribute to the debate on global democracy by provoking reflection upon fundamental assumptions about globalisation and ethics in everyday situations. They therefore problematise and subvert the problematic subjectivity of the ‘global-individual’ in a

manner that might (but does not necessarily) allow for the imagination of alternative possibilities. The importance of this argument is that it resists the tendency of poststructural scepticism with regard to ethical discourses of global democracy, while retaining what is so promising: a turn towards singularity and imagination. Parody does

not solve all problems, what could? But it does offer a modality within which subjects can imagine and act creatively with regards to the everyday closures of global democrac
publisher: University of Warwick. Centre for the Study of Globalisation and Regionalisation
summary: This article critically analyzes the global democracy debate, moving beyond post-structural critiques to examine it as a performative practice. Drawing on William Connolly and Judith Butler, it argues that fundamental democratic limits, such as problematic global scale and universal individual agency, are often overlooked. The authors explore these ideas through the cultural governance of global trade and resistance, specifically highlighting the Space Hijackers' use of parody to provoke reflection on globalization and ethics. This approach resists poststructural skepticism by embracing singularity and imagination, offering a creative modality for addressing the everyday closures of global democracy. Keywords: global democracy, performative practice, ontopolitical foundations, cultural governance, parody, Space Hijackers, poststructuralism.

title: Interstate competition and political stability
abstract:
Previous theories of globalization have examined factor mobility’s effect on the political conflict

between social classes. But factor mobility also increases competition between state rulers in provid-

ing services for citizens. I ask how this interstate competition affects the process of political change.

In a simple model, interstate competition substitutes for democracy, by forcing rulers to invest in pub-

lic goods so as to avoid capital and labor leaving the country. As a result, citizens are less willing to

struggle for democracy, and rulers are less willing to oppose it, when interstate competition is strong.

Therefore, there is less conflict over the level of democracy. The theory is tested on a post-war panel

of countries, using neighboring countries’ financial openness as a proxy for factor mobility. As the

theory predicts, states experience fewer changes in their level of democracy when their neighbors are

financially open
publisher: Department of Economics, University of Warwick
summary: This paper examines how interstate competition, driven by factor mobility, influences political change and the stability of democracy. The author proposes a model where competition among state rulers to provide services, to prevent capital and labor flight, acts as a substitute for democracy. This reduces citizens' motivation to strive for democracy and rulers' opposition to it, thus leading to less conflict over democratic transitions. Empirical testing using a post-war panel of countries and neighboring countries' financial openness as a proxy for factor mobility supports the theory, showing fewer changes in democracy levels when neighbors are financially open.

title: The Czech Republicans 1990-8: A populist outsider in a consolidating democracy
abstract: The chapter examines the Czech Repulicans (the SPR-RSČ) , a radical right-wing party represented in the Czech parliament between 1992 and 1998, as a case study of party-based oppositional outsider populism in a consolidating democracy. It traces the origins and development of the party, then examines the populist nature of the party's radical right appeals in the 1990s and the implicit understanding of democracy these contained. It concludes by evaluating the Republicans’ impact on the development of Czech democracy and assessing the extent to which it has left a legacy in contemporary Czech politics

title: History education and 'Asian' values for an 'Asian' democracy: the case of Singapore
abstract: Where some of the papers in this volume deal with nation building in the democratising former East European states in the wider ideological context of liberal democratic thought, this paper aims to present a view of values and democracy from an alternative, ‘Asian’ perspective. South East Asian nations, such as Singapore, have attempted to articulate and practise forms of ‘Asian’ democracy as a response to, and in rejection of, Western liberal democratic models. In these countries, there is not so much a programme of reform and liberalization, as an attempt to evolve a form of democracy suited to an Asian society. To this end, efforts have been made by political leaders to articulate what ‘Asian’ values are, and some countries have also promoted sets of values that are considered to be congruent with their form of ‘Asian’ democracy. Singapore is an example of how a government has set about developing a form of ‘Asian’ democracy. By examining the history texts used in Singapore schools, and comparing the different contexts in which European and ‘Asian’ values are embedded and used, the paper shows that there is indeed a distinctive form of values and democracy that is taught. But, while this is referred to as ‘Asian’, there is in fact a lacuna in terms of the wider values framework and context, and children are in effect being socialised into accepting a rather passive conception of citizenship and a notion of democracy that are arguably distinctive to Singapore. What that Asia stands for is far too diverse, and perhaps there is also, on the part of Singapore and its political leaders, an inclination to make ‘Asian’ values in their own image, as it were
summary: This paper examines the concept of "Asian" democracy, contrasting it with Western liberal democratic models, and focuses on Singapore's efforts to articulate and practice its own form. By analyzing history texts used in Singaporean schools, the study reveals a distinct set of values and a particular conception of democracy being taught. While presented as broadly "Asian," the paper argues there's a lack of a wider values framework, leading to children being socialized into a passive view of citizenship and a democracy arguably unique to Singapore, rather than representative of a diverse Asia. Keywords: Asian democracy, Singapore, values, history education, citizenship.

title: Is The Daily Show Bad for Democracy? An Analysis of Cynicism and its Significance
abstract: In recent years, satirical news programs like The Daily Show with Jon Stewart have emerged as an important development in contemporary American society, culture, and politics. Critics have argued that The Daily Show has a negative impact on the political attitudes of American citizens by making them cynical about government and the political process as a whole. As a result of these attitudes, they argue, citizens are less apt to participate in politics and, in turn, this behavior is detrimental to American democracy. The purpose of this research project is to explore the debate over whether or not The Daily Show is indeed bad for democracy. Its objectives are not simply to develop my own answer to this question, but more importantly to critically unpack the question itself in order to analyze the complex relationships between The Daily Show, cynicism, and democracy. To do so, I review, analyze, and assess various and competing definitions of the concepts “cynicism” and “democracy,” and then use close readings of scholarship from political science, communication, and cultural studies to construct a “debate” on the question of the show’s significance for contemporary American democracy
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Science, Communication, Cultural Studies
summary: This research project investigates the societal impact of satirical news programs, specifically 'The Daily Show with Jon Stewart', on American democracy. It addresses the debate regarding whether such shows foster political cynicism, leading to decreased civic participation, which critics argue is detrimental to democracy. The study critically unpacks the complex relationships between 'The Daily Show', cynicism, and democracy by reviewing and analyzing various definitions of these concepts. It employs close readings of scholarship from political science, communication, and cultural studies to construct a comprehensive debate on the show's significance for contemporary American democracy. Keywords: political cynicism, media influence, civic participation, American politics, satirical news.

title: Democracy promotion and civil society
abstract: The annual Global Civil Society Yearbooks provide an indispensable guide to global civil society or civic participation and action around the world. This year, the Yearbook will focus on communicative power and democracy, investigating different forms of democracy promotion and communication with a view to understanding the relationship between communication, democracy and media. The Global Civil Society Yearbook remains the standard work on all aspects of contemporary global civil society for activists, practitioners, students and academics alike. It is essential reading for anyone seeking a deeper understanding of the key actors, forms and manifestations of global civil society around the world today
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Civil Society, Democracy Promotion, Communication
summary: This book section, part of the Global Civil Society Yearbook 2007/8, focuses on civil society strengthening programs as a key strand of democracy promotion. The yearbook itself serves as a comprehensive guide to global civil society and civic participation, with this edition investigating the relationship between communication, democracy, and media, examining various forms of democracy promotion and communication. It aims to provide activists, practitioners, students, and academics with a deeper understanding of key actors, forms, and manifestations of global civil society, making it essential reading for those interested in global civic action and democratic development.

title: Is the Internet a Viable Threat to Representative Democracy?
abstract: The Internet, despite its relatively recent advent, is critical to millions of Americans’ way of life. Although the Internet arguably opens new opportunities for citizens to become more directly involved in their government, some scholars fear this direct involvement poses a risk to one of the Constitution’s most precious ideals: representative democracy. This iBrief explores whether the constitutional notion of representation is vulnerable to the Internet’s capacity to open new vistas for a more direct democracy by analyzing statistics and theories about why voters in the United States do or do not vote and by examining the inherent qualities of the Internet itself. This iBrief concludes that the Constitution will adapt to the Internet and the Internet to the Constitution, such that even if there are advances in direct democracy, representative democracy will not be unduly threatened
summary: This iBrief explores whether the Internet poses a viable threat to representative democracy, a foundational ideal of the US Constitution. It analyzes statistics and theories regarding voter participation in the United States and examines the inherent qualities of the Internet itself. The study concludes that while the Internet may foster advances in direct democracy, the Constitution is adaptable, and representative democracy will not be unduly threatened. Key areas for semantic search include: Internet, representative democracy, direct democracy, US Constitution, voter behavior, political systems, technology and governance.

title: Joblessness and Perceptions about the Effectiveness of Democracy
abstract: Using micro data on more than 130,000 individuals from 69 countries, we analyze the extent to which joblessness of the individuals and the prevailing unemployment rate in the country impact perceptions of the effectiveness of democracy. We find that personal joblessness experience translates into negative opinions about the effectiveness of democracy and it increases the desire for a rouge leader. Evidence from people who live in European countries suggests that being jobless for more than a year is the source of discontent. We also find that well-educated and wealthier individuals are less likely to indicate that democracies are ineffective, regardless of joblessness. People's beliefs about the effectiveness of democracy as system of governance are also shaped by the unemployment rate in countries with low levels of democracy. The results suggest that periods of high unemployment and joblessness could hinder the development of democracy or threaten its existence.unemployment duration, democracy, education, development, World Values Survey
fieldOfStudy: Politics, unemployment duration, democracy, education, development, World Values Survey
summary: This study analyzes the impact of individual joblessness and national unemployment rates on perceptions of democracy's effectiveness, using micro-data from 130,000 individuals across 69 countries. It finds that personal joblessness negatively impacts democratic perceptions and increases the desire for an authoritarian leader, particularly after a year of unemployment in European countries. Well-educated and wealthier individuals are less likely to view democracies as ineffective. High unemployment also shapes beliefs about democracy in countries with low democratic levels, suggesting that economic hardship could threaten democratic development and existence. Keywords: unemployment, democracy, education, political development.

title: Is There a Democracy–Civil Society Paradox in Global Environmental Governance?
abstract: Civil society is commonly assumed to have a positive effect on international cooperation. This paper sheds light on one important facet of this assumption: we examine the impact of environmental non-governmental organizations (ENGOs) on ratification behavior of countries vis-à-vis international environmental agreements (IEAs). The main argument of the paper focuses on a “democracy-civil society paradox”: although ENGOs have a positive effect on ratification of IEAs on average, this effect decreases with increasing levels of democracy. This argument is counter-intuitive and appears paradoxical because democracy is generally associated both with a more active civil society and more international cooperation. The reasons for this hypothesized effect pertain to public demand for environmental public goods provision, government incentives, and problems of collective action among ENGOs. To test the net effect of ENGOs on countries' ratification behavior, the paper uses a new dataset on ENGOs in the time-period 1973–2006. The results offer strong support for the presumed democracy–civil society paradox. </jats:p
summary:
This paper investigates the impact of environmental non-governmental organizations (ENGOs) on countries' ratification of international environmental agreements (IEAs). It posits a "democracy-civil society paradox," arguing that while ENGOs generally foster IEA ratification, this effect diminishes as democratic levels increase. This counter-intuitive hypothesis is attributed to public demand for environmental public goods, government incentives, and collective action challenges among ENGOs. Utilizing a new dataset spanning 1973





2006, the study provides strong empirical support for this paradox. Key findings relate to international cooperation, democracy, civil society, and environmental governance.

title: Democracy and prosperity in two decades of transition
abstract: This paper revisits the relation between democracy, liberalization, and prosperity in transition countries, using a panel of 25 countries over 19 years. Earlier investigations found political and economic liberalization to be positively correlated whereas the relation between political liberalization and prosperity remained unclear. In this paper, a hump-shaped relationship between political liberalization and growth is found, such that a rise in democracy levels promotes growth only under initially low democracy levels. Furthermore, economic and political liberalization turn out to be positively related, but with surprisingly small coefficients. --Transition Economics,Public Choice,Democracy,Growth
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Transition Economics, Public Choice, Democracy, Growth
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between democracy, liberalization, and prosperity in 25 transition countries over 19 years. Utilizing panel data, the study identifies a hump-shaped relationship between political liberalization and economic growth, where increased democracy promotes growth only at initially low democracy levels. It also finds a positive, but surprisingly weak, correlation between economic and political liberalization. This research contributes to understanding the dynamics of political and economic transitions and their impact on prosperity, providing insights for policymakers and researchers interested in political economy and development.

title: The Impact of Referendums on the Centralisation of Public Goods Provision: A Political Economy Approach
abstract: The paper compares decision-making on the centralisation of public goods provision in the presence of regional externalities under representative and direct democratic institutions. A model with two regions, two public goods and regional spillovers is developed in which uncertainty over the true preferences of candidates makes strategic delegation impossible. Instead, it is shown that the existence of rent extraction by delegates alone suffices to make cooperative centralisation more likely through representative democracy. In the non-cooperative case, the more extensive possibilities for institutional design under representative democracy increase the likelihood of centralisation. Direct democracy may thus be interpreted as a federalism-preserving institution.centralisation, direct democracy, representative democracy, public good provision
summary: This paper investigates decision-making regarding the centralisation of public goods provision amidst regional externalities under representative and direct democratic institutions. Utilizing a two-region, two-public-goods model with spillovers, it demonstrates that rent extraction by delegates in a representative democracy enhances cooperative centralisation. In non-cooperative scenarios, the institutional design flexibility of representative democracy also increases centralisation likelihood. The study concludes that direct democracy acts as a federalism-preserving institution. Keywords: centralisation, direct democracy, representative democracy, public good provision.

title: 91st Commencement Address:  Not for Profit: Liberal Education and Democratic Citizenship
abstract: Martha Nussbaum speaks to the graduates about the role of liberal education in producing democratic citizens, the sort of citizen who can keep democracy alive and realize its promise and asks  what does a liberal education that contains a substantial component from the humanities and the arts contribute to the health of democracy
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Liberal Education, Democratic Citizenship, Humanities, Arts
summary: Martha Nussbaum's commencement address at Connecticut College examines the critical role of liberal education, particularly the humanities and arts, in fostering democratic citizenship. She argues that this form of education is essential for sustaining a healthy democracy and realizing its full potential, countering the trend of education focused solely on profitability. Nussbaum emphasizes that a liberal education cultivates rational and imaginative powers, combats flaws like parochialism and selfishness, and promotes a world culture based on equality, sympathy, and reasoned debate. The address serves as a call to action for graduates to advocate for and preserve the value of humanities in higher education.

title: Health and democracy
summary: This article explores the complex relationship between democratic institutions and human well-being, specifically focusing on health outcomes. Despite the global spread of democracy, the evidence for its positive impact on prosperity and specific policy areas remains debated and not consistently robust. The authors investigate how democratic structures might influence health indicators, acknowledging the challenges in establishing clear causal links. This research contributes to the ongoing discussion in political economy and development studies regarding the effectiveness of democratic governance in improving population health and overall human welfare.

title: A Theory of Civil Conflict and Democracy in Unequal Societies
abstract: This paper examines the endogenous choice between democracy and conflict in a scenario with different social classes in terms of income inequality and with parties representing each of the two social classes. We consider how the change in economic inequality between the poor and rich people affects the sustainability of democracy against conflict and how it impacts the equilibrium levels of tax rate and public expenditure under democracy. We show that the increase in economic inequality destabilizes of democracy since the poor hardly has the incentive to sustain the democracy Further the increase is positively associated with the equilibrium levels of both the tax rate and public expenditure. Therefore, we successfully provide theoretic justification for the fact that sufficiently large economic inequality decreases the possibility of a self-enforcing democracy.
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Civil Conflict, Democracy, Economic Inequality
summary: This paper explores the endogenous choice between democracy and conflict, focusing on societies with income inequality and distinct social classes represented by political parties. The study investigates how changes in economic inequality between the rich and poor impact democracy's sustainability and influence equilibrium tax rates and public expenditure under democratic rule. Findings indicate that increased economic inequality destabilizes democracy by reducing incentives for the poor to support it, and is positively correlated with higher tax rates and public spending. The research provides theoretical justification that substantial economic inequality diminishes the possibility of a self-enforcing democracy.

title: Instability from trade and democracy: the long-run effect of aid
abstract: Is there an effect of aid on democracy conditional on instability from trade? This paper reinvestigates the debated effect of aid on democracy with a new specification. We take advantage of previous empirical findings explaining the role of aid in mitigating the adverse effects of external shocks, and argue that in the long term, aggregate aid flows can potentially dampen the effects of terms-of-trade instability on the quality of democracy. An empirical investigation with data from 70 developing countries (28 of them African countries) over the period 1980-2003 (pooled in two twelve-years periods) provides supportive results. Moreover, the data suggest that terms-of- trade instability affects democracy through income instability. These results are robust to alternative specifications and to the use of different measures of aid intensity and democracy
summary: This paper investigates the long-term effect of aggregate aid flows on democracy, particularly how they may mitigate the adverse effects of terms-of-trade instability. Reinvestigating the debated relationship between aid and democracy with a new specification, the study leverages previous findings on aid's role in buffering external shocks. An empirical analysis using data from 70 developing countries, including 28 African nations, over 1980-2003 (pooled into two twelve-year periods) supports the hypothesis. The findings also suggest that terms-of-trade instability influences democracy through income instability, with results robust across different specifications and measures of aid and democracy.

title: Information, Polarization and Delegation in Democracy
abstract: This paper investigates the merits of different democratic institutions when politics is uni-dimensional, there is uncertainty both about the preferences of the future electorate and the future polarization of political parties, and politicians have better information about the state of the world than voters. Three types of institutions are compared: direct democracy, representative democracy, where politicians are accountable and independent agencies, where they are not. Low uncertainty about the state of the world and the future electorate’s preferences and high expected polarization make direct democracy optimal, while the opposite configuration makes representative democracy optimal. Independent agencies are optimal for intermediate values.accountability, redistribution, constitutional design, voting, information, direct democracy
summary: This paper investigates the merits of direct democracy, representative democracy, and independent agencies in a uni-dimensional political landscape with uncertainty about the electorate's future preferences and party polarization. The study also considers that politicians possess superior information compared to voters. The findings indicate that direct democracy is optimal under low uncertainty and high expected polarization, whereas representative democracy is optimal in the opposite configuration. Independent agencies are found to be optimal for intermediate values of these factors, highlighting the roles of accountability, information, and constitutional design.

title: Democracy and Evaluation
summary: This paper examines the political dimensions of educational program evaluation, arguing that evaluation is a significant form of political action that raises fundamental issues. The author, an independent evaluator of British educational programs, reflects on a decade of experience and the persistent dilemmas (technical, ethical, and political) in the field. The presentation, titled 'Democracy and Evaluation,' aims to exchange views with Canadian educators on how to ensure the survival of evaluation as a defensible social role amidst its growing political implications and societal impact. Key concepts include democratic theory, educational policy, and social science knowledge in policy decisions.

title: Democracy and Oversight
summary: This working paper, titled "Democracy and Oversight" by Riccardo Pelizzo and Rick Stapenhurst, explores the relationship between democratic governance and oversight mechanisms. The authors likely investigate how various democratic systems implement and maintain effective oversight to ensure accountability and transparency. The study, published in 2006, contributes to the discourse on political science, democratic institutions, and governance, offering insights into the functions and challenges of oversight in different national contexts. This research is relevant for understanding democratic resilience and good governance practices globally.

title: Rottweilers savage democracy
summary: This text critiques the aggressive interviewing style prevalent in mass media, exemplified by "rottweiler" interviewers, and its detrimental impact on democratic discourse. It argues that while such approaches are often applauded for challenging politicians, they foster a "fever of negativity" and an "emotional deficit" rather than informed civic engagement. The author advocates for a return to a more respectful and intellectually curious interviewing style, where journalists approach politicians as equals, promoting constructive engagement and emotionally complex contributions to political culture, particularly in a post-war context of national self-examination.

title: Local values in local political culture and democracy; A review of hermeneutics among local elites
abstract:
The reforms provided space for local elites, both traditionally based (Bangsawan) and political elites (Bureaucrats-Politicians) to contest in the arena of local democracy. It is in this arena that the value of the political culture of local elites is tested whether it can strengthen 

democracy or on the contrary weaken democracy in the midst of the process towards its death.(Ziblatt, 2019) where democracy, which actually places the people as the main focal point, becomes "blunted" by political oligarchy and personal elite domination (Fatah & Deni, 2019).(Fatah & Deni, 2019). Using Gadamer's Phenomenological and Hermeneutic Methods, this research analyses the actions of local elites in interpreting the local values of Jou Se Ngofa Ngare in the 2020 Ternate City Regional Election Arena. This research aims to find the meaning of Jou Se Ngofa Ngare local values in strengthening the cultural values of local politics and democracy. The results of the study revealed that [1] The meaning of local values in local 

political culture and democratic values is interpreted by local elites through the process of history, pre-understanding (prejudice), tradition and value authority of leaders (Sultan / Kolano) and cultural symbols [2] The stronger the meaning and application of local values, the stronger the meaning and application of the relationship between leaders (Jou) and the people (Ngofa Ngare) in strengthening local political culture and democratic valu
summary: This research examines how local elites interpret the local values of Jou Se Ngofa Ngare within the 2020 Ternate City Regional Election, aiming to understand their role in strengthening local political culture and democracy. Using Gadamer's Phenomenological and Hermeneutic Methods, the study reveals that local values are interpreted through historical processes, pre-understanding, tradition, and the authority of leaders (Sultan/Kolano) and cultural symbols. A key finding is that the stronger the meaning and application of these local values, the more robust the relationship between leaders (Jou) and the people (Ngofa Ngare) in reinforcing local political culture and democratic values. This process challenges political oligarchy and elite domination.

title: Why is Economic Policy Different in New Democracies? Affecting Attitudes About Democracy
abstract: When democracy is new, it is often fragile and not fully consolidated. We investigate how the danger of a collapse of democracy may affect fiscal policy in new democracies in comparison to countries where democracy is older and often more established. We argue that the attitude of the citizenry towards democracy is important in preventing democratic collapse, and expenditures may therefore be used to convince them that "democracy works". We present a model focusing on the inference problem that citizens solve in forming their beliefs about the efficacy of democracy. Our approach differs from much of the literature that concentrates on policy directed towards anti-democratic elites, but our model can encompass that view and allows comparison of different apporoaches. We argue that the implications of the model are broadly consistent with the empirical patterns generally observed, including the existence of political budget cycles in new democracies not observed in established democracies.
summary: This paper investigates how the threat of democratic collapse impacts fiscal policy in new democracies, contrasting them with established democracies. The authors propose a model where citizens' beliefs about democracy's efficacy are crucial in preventing collapse, suggesting that expenditures can be used to demonstrate that "democracy works." This approach focuses on citizen inference rather than policies targeting anti-democratic elites. The model's implications, including the presence of political budget cycles in new democracies but not in older ones, are consistent with observed empirical patterns. Key concepts include new democracies, democratic fragility, fiscal policy, citizen attitudes, and political budget cycles.

title: Democracy and Feminism
abstract: Although feminist legal theory has had an important impact on most areas of legal doctrine and theory over the last two decades, its contribution to the debate over constitutional interpretation has been comparatively small. In this Article, Professor Higgins explores reasons for the limited dialogue between mainstream constitutional theory and feminist theory concerning questions of democracy, constitutionalism, and judicial review. She argues that mainstream constitutional theory tends to take for granted the capacity of the individual to make choices, leaving the social construction of those choices largely unexamined. In contrast, feminist legal theory\u27s emphasis on the importance of constraints on women\u27s choices has led to a neglect of questions of citizenship and sovereignty within a democratic system. By comparing mainstream constitutional theory and feminist theory, Professor Higgins highlights the existing limitations of both. She argues both that mainstream constitutional theory must take into account feminist arguments concerning constraints on individual choice and that feminist theory must take seriously the mainstream debate over democratic legitimacy. Integrating these distinct concerns, she suggests a framework for constitutional interpretation that reflects a feminist conception of citizenship under conditions of inequality
publisher: FLASH: The Fordham Law Archive of Scholarship and History
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Constitutional Law, Jurisprudence, Legal History
summary: This article examines the limited engagement between feminist legal theory and mainstream constitutional theory regarding constitutional interpretation, democracy, and judicial review. Professor Higgins argues that mainstream theory overlooks the social construction of choices, while feminist theory's focus on constraints on women's choices neglects questions of citizenship and sovereignty. The paper proposes a framework for constitutional interpretation that integrates feminist arguments concerning individual choice constraints with the mainstream debate on democratic legitimacy, aiming to reflect a feminist conception of citizenship under inequality. This framework suggests a role for judicial review in promoting equality.

title: Trade-Union Democracy
summary: This paper examines whether trade-union governance effectively reconciles the need for authority and discipline with individual worker freedom, aligning with democratic principles. It acknowledges that while abuses, such as the extensive power of leaders like John L. Lewis or provisions allowing presidents to annul union constitutions, exist within labor unions, these issues are often a consequence of capable younger individuals not engaging in union governance. The author argues that restrictive legislation would stifle unions' autonomous nature; instead, the solution lies in educating and galvanizing union constituencies to improve internal procedures, ensuring proper judicial machinery and regular elections.

title: Subaltern imaginaries of localism: constructions of place, space and democracy in community-led housing organisations.
abstract: The localism strategies of the UK government provide a suite of ‘rights’ for community organisations that licence place-based political imaginaries with the intent to construct the community as a proxy for a smaller state. Conflating place with participation and promising to devolve power, localism authorises a performative enactment of democracy, citizenship and the ‘public’ through the lived experience of space. In constituting the local as a metaphor for democracy and empowerment, however, community localism foregrounds the pivotal role played by place and scale in cementing social differentiation and in naturalising hierarchical power relations. This paper explores the subaltern strategies of localism that may emerge when the rights of localism are exercised by residents’ organisations in marginalised communities of social housing. Drawing on research with community-led housing organisations it demonstrates how the spatial imaginations and spatial practices of localism can be implemented to assert new claims on democracy and citizenship. In particular it identifies four spatial practices – the extension of domestic space, the invocation of locality, the construction of domestic scale, and the scalar reimagining of democracy – that subvert the reordering of political space that is localism’s regulatory intent
summary: This paper analyzes the UK government's localism strategies, which aim to construct community as a proxy for a smaller state through devolved power and performative democracy. It explores how these strategies, despite intending to reorder political space, can be subverted by residents' organizations in marginalized social housing communities. Drawing on research with community-led housing, the paper identifies four spatial practices—extension of domestic space, invocation of locality, construction of domestic scale, and scalar reimagining of democracy—that assert new claims on democracy and citizenship, challenging the regulatory intent of localism. Key themes include localism, community organizations, spatial practices, democracy, and social housing.

title: Dignity, Human Rights, and Democracy
abstract: In order to analyze what can plausibly be said about the relationship between dignity, human rights, and democracy, I will propose a basic assumption about human dignity (I) and then formulate five theses concerning the justification of democracy (II) which will allow me to conclude (III) that only when human rights are constitutionally established and effectively implemented democracy can be theoretically and practically justified as a political means to guarantee human dignity.human dignity, justifications of democracy, human rights
summary: This paper analyzes the relationship between human dignity, human rights, and democracy. It proposes a basic assumption about human dignity, defining it as an ascriptive, positive moral value inherent in living human beings. The author then formulates five theses concerning the justification of democracy, concluding that democracy can only be theoretically and practically justified as a political means to guarantee human dignity when human rights are constitutionally established and effectively implemented. This work emphasizes the intrinsic link between human rights, constitutionalism, and the legitimate function of democratic systems.

title: Information, Polarization and Delegation in Democracy.
abstract: This paper investigates the merits of different democratic institutions when politics is uni-dimensional, there is uncertainty both about the preferences of the future electorate and the future polarization of political parties, and politicians have better information about the state of the world than voters. Three types of institutions are compared: direct democracy, representative democracy where politicians are accountable, and independent agencies where they are not. Low uncertainty about the state of the world and the future electorate’s preferences and high expected polarization make direct democracy optimal, while the opposite configuration makes representative democracy optimal. Independent agencies are optimal for intermediate values.accountability; redistribution; constitutional design; voting; information; direct democracy
summary: This paper examines the optimal design of democratic institutions, considering uni-dimensional politics, uncertainty about future electorates and party polarization, and information asymmetry between politicians and voters. It compares direct democracy, representative democracy with accountable politicians, and independent agencies without accountability. Findings indicate that direct democracy is optimal under low uncertainty about the state and electorate preferences and high expected polarization. Conversely, representative democracy is preferred with high uncertainty and low polarization. Independent agencies are optimal for intermediate conditions. Key concepts include accountability, redistribution, constitutional design, voting, and information in democratic systems.

title: Democracy and Dispute Resolution: The Problem of Arbitration
abstract: This article seeks to bring the submerged issue of arbitration\u27s relationship to democracy to the surface of the mandatory arbitration debate. Its goal is relatively modest: To recognize and articulate the relationship between democracy and arbitration as an issue worth considering, to analyze the democratic character of arbitration and to suggest some implications of this assessment
summary: This article explores the underexamined relationship between arbitration and democracy, aiming to articulate it as a significant issue within the mandatory arbitration debate. It analyzes the democratic characteristics of arbitration and discusses the implications of this assessment. The author suggests that arbitration, especially under the Federal Arbitration Act, needs to be considered from doctrinal, historical, empirical, and practical perspectives. The research questions how historical understanding, empirical findings on public expectations, and comparative analysis can inform the integration of dispute resolution into legal systems and its export to emerging democracies, highlighting the need to reconsider the overlooked connection between democracy and dispute resolution.

title: Citizenship, democracy and social justice: A conversation with Maria Olson
abstract: Maria Olson is a researcher and lecturer in Education at Stockholm University and the University of Skövde, Sweden. Her areas of interest include democracy and citizenship in relation to education. Her major fields are educational theory and educational philosophy. Her current publications include most recently a series of papers that develop themes of citizenship, democracy and social justice, including: “Citizenship Education without Citizenship? The Migrant in EU Policy on Participatory Citizenship – Toward the Margin through ‘Strangification,’” in R. Hedke and T. Zimenkova (eds.), Education for Civic and Political Participation: A Critical Approach (pp. 155–170). London: Routledge, 2012; “Citizenship ‘in Between’: The Local and the Global Scope of European Citizenship in Swedish Educational Policy,” in S. Goncales and M. A. Carpenter (eds.), Intercultural Policies and Education (pp. 193–203). New York: Peter Lang, 2012; “The European ‘We’: From Citizenship Policy to the Role of Education,” Studies in Philosophy and Education 31(1), 77–89, 2012; “Opening Discourses of Citizenship Education: Theorizing with Foucault” (with Nicoll, K., Fejes, A., Dahlstedt, M. & Biesta, G. J. J.), Journal of Education Policy, 2013 (forthcoming); “Democracy Lessons in Market-oriented Schools: The Case of Swedish Upper Secondary Education,” Education, Citizenship and Social Justice, online first, Doi: 10.1177/17461979134836842013 (with Lundahl, Lisbeth), 2013; “What Counts as Young People’s Civic Engagement in Times of Accountability? On the Importance of Maintaining Openness about Young People’s Civic Engagement in Education,” in M. Olson (ed.), Theme: Citizenship Education under Liberal Democracy. Utbildning & Demokrati [Education & Democracy] 21(1), 29–55, 2012
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Educational Theory, Educational Philosophy, Social Justice
summary: This document presents an overview of Maria Olson's research, focusing on themes of democracy, citizenship, and social justice within education. A lecturer at Stockholm University and the University of Skövde, Olson's work critically examines these concepts, particularly in relation to EU policy, Swedish educational policy, and market-oriented schools. Her publications explore topics such as migrant participatory citizenship, European citizenship, and the role of education in fostering civic engagement. Olson's research trajectory emphasizes aligning philosophical thinking with contemporary global social, political, and cultural changes, drawing on post-structural thinkers to analyze collective processes of subjectification and other educational outcomes.

title: Democracy, Pluralization and Voice
abstract: This article explores different theoretical and political dimensions of voice in democratic theory. Drawing on recent developments in political theory, ranging from James Bohman?s work on the movement from demos to demoi in transnational politics, to William Connolly?s writings on pluralization, it develops a critical account of the emphasis within conventional pluralism on the representation of extant identities. Instead, it foregrounds the need to engage with emerging identities, demands, and claims that fall outside the parameters of dominant discursive orders. Building on the works of Ranciere and Cavell, it highlights the importance of an analytical engagement with the emergence and articulation of new struggles and voices -the processes through which inchoate demands are given political expression- so as to counter the ongoing possibilities of domination, understood here as a ?deprivation of voice.? The article develops an account of the centrality of the category of responsiveness to such claims and demands for democratic theory, especially in relation to a range of democratic struggles in our contemporary world. In so doing, it contributes to a growing body of work that questions the taken for granted character and status of the institutional forms of liberal democracy
summary: This article delves into the theoretical and political dimensions of 'voice' within democratic theory, challenging conventional pluralism's focus on representing existing identities. Drawing on the works of James Bohman, William Connolly, Rancière, and Cavell, it advocates for engaging with emerging identities and demands that fall outside dominant discursive orders. The study emphasizes the analytical importance of new struggles and voices, providing political expression to inchoate demands to counteract 'deprivation of voice.' It highlights the centrality of responsiveness in democratic theory, contributing to a critique of liberal democracy's institutional forms. Keywords include pluralism, demoi, Connolly, Rancière, responsiveness, and deprivation of voice.

title: Ronald Dworkin’s Justice for Hedgehogs and Partnership Conception of Democracy (With a Comment to Jeremy Waldron’s \u27A Majority in the Lifeboat\u27)
abstract: In this article the author focuses mainly in the last part of Ronald Dworkin´s Justice for Hedgehogs and in his argument for a partnership conception of democracy. For that purpose, first, he recalls some of the main features that Dworkin had advanced in previous but intrinsically related works, about political morality, equality and democracy; second, he reassess the arguments for a partnership conception of democracy; third, he reconsiders the resistance produced by Jeremy Waldron in his “A Majority in the Lifeboat” and the response provided by Dworkin, but since it may appear insufficient, he intends to present an alternative—or complementary—riposte in order to meet Waldron’s challenge; and, finally, he insists in the importance of taking Ronald Dworkin seriously
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Constitutional Law, Jurisprudence, Public Law and Legal Theory
summary: This article analyzes Ronald Dworkin's argument for a partnership conception of democracy, primarily drawing from his work "Justice for Hedgehogs." It begins by recalling Dworkin's key ideas on political morality, equality, and democracy from earlier works. The author then re-evaluates the arguments supporting a partnership democracy and addresses Jeremy Waldron's critique in "A Majority in the Lifeboat," offering a complementary response to Dworkin's original rejoinder. The paper emphasizes the importance of understanding law not in isolation but as part of a broader scheme of justice, echoing Isaiah Berlin's concept. Keywords: Ronald Dworkin, Justice for Hedgehogs, partnership democracy, political morality, Jeremy Waldron, legal interpretation, justice.

title: Democracy and Economic Development
abstract: With the goal of freeing the world from poverty, some Western authorities have consistently insisted on promoting democracy in totalitarian states in the past decades. Seeing that democratic political system are stably established more and more in many countries, an opportunity arises to determine the effects of democracy on economic development. Taking advantage of this fact, this paper attempts to explore whether or not democracy contributes largely to prosperity of a nation. The conclusion is that, whereas democracy acts as a catalyst that influences prosperity in many already well-to-do nations, democracy per se is not significantly beneficial to low initial income countries. Another interesting point found in this study is that the Western colonialism tends to be one of the most significant factors in explaining poor economic development in many regions of the world today.
summary: This paper investigates the effects of democracy on economic development and national prosperity, aiming to determine if democracy significantly contributes to a nation's wealth. The study concludes that democracy acts as a catalyst for prosperity in already affluent nations but is not substantially beneficial for low initial income countries. A key finding is that Western colonialism is a significant factor explaining poor economic development in many parts of the world today. This research explores themes of democracy, authoritarianism, economic growth, and economic institutions.

title: Democracy and Reforms: Evidence from a New Dataset
abstract: Empirical evidence on the relationship between democracy and economic reforms is limited to few reforms, countries, and years. This paper studies the impact of democracy on the adoption of economic reforms using a new dataset on reforms in the financial, capital and banking sectors, product markets, agriculture, and trade for 150 countries over the period 1960-2004. Democracy has a positive and significant impact on the adoption of economic reforms but there is no evidence that economic reforms foster democracy. Our results are robust to the inclusion of a large variety of controls and estimation strategies.
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between democracy and the adoption of economic reforms, addressing the limited empirical evidence available. Utilizing a novel dataset encompassing reforms across financial, capital, banking, product markets, agriculture, and trade sectors in 150 countries from 1960 to 2004, the study finds a significant positive impact of democracy on economic reform adoption. Conversely, there is no evidence suggesting that economic reforms foster democracy. The findings are robust to various control variables and estimation strategies, providing key insights into the dynamics between political systems and economic liberalization.

title: Challenges to Fair Elections 5: Poll Worker Training
abstract: If elections are the foundation of our democracy, then poll workers are the gears and wheels that make the mechanics of democracy function on Election Day. Regrettably, this human factor is often overlooked and under-supported. States squeak by each year with a bare minimum of poll workers who receive inadequate training for an increasingly complex task. Recent surveys, press accounts, and troubled primary elections attest to the problem
summary: This document addresses the critical role of poll workers in democratic elections, highlighting how their insufficient training and support compromise the fairness and efficiency of Election Day processes. It cites examples from Maryland and Ohio's 2006 primary elections, where issues like late poll openings, lost vote tallies, and difficulties with new voting machines were prevalent due to inadequate poll worker preparation. The document advocates for improved training programs and increased support for poll workers to ensure a robust and inclusive democracy. Key themes include election administration, voter engagement, and democratic ideals.

title: War and endogenous democracy
abstract: Many episodes of extension of franchise in the 19th and especially in the 20th century occurred during or in the aftermath of major wars. Motivated by this fact, we offer a theory of political transitions which focuses on the impact of international conflicts on domestic political institutions. We argue that mass-armies, which appeared in Europe after the French Revolution, are an effective military organization only if the conscripted citizens are willing to put effort in fighting wars, which in turn depends on the economic incentives that are provided to them. The need to provide such incentives implies that an oligarchy adopting a mass-army may voluntarily decide to promise some amount of income redistribution to its citizens, conditionally on satisfactory performance as soldiers. When the elite cannot credibly commit to provide an incentive-compatible redistribution, they may cope with the moral hazard problem of the citizens-soldiers only by relinquishing political power to them through the extension of franchise. This is because democracy always implements a highly redistributive fiscal policy, which makes fighting hard incentive-compatible for the citizens-soldiers. We show that a transition to democracy is more likely to occur when the external threat faced by an incumbent oligarchy is in some sense intermediate. A very high external threat allows the elite to make credible commitments of future income redistribution in favor of the citizens, while a limited external threat makes optimal for the elite not making any (economic or political) concession to the masses. Some historical evidence consistent with our theory is also provided
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Transitions, International Conflicts, Democracy, Franchise Extension
summary: This theory explores political transitions, focusing on how international conflicts influence domestic political institutions, particularly the extension of franchise. It argues that mass-armies, crucial since the French Revolution, are effective only if conscripted citizens are motivated by economic incentives. Oligarchies may promise income redistribution or, if commitment is an issue, relinquish power through franchise extension to ensure soldier performance. Democracy, implementing redistributive fiscal policy, makes fighting incentive-compatible. The study shows that an intermediate external threat is most likely to trigger a transition to democracy, as high threats allow credible commitments and low threats deter concessions. Historical evidence supports this theory of endogenous democracy.

title: Rawls and deliberative democracy
abstract: This chapter offers arguments to support the following conjectures: (1) despite claims by Rawls and some commentators, Rawls is not and cannot be a deliberative democrat; the evidence for this can be gleaned by focussing on various interpretations of the structure of Rawls’ arguments in A Theory of Justice (1972) and Political Liberalism (1993) respectively; and (2) if we ask more directly how the ideal dialogue of the original position might be approximated in real-world conditions, we can reach suggestive conclusions about institutions and deliberative democracy radically different from those reached by Rawls himself
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Philosophy, Deliberative Democracy, Justice
summary: This chapter critically examines the relationship between John Rawls's theories of justice and deliberative democracy. It argues that despite claims by Rawls and commentators, Rawls cannot be considered a deliberative democrat, drawing evidence from interpretations of his arguments in "A Theory of Justice" (1972) and "Political Liberalism" (1993). Furthermore, the chapter suggests that directly considering how Rawls's ideal original position could be approximated in real-world conditions leads to conclusions about institutions and deliberative democracy that significantly diverge from Rawls's own, offering new perspectives on democratic legitimacy and public deliberation.

title: How a Court Becomes Supreme: Defending the Constitution from Unconstitutional Amendments
abstract: High courts around the world have increasingly invalidated constitutional amendments in defense of their view of democracy, answering in the affirmative what was once a paradoxical question with no obvious answer: can a constitutional amendment be unconstitutional?  In the United States, however, the Supreme Court has yet to articulate a theory or doctrine of unconstitutional constitutional amendment.  Faced with a constitutional amendment that would challenge the liberal democratic values of American constitutionalism—for instance an amendment restricting political speech or establishing a national religion—the Court would be left without a strategy or vocabulary to protect the foundations of constitutional democracy.  In this Article, I sketch eight strategies the Court could deploy in order to defend American constitutional democracy—and to make itself truly supreme by immunizing its judgments from reversal by constitutional amendment
summary: This article explores the concept of unconstitutional constitutional amendments, a phenomenon increasingly recognized by high courts globally but lacking a clear doctrine in the United States Supreme Court. The author, Richard Albert, sketches eight strategies the Court could employ to defend American constitutional democracy against amendments challenging liberal democratic values, such as those restricting speech or establishing a national religion. The strategies aim to protect the foundations of constitutional democracy and immunize the Court's judgments from reversal by amendment, despite the inherent difficulty of amending the U.S. Constitution.

title: The Media's Paradox Towards Democracy a Case of the Clash Between Media Indonesia and Vivanews in Munas Golkar 2009
abstract: Persaingan antara Aburizal Bakrie dan Surya Paloh dalam menduduki kursi ketuaumum Golkar tidak hanya terjadi di internal partai Golkar saja. Lebih dari itu, persaingan inidibawa ke hadapan public dengan terlibatnya Media Indonesia Grup yang dimiliki oleh Palohdan Vivanews yang dimiliki oleh Bakrie. Kedua Perusahaan media tersebut berlomba-lombauntuk mencuri perhatian publik untuk mengkampanyekan pemiliknya. Hal ini menyebabkanmedia yang seharusnya netral, non-partisan dan independen hanya menjadi alat darikekuasaan, tak ubahnya seperti peran militer di masa lalu. Oleh karena itulah, kehadiranmedia yang dianggap sebagai pilar keempat demokrasi patut untuk dipertanyakan. Semakinbesarnya kekuatan yang dimiliki oleh media menjadi sebuah paradoks dari nilai-nilaidemokrasi itu sendiri, dimana semakin kuat suatu media maka ia dapat dengan mudahdijadikan alat oleh pemiliknya untuk mengebiri nilai-nilai demokrasi yang melahirkannya.Dalam Munas Golkar yamg telah selesai digelar tersebut, publik benar-benar dicekokidengan segala macam pemberitaan tentang persaingan dalam munas walaupun hal itubukanlah sesuatu yang urgent atau berpengaruh secara signifikan terhadap kehidupanmereka
summary: This study examines the paradox of media's role in democracy, focusing on the competition between Aburizal Bakrie and Surya Paloh for the Golkar party leadership in 2009. It highlights how Media Indonesia Group and Vivanews, owned by Paloh and Bakrie respectively, were used to campaign for their owners, compromising media neutrality and independence. The paper argues that the growing power of media can undermine democratic values, turning the "fourth pillar of democracy" into an instrument of power, reminiscent of the military's past role. It raises questions about media objectivity and its influence on public discourse during critical political events like the Golkar national congress. Keywords: media ownership, political competition, democracy paradox, Golkar.

title: Is democracy beneficial for growth in countries with low ethnic diversity?
abstract: We study the impact of democracy on economic growth for a panel of the most and least ethnically diverse nations as documented by Easterly and Levine (1997). Using a GMM system to capture endogeneity and simultaneity, we find that democracy exerts a direct positive impact on growth, in addition to ameliorating the adverse effects of ethnic diversity on growth, unlike some of the results of the previous empirical literature
summary: This study investigates the effect of democracy on economic growth in nations with varying ethnic diversity, using a panel of countries identified by Easterly and Levine (1997). Employing a GMM system to address endogeneity and simultaneity, the research finds that democracy not only directly promotes growth but also mitigates the negative impacts of ethnic diversity, a finding that contrasts with some prior empirical literature. The key findings include a direct positive impact of democracy on growth and its role in ameliorating adverse effects of ethnic diversity. Keywords: Ethnic diversity, Democracy, Economic growth, Panel data, GMM system.

title: Democratic Institutions and Variability of Economic Growth in Pakistan: Some Evidence from the Time-series Analysis
abstract: This paper explores the empirical association between democracy and per capita output growth in Pakistan using data for the period 1947 to 2006. The findings of the paper indicate a weak negative association between democracy and output growth. Consistent with some current empirical literature, democracy is also found to influence output growth indirectly. The empirical results are robust to different democracy variables and output growth equation specifications. The empirical findings also highlight the role of other variables in determining output growth and, except for rising oil prices, show its positive linkage to physical and human capital, government consumption, openness of trade practices and inflation.Democracy, Growth, Time-series
summary: This paper investigates the empirical link between democracy and per capita output growth in Pakistan from 1947 to 2006. Utilizing time-series analysis, the study reveals a weak negative association, and democracy also indirectly influences output growth. The findings are robust across various democracy variables and equation specifications. The research also highlights the positive impact of physical and human capital, government consumption, trade openness, and inflation on output growth, while rising oil prices show a negative linkage. Keywords include Democracy, Economic Growth, and Time-series analysis.

title: Democracy\u2019s \u201cdoubles\u201d
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Science, Democracy, Populism, Autocracy
summary: This essay argues that the post-1989 era of liberal ascendancy has ended, replaced by a new period where the primary threat to freedom comes from "democracy's doubles"—regimes that mimic democratic forms but function as autocracies. Focusing on Hugo Chávez's Venezuela and Vladimir Putin's Russia, the author explores their shared kinship despite apparent differences. Drawing on Cas Mudde's work on populism, the essay analyzes how both Venezuelan populism and Russian elitism represent twin embodiments of the major threat to liberal democracy today, challenging traditional democratic principles.

title: Review of  Consolidating Taiwan’s Democracy
abstract: The article reviews the book Consolidating Taiwan\u27s Democracy by John F. Copper
summary: This article reviews John F. Copper's book "Consolidating Taiwan's Democracy," focusing on its analysis of Taiwan's political landscape, particularly the role of national identity in creating political gridlock between the "blue" and "green" camps. The review highlights Copper's timely examination of Taiwanese identity as a major cause of political impasse and suggests further elaboration on its development, especially the impact of elections since the mid-1990s. It also recommends evaluating the influence of the 2000 and 2001 elections on Taiwanese identity and its future effects on democratic consolidation.

title: Soft Power, World System Dynamics, and Democratization: A Bass Model of Democracy Diffusion 1800-2000
abstract: This article uses Polity IV data to probe system dynamics for studies of the global diffusion of democracy from 1800 to 2000. By analogy with the Bass model of diffusion of innovations, as translated into system dynamics by Sterman, the dynamic explanation proposed focuses on transitions to democracy, soft power, and communication rates on a global level. The analysis suggests that the transition from democratic experiences (\'the soft power of democracy\') can be estimated from the systems dynamics simulation of an extended Bass model. Soft power, fueled by the growth in communications worldwide, is today the major force behind the diffusion of democracy. Our findings indicate the applicability of system dynamics simulation tools for the analysis of political change over time in the world system of polities.Democracy, Bass, Communication, System Dynamics, Power, Diffusion
summary: This article investigates the global diffusion of democracy from 1800 to 2000 using Polity IV data and system dynamics. Analogous to the Bass model of innovation diffusion, the study focuses on transitions to democracy, soft power, and global communication rates. The analysis suggests that the "soft power of democracy," fueled by worldwide communication growth, is the primary force driving this diffusion. The findings highlight the applicability of system dynamics simulation tools for analyzing political change in the world system of polities over time, offering insights into democracy, communication, and power dynamics.

title: Millions to the Polls: Practical Policies to Fulfill the Freedom to Vote for All Americans
abstract: Voting is the bedrock of America's democracy. In a government of, by, and for the people, casting a ballot is the fundamental means through which we all have a say in the political decisions that affect our lives. Yet now, without substantial interventions, the freedom to vote is at great risk.This report contains a comprehensive and bold agenda of 16 policy proposals and common sense reforms. It details policies to help us realize the full promise of a democracy
summary: This report proposes a bold agenda of 16 policy reforms aimed at safeguarding and enhancing the freedom to vote in American democracy. It argues that voting is fundamental to citizen participation and that substantial interventions are required to address current risks to this right. The document details practical policies designed to ensure all Americans have an equal chance and an equal say in political decisions. Key themes include voter rights, democratic participation, and electoral reform. The authors, J. Mijin Cha and Liz Kennedy from Dēmos, focus on ideal elections and money in politics.

title: Multiethnic Democracy
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Public goods, Ethnic divisions, Majority voting
summary: This paper presents a model exploring public goods provision in ethnically divided economies under majority voting. It finds that public goods provision may be lower if ethnically based transfers are permitted, but this link is broken when such transfers are disallowed. Regardless, majority voting provides an efficient level of public goods. However, if transfers are allowed, policy favors certain households, indicating that fairness necessitates their elimination. This study contributes to understanding multiethnic democracies, public goods, ethnic divisions, and majority voting.

title: Democracy, Property Rights, Income Equality, and Corruption
abstract: This paper presents theoretical and empirical evidence on the nexus between corruption and democracy. We establish a political economy model where the effect of democracy on corruption is conditional on income distribution and property rights protection. Our empirical analysis with cross-national panel data provides evidence that is consistent with the theoretical prediction. Moreover, the effect of democratization on corruption depends on the protection of property rights and income equality which shows that corruption is a nonlinear function of these variables. The results indicate that democracy will work better as a control of corruption if the property rights system works and there is a low level of income inequality. On the other hand if property rights are not secured and there is strong income inequality, democracy may even lead to an increase of corruption. In addition, property rights protection and the mitigation of income inequality contribute in a strong manner to the reduction of corruption.Corruption, Democracy, Income inequality, Property rights
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Corruption, Democracy, Income Inequality, Property Rights
summary: This paper examines the complex relationship between corruption and democracy, proposing a political economy model where democracy's impact on corruption is contingent on income distribution and property rights protection. Through empirical analysis using cross-national panel data, the study confirms its theoretical predictions, showing that democratization's effect on corruption is nonlinear and depends on property rights and income equality. The findings suggest that democracy more effectively controls corruption when property rights are secure and income inequality is low. Conversely, insecure property rights and high income inequality may exacerbate corruption, while strong property rights and reduced income inequality consistently contribute to its reduction.

title: Democracy and the curse of natural resources
abstract:
We propose a theoretical model to explain empirical regularities related to the curse of natural
resources. This is an explicitly political model which emphasizes the behavior and incentives of
politicians. We extend the standard voting model to give voters political control beyond the
elections. This gives rise to a new restriction into our political economy model: policies should
not give rise to a revolution. Our model clarifies when resource discoveries might lead to
revolutions, namely, in countries with weak institutions. Natural resources may be bad for
democracy by harming political turnover. Our model also suggests a non-linear dependence of
human capital on natural resources. For low levels of democracy human capital depends
negatively on natural resources, while for high levels of democracy the dependence is reversed.
This theoretical finding is corroborated in both cross section and panel data regressions
fieldOfStudy: Politics, curse of natural resources, democracy, political game, revolution, human capital
summary: This paper proposes a theoretical political model to explain the "curse of natural resources" by analyzing politician incentives and voter control beyond elections. The model introduces a constraint that policies should not trigger revolutions, clarifying that resource discoveries lead to revolutions in countries with weak institutions. It suggests natural resources can harm democracy by hindering political turnover and reveals a non-linear relationship between human capital and natural resources, corroborated by cross-section and panel data: negative dependence in low-democracy settings, reversed in high-democracy ones. Key concepts include political game, revolution, and human capital.

title: Reevaluating the Modernization Hypothesis
abstract: This paper revisits and critically reevaluates the widely-accepted modernization hypothesis which claims that per capita income causes the creation and the consolidation of democracy. We argue that existing studies find support for this hypothesis because they fail to control for the presence of omitted variables. There are many underlying historical factors that affect both the level of income per capita and the likelihood of democracy in a country, and failing to control for these factors may introduce a spurious relationship between income and democracy. We show that controlling for these historical factors by including fixed country effects removes the correlation between income and democracy, as well as the correlation between income and the likelihood of transitions to and from democratic regimes. We argue that this evidence is consistent with another well-established approach in political science, which emphasizes how events during critical historical junctures can lead to divergent political-economic development paths, some leading to prosperity and democracy, others to relative poverty and non-democracy. We present evidence in favor of this interpretation by documenting that the fixed effects we estimate in the post-war sample are strongly associated with historical variables that have previously been used to explain diverging development paths within the former colonial world.
summary: This paper critically reevaluates the modernization hypothesis, which posits that per capita income drives the creation and consolidation of democracy. The authors argue that previous studies supporting this hypothesis fail to account for omitted historical variables that influence both income and democracy. By controlling for these factors using fixed country effects, the study finds that the correlation between income and democracy, as well as transitions to and from democratic regimes, disappears. This evidence aligns with a political science approach emphasizing divergent political-economic development paths stemming from critical historical junctures. The fixed effects are strongly associated with historical variables explaining development paths in former colonial nations.

title: E-democracy: exploring the current stage of e-government
abstract: Governments around the world have been pressured to implement e-Government programs in order to improve the government-citizen dialogue. The authors of this article review prior literature on such efforts to find if they lead to increased democratic participation ("e-Democracy") for the affected citizens, with a focus on the key concepts of transparency, openness, and engagement. The authors find that such efforts are a starting point toward e-Democracy, but the journey is far from complete
authors: Van der Meer, Toni G. L. A.
summary: This article reviews existing literature on e-Government initiatives to assess their impact on democratic participation, specifically

title: Elections over...long live elections!
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Elections, Ukrainian Political Process, Local Government
summary: This document analyzes the mayoral elections held in Ukrainian cities in June 2000, particularly in Zaporizhya, Mykolayiv, and Vinnytsya, viewing them as a prelude to forthcoming parliamentary by-elections. It examines voting patterns to forecast outcomes for the by-elections, which are expected to shape the near-future political process and indicate the influence of political parties. The analysis highlights common election techniques between mayoral and parliamentary campaigns, noting that successful candidates often secured authority support, integrated into the power system, and leveraged local political preferences. Low voter turnout emerged as a significant factor in the election process.

title: A synthesis of the role of media reports and elections in Nigerian democracy
abstract: This paper examines the interplay between the media and the elections in Nigeria, and discusses some of the relevant communication models that could assist the media in effectively reporting future elections in the country. This study has employed a historical approach, and argues that since Nigeria attained its political independence in 1960; conducting free and fair elections has been the major political problem in the country. The paper observed that the June 12 1993 Presidential Elections resulted in a stalemate, while the 2007 Elections were flawed with cases of electoral irregularities. Many of the results of the elections that were approved earlier by the Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) were later cancelled by the Nigerian Judiciary, a confirmation that the elections were rigged as confirmed by most of the internal and the external observers that monitored the elections. As a part of the solutions to the problem of elections in Nigeria, this paper recommends the establishment of an Inter-Party Central Committee (ICPP), made up of the national executives of the registered political parties, to work in collaboration with the media as the committee supports the electoral commission to conduct free and fair elections in the country
publisher: Faculty of Social Sciences, Delta State University, Abraka, Nigeria.
summary: This paper investigates the relationship between media and elections in Nigeria, proposing communication models to enhance future election reporting. Employing a historical approach, the study argues that conducting free and fair elections has been a persistent political challenge since Nigeria's independence in 1960. It highlights issues like the 1993 Presidential Elections stalemate and widespread irregularities in the 2007 Elections, confirmed by judicial cancellations and observer reports.
