The paper recommends establishing an Inter-Party Central Committee (ICPP) to collaborate with the media and support the electoral commission in ensuring credible elections. Key terms include media, elections, Nigeria, political problems, communication models, and electoral irregularities.

title: Myth, Reality Past and Present, and Judicial Elections
abstract: Why do we have judicial elections? A democracy without elections for the legislature and executive (or, in parliamentary systems, for the executive as the leadership of the elected legislators), would be simply inconceivable. But no one would deny that eleven of our states, or many other nations, are democracies even though they do not elect judges. It might follow from that irrefutable, fundamental difference between elections for judges and for other offices, that judicial elections should not-or more to the point, need not-be conducted the same as other elections. Before we soar into debate, let us lay a foundation with elements of fact: first, the historical facts about why we have judicial elections; second, how well or poorly those facts-that is, the very purpose of having judicial elections-have been taken into account by the courts that have stricken efforts to treat judicial elections differently
summary: This paper explores the rationale behind judicial elections, contrasting them with other political elections. It delves into the historical context of why judicial elections exist and how courts have addressed efforts to differentiate them. The author argues for maintaining safeguards around judicial elections to protect litigants' constitutional rights and the unique function of courts, suggesting that making judicial elections too similar to other elections could deter excellent judicial candidates. Key concepts include judicial elections, democratic systems, judicial independence, and campaign ethics.

title: Do Elections Slow Down Economic Globalization Process in India? It's Politics Stupid!
abstract: I investigate whether timing of the elections impact economic globalization process or not in India. In other words, do elections slowdown economic globalization process? The theoretical underpinning is that, policies of economic globalization lead to economic and social hardships in short run but benefit the economy in the long run. The motto behind slowing down the economic globalization process before elections is that it leads to polarization of voters and thus negatively affects the incumbent government. I make use of Axel Dreherís economic globalization index and construct ëinstrumental electoral cycleí to capture the scheduled and midterm election cycle. Using time series data for India for the period 1970 ñ 2006, I find that scheduled elections are associated with slow down in economic globalization, whereas midterm elections are not. Replacing Dreherís economic globalization index with our modified globalization index does not alter the results. I also find that slow down in economic globalization process is responsive to the propinquity to a scheduled election year. Meaning, as incumbent government nears the scheduled elections, economic globalization process keeps slowing down, while this is exactly opposite during the early years of incumbent government in office. These results suggest that elections generate ìelectoral globalization cycleî in developing democratic country like India.http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/64406/1/wp929.pd
summary: This study investigates whether the timing of elections impacts the process of economic globalization in India, positing that globalization policies cause short-term hardships but long-term benefits, and slowing them before elections can polarize voters, negatively affecting the incumbent. Utilizing Axel Dreher's economic globalization index and an 'instrumental electoral cycle' for data spanning 1970-2006, the research finds that scheduled elections are associated with a slowdown in economic globalization, while midterm elections are not. This slowdown intensifies as scheduled elections approach. The findings suggest that elections generate an 'electoral globalization cycle' in democratic developing nations like India, highlighting the political economy of globalization.

title: The Usefulness of Corruptible Elections
abstract: The belief that elections reduce rent seeking by government officials is widely held, likewise the belief that rent seeking decreases as elections are less subject to corruption. In this paper we develop and test a model in which these beliefs are carefully examined. Our model indicates that, while elections may provide a disincentive for rent seeking, this disincentive (1) need not actually materialise, and (2), is not necessarily correlated with the integrity of the electoral protocol. We next consider the ability of village-level elections in rural China to reduce rent seeking, and the extent to which this ability varies as the elections are more or less corruptible. We find that in practice, even elections that appear quite corruptible provide a strong disincentive to rent seeking. Moreover, our results indicate which types of electoral reform lead to more effective popular oversight of leaders, and which do not.http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/39988/3/wp602.pd
summary: This paper examines the widely held belief that elections reduce rent-seeking by government officials, and that this effect strengthens with electoral integrity. Developing and testing a model, the authors find that while elections can disincentivize rent-seeking, this isn't guaranteed and doesn't always correlate with electoral protocol integrity. Focusing on village-level elections in rural China, the study reveals that even seemingly corruptible elections significantly deter rent-seeking. The findings also identify specific electoral reforms that enhance popular oversight of leaders, contributing to the understanding of political economics and governance in China.

title: The 2009 European Election in Italy: National or European?
abstract:
In June 2009, European citizens voted in the European Parliamentary elections.

Despite the relevance of the election, turnout across countries was particularly low. In Italy, too,

abstention is growing and this paper aims to explain why. Traditionally, low turnout in European

Parliamentary elections is explained by the fact that they are considered second-order elections

and, thus, less important than national elections. According to this perspective, national factors

are the main cause of lower turnout as compared to national elections. Thus, it is generally

considered that low turnout is not related to citizens’ support for the European Union or other

European attitudes, such as European identity. In this article, this perspective is questioned and

other individual factors are considered. In particular, a number of European attitudes are

considered as independent variables together with national factors. The findings show that

abstention in European Parliamentary elections in Italy is directly linked to citizens’ disaffection

with politics, rather than disaffection with government performance. Furthermore, attitudes

toward the European Union integration project play a role only when the level of political

involvement is high. Thus, European questions matter and turnout in European Parliamentary

elections is driven not only by national-level factors, but also by citizens’ satisfaction with the

European Union and sense of European identity
summary: This paper investigates the reasons behind low turnout in European Parliamentary elections in Italy, challenging the traditional "second-order election" perspective. It considers individual European attitudes alongside national factors as independent variables. The findings reveal that abstention is linked to citizens' disaffection with politics, not government performance. Furthermore, attitudes toward EU integration matter when political involvement is high. This study highlights that turnout is driven by both national factors and citizens' satisfaction with the European Union and European identity, emphasizing the role of European questions in electoral participation.

title: Garbled Elections
abstract: Majority rules are frequently used to decide whether or not a public good should be provided, but will typically fail to achieve an efficient provision. We provide a worst-case analysis of the majority rule with an optimally chosen majority threshold, assuming that voters have independent private valuations and are exante symmetric (provision cost shares are included in the valuations). We show that if the population is large it can happen that the optimal majority rule is essentially no better than a random provision of the public good. But the optimal majority rule is worst-case asymptotically efficient in the large-population limit if (i) the voters’ expected valuation is bounded away from 0, and (ii) an absolute bound for valuations is known
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Economics, Public Goods, Voting Mechanisms
summary: This paper conducts a worst-case analysis of majority rules with an optimally chosen majority threshold, examining their effectiveness in public good provision. Despite the common use of majority rules, they often fail to achieve efficient provision. The study assumes independent private valuations and ex-ante symmetric voters. Key findings indicate that in large populations, the optimal majority rule can be no better than random provision. However, it achieves worst-case asymptotic efficiency if voters' expected valuations are bounded away from zero and an absolute bound for valuations is known. This research provides insights into voting mechanisms, public goods, and economic efficiency.

title: Elections, Ideology, and Turnover in the U.S. Federal Government
abstract: A defining feature of public sector employment is the regular change in elected leadership. Yet, we know little about how elections influence public sector careers. We describe how elections alter policy outputs and disrupt the influence of civil servants over agency decisions. These changes shape the career choices of employees motivated by policy, influence, and wages. Using new Office of Personnel Management data on the careers of millions of federal employees between 1988 and 2011, we evaluate how elections influence employee turnover decisions. We find that presidential elections increase departure rates of career senior employees, particularly in agencies with divergent views relative to the new president and at the start of presidential terms. We also find suggestive evidence that vacancies in high-level positions after elections may induce lower-level executives to stay longer in hopes of advancing. We conclude with implications of our findings for public policy, presidential politics, and public management
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Public Policy, Public Administration, Organizational Behavior
summary: This study investigates how presidential elections influence public sector careers and employee turnover in the U.S. federal government. Utilizing Office of Personnel Management data from 1988 to 2011, the researchers analyze millions of federal employees' career choices, particularly those motivated by policy, influence, and wages. Findings indicate that presidential elections increase departure rates among career senior employees, especially in agencies whose views diverge from the new president and at the beginning of presidential terms. Additionally, the study suggests that post-election vacancies in high-level positions might encourage lower-level executives to stay, hoping for advancement. These findings offer implications for public policy, presidential politics, and public management.

title: Donor Diversity through Public Matching Funds
abstract: New York State is considering a system of public campaign financing for state elections similar to the one New York City uses for municipal elections. In that system, the city puts up six dollars in public matching funds for each of the first $175 that a city resident contributes to a candidate participating in the voluntary program.One of the key purposes of the city's matching fund program is to strengthen the connections between public officials and their constituents by bringing more small donors into the process and making them more important to the candidates' campaigns. A previous paper by the Campaign Finance Institute showed that matching funds heighten the number and role of small donors in city elections and would be likely to do the same at the state level.This joint study by the Brennan Center for Justice and the Campaign Finance Institute tests whether these powerful but anecdotal claims are supported by the available evidence from the most recent state and municipal elections. To do so, we compared donors to candidates in the City Council elections of 2009, where there was a public financing program, to the donors to candidates in the State Assembly elections of 2010, where there was no such program. We compared the City Council and State Assembly races because those electoral districts are similar in size and because doing so allowed us to look at the giving patterns of the same city residents in different elections
summary: This study examines the effectiveness of public campaign financing in New York State elections, specifically comparing New York City's matching fund program with the absence of such a program in State Assembly elections. The research, conducted by the Brennan Center for Justice and the Campaign Finance Institute, investigates whether matching funds strengthen the connections between public officials and constituents by increasing the number and role of small donors. By comparing donor patterns in City Council elections (with public financing) and State Assembly elections (without), the authors analyze anecdotal claims, aiming to provide evidence-based insights into campaign finance reform and its impact on donor diversity and democratic participation. Keywords: campaign finance, public financing, matching funds, small donors, New York elections, political participation, election reform.

title: The Timing of Elections in Federations : A Disciplining Device against Soft Budget Constraints ?
abstract: We introduce political economics into the soft budget constraint problem by asking if the timing of elections has the potential to harden budget constraints. Specifically, we ask under which circumstances the soft budget constraint problem is worse - with synchronized elections, i.e. simultaneous central and regional office terms, or with staggered elections, i.e. terms of office that do not coincide. We find that staggered elections clearly improve fiscal discipline at the local level as well as welfare.Soft budget constraints, fiscal federalism, elections.
summary: This study introduces political economics into the soft budget constraint problem, investigating how the timing of elections can influence budget hardening. The authors analyze whether the soft budget constraint issue is more severe with synchronized elections (simultaneous central and regional office terms) or with staggered elections (non-coinciding terms). Their findings indicate that staggered elections significantly enhance fiscal discipline at the local level and improve overall welfare. This research contributes to understanding fiscal federalism and the impact of electoral timing on economic policy.

title: Polarization of the Sri Lankan Polity: An Analysis of Presidential Elections (1982 – 2005)
abstract: Sri Lanka is a multi-ethnic, multi-religious developing country that has enjoyed continuous universal adult franchise since 1931. Under a new constitution enacted in 1978, Sri Lanka moved to a presidential system of government. Since 1982 five presidential elections were conducted. This paper analyzes voter behavior by looking at all the five presidential elections. This study shows that all the winners of the presidential elections (except in 2005) won them by appealing across racial and religious boundaries with a popular mandate. In 2005, there was a shift; the winner was able to secure victory by promoting a hard-line pro-Sinhala nationalistic platform. This signals a departure from the previous elections, as in the past it was understood that minority support is crucial to win the Presidency. The 2005 election sends a dangerous signal to a country that is ravaged by ethnic violence for over 20 years. Further, this study looks at the voter behavior in urban vs. rural areas. Similar to the red vs. blue states divide in the US, in Sri Lanka, there is a strong urban-rural division in voter behavior. Logistic regression was used to analyze the results of the elections
summary: This paper analyzes voter behavior in Sri Lanka's presidential elections from 1982 to 2005, following the country's transition to a presidential system in 1978. The study reveals that most winners achieved victory by appealing across racial and religious lines, securing a popular mandate. However, the 2005 election marked a significant shift, where the winner succeeded by promoting a hard-line pro-Sinhala nationalistic platform, challenging the historical importance of minority support for presidential victories. The research also investigates urban versus rural voter behavior, identifying a strong urban-rural division akin to US political polarization. Logistic regression was employed for analysis, offering insights into Sri Lankan political dynamics and electoral trends.

title: E-Voting Solution for Romanian Parliament
abstract: Every year hundreds of millions of people vote in a variety of settings in many countries around the world. People vote in public elections to choose government leaders and also in private elections to determine the course of action for groups that people are organized in such as non-governmental organizations, unions, associations and corporations (shareholders). Voting is a widely spread, rather democratic, way of making decisions. More and more governments and private organizations realize that the use of new technologies such as the Internet can have beneficial impacts on elections - i.e. higher voter turnout and lower costs of conducting elections. The rules governing elections tend to be highly specialized to meet the specific needs of each type of organization. Most elections, however, require integrity, privacy and authentication.e-voting, elections, democracy, ngo, unions, government
summary: This paper presents an e-voting solution addressing the increasing global trend of using new technologies like the Internet for elections. It emphasizes the critical requirements for electoral integrity, privacy, and authentication in both public and private organizational contexts, such as non-governmental organizations, unions, and corporations. The proposed solution employs sophisticated algorithms for voter authentication and preventing multiple votes. It also delves into the technical aspects of client-server interaction, discussing protocols like XML-RPC and SOAP, highlighting SOAP's advantages in traversing firewalls via HTTP for secure and reliable internet-based voting systems. Keywords: e-voting, elections, democracy, online voting, secure elections.

title: The news coverage of the 2004 European Parliamentary Election Campaign in 25 countries
abstract:
This article analyzes the news coverage of the 2004 European Parliamentary\ud
(EP) elections in all 25 member states of the European Union (EU). It\ud
provides a unique pan-European overview of the campaign coverage based\ud
on an analysis of three national newspapers and two television newscasts in\ud
the two weeks leading up to the elections. On average, the elections were\ud
more visible in the new 10 member states than in the 15 old EU member\ud
states. The political personalities and institutional actors featured in news\ud
stories about the elections were generally national political actors and not EU\ud
actors. When it was evaluative, the news in the old EU-15 was generally\ud
negative towards the EU, while in the new countries a mixed pattern was\ud
found. The findings of the study are discussed in the light of the literature on\ud
the EU’s legitimacy and communication deficit
summary: This article provides a pan-European analysis of news coverage during the 2004 European Parliamentary (EP) elections across all 25 EU member states. Based on an examination of national newspapers and television newscasts, the study found that election visibility was higher in new member states. Political actors featured were predominantly national, not EU-level. News in the old EU-15 was generally negative towards the EU, while new countries showed a mixed pattern. The findings are discussed in the context of the EU's legitimacy and communication deficit literature, offering insights into media portrayal and political communication.

title: Political Institutions and Policy Outcomes: What are the Stylized Facts?
abstract: We investigate the effect of electoral rules and political regimes on fiscal policy outcomes in a panel of 61 democracies from 1960 and onwards. In presidential regimes, the size of government is smaller and less responsive to income shocks, compared to parliamentary regimes. Under majoritarian elections, social transfers are smaller and aggregate spending less responsive to to income shocks than under proportional elections. Institutions also shape electoral cycles; only in presidential regimes is fiscal adjustment delayed until after the elections, and only in proportional and parliamentary systems do social transfers expand around elections. Several of these empirical regularities are in line with recent theoretical work; others are still awaiting a theoretical explanation.comparative politics, constitution, fiscal policy, elections, democracies
fieldOfStudy: Politics, comparative politics, constitution, fiscal policy, elections, democracies
summary: This study investigates how electoral rules and political regimes impact fiscal policy in 61 democracies from 1960 onwards, using a panel data approach. It finds that presidential regimes lead to smaller, less responsive governments, while majoritarian elections result in smaller social transfers and less responsive aggregate spending. The research also reveals that fiscal adjustment is delayed post-election only in presidential systems, and social transfers expand around elections exclusively in proportional and parliamentary systems. These empirical regularities align with some existing theories but also highlight areas needing further theoretical explanation, contributing to comparative politics and the understanding of fiscal policy cycles.

title: Does Timing of Elections Instigate Riots? A Subnational Study of 16 Indian States, 1958-2004
abstract: We investigate whether timing of the elections leads to riots or not within India. In other words, does timing of elections instigate riots? The theoretical underpinning is that an incumbent government and opposition parties exercises control over their agents to instigate communal mob violence and riots during the election years. The motto behind instigating riots is that it leads to polarization of voters and thus benefits the respective constituents (incumbent government & opposition parties). Using time series crosssectional data for 16 major Indian states for the period 1958 ñ 2004, we find that scheduled elections are associated with increase in riots. Also intensity of riots, proxied by rate of growth rate of riots increases in scheduled election years. We also find that riots and intensity of riots are responsive to the propinquity to an election year. Meaning, as incumbent government nears the elections, riots and intensity of riots keeps increasing, while this is exactly opposite during the early years of incumbent government in office. These results suggest that elections generate ìriots cycleî in regionally, ethnically, culturally and socially diverse country like India.http://deepblue.lib.umich.edu/bitstream/2027.42/64385/1/wp939.pd
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Election Studies, Social Conflict, Indian Politics
summary: This study investigates whether the timing of elections instigates riots in India, hypothesizing that incumbent governments and opposition parties manipulate communal violence for voter polarization. Utilizing time-series cross-sectional data from 16 major Indian states (1958-2004), the research finds that scheduled elections are associated with an increase in both the occurrence and intensity of riots. It also reveals a "riots cycle," where riot activity escalates as elections approach during an incumbent's term but decreases in the early years of government. These findings highlight the political manipulation of social tensions around election periods in diverse societies.

title: Counting interesting elections
abstract:
We provide an elementary proof of a formula for the number of northeast
lattice paths that lie in a certain region of the plane. Equivalently, this
formula counts the lattice points inside the Pitman--Stanley polytope of an
n-tuple.Comment: 7 pages, 1 figure; published versio
summary:
This paper presents an elementary proof for a formula counting northeast lattice paths within a specific planar region, which is equivalent to counting lattice points inside the Pitman
Stanley polytope of an n-tuple. The work extends the classical "ballot problem" by considering more general conditions for vote tallying, motivated by a scenario where a news network aims to manipulate viewership by controlling the order of reported votes to achieve desired margins. This mathematical exploration provides methods for determining the number of ways such conditions can be satisfied.

title: Entropic Analysis of Votes Expressed in Italian Elections between 1948 and 2018
abstract: open access articleIn Italy, the elections occur often, indeed almost every year the citizens are involved in a democratic choice for deciding leaders of different administrative entities. Sometimes the citizens are called to vote for ﬁlling more than one ofﬁce in more than one administrative body. This phenomenon has occurred 35 times after 1948; it creates the peculiar condition of having the same sample of people expressing decisions on political bases at the same time. Therefore, the Italian contemporaneous ballots constitute the occasion to measure coherence and chaos in the way of expressing political opinion. In this paper, we address all the Italian elections that occurred between 1948and2018. Wecollectthenumberofvotesperpartyateachadministrativelevelandwetreateach electionasamanifestationofacomplexsystem. Then,weusetheShannonentropyandtheGiniIndex to study the degree of disorder manifested during different types of elections at the municipality level. A particular focus is devoted to the contemporaneous elections. Such cases implicate different disorder dynamics in the contemporaneous ballots, when different administrative level are involved. Furthermore, some features that characterize different entropic regimes have emerged
summary: This paper analyzes Italian elections between 1948 and 2018, focusing on the coherence and chaos in political opinion expression during contemporaneous ballots, where citizens vote for multiple offices at different administrative levels simultaneously. Treating each election as a complex system, the study employs Shannon entropy and the Gini Index to quantify disorder at the municipality level. The findings reveal distinct disorder dynamics in contemporaneous elections when various administrative tiers are involved, and characterize different entropic regimes. This research is valuable for understanding electoral behavior, political science, and complex systems analysis in democratic contexts.

title: Politics and public infrastructure investments in local governments: empirical evidence from Flemish municipalities (1996-2006)
abstract: In this paper, we estimate a public infrastructure investment function using a panel data set of 307 Flemish municipalities for the period 1996-2006. We particularly draw attention to political determinants of public infrastructure investment decisions. We show that the characteristics of the government, such as partisan affiliation and fragmentation, affect the level of public infrastructure investments Local governments are also sensitive to the investment policy of neighbouring municipalities. There is a positive interaction effect that changes own investments by 20% of that of neighbouring municipalities. Finally, elections obviously have an impact on investment policy. Investments increase the nearer elections come, with highest investments in the year before elections
fieldOfStudy: Politics, public investment, public infrastructure, partisan politics, political fragmentation, political budget cycles
summary: This paper estimates a public infrastructure investment function using a panel dataset of 307 Flemish municipalities from 1996-2006, focusing on political determinants. Key methods include panel data analysis to identify how government characteristics like partisan affiliation and fragmentation impact investment levels. Findings show that government characteristics affect public infrastructure investments, local governments are sensitive to neighboring municipalities' investment policies (20% interaction effect), and elections significantly influence investment policy, with the highest investments occurring in the year before elections. Keywords include public investment, public infrastructure, partisan politics, political fragmentation, and political budget cycles.

title: Exit, Voice, and Cyclicality: A Micro-Logic of Voting Behaviour in European Parliament Elections
abstract: Unlike other classics of political economy, “Exit, Voice, and Loyalty” (EVL) has not sparked many innovations in the field of electoral studies. This paper aims to demonstrate that scholars miss out on a powerful theory of political behaviour by leaving Hirschman’s ideas to other disciplines. To change this, I resolve several theoretical complications that have hampered the application of EVL to democratic elections. On this basis, I construct a model of voting behaviour through the electoral cycle to explain typical “second-order” effects in elections to the European Parliament (EP). Building on the parameters of EVL allows to unite such diverse phenomena as anti-government swings, declining turnout, protest voting, conversion and alienation in one theoretical framework. Testing the model with survey data from the European Election Studies of 1999 and 2004 reveals novel insights into the dynamics at work in EP elections. The role of strategic voting in the form of voice appears to be limited. Instead, processes of de- and realignment in the form of exit dominate a picture of EP elections that undermines the widespread conception of second-order irrelevance
summary: This paper re-examines Hirschman's "Exit, Voice, and Loyalty" (EVL) theory, proposing its application to democratic elections to address theoretical complications that have limited its use in electoral studies. The author constructs a model of voting behavior across the electoral cycle to explain "second-order" effects in European Parliament (EP) elections, integrating phenomena like anti-government swings, declining turnout, and protest voting. Testing with survey data from European Election Studies (1999, 2004) reveals that de- and realignment through 'exit' are more dominant in EP elections than strategic 'voice,' challenging the notion of their irrelevance.

title: Detecting and Correcting Election Fraud
abstract: I examine the provision of free and fair elections using a decision-theoretic model in which election observers provide a noisy information signal concerning fraud. Monitoring an election is not always worth the cost and so democracy is not always sustainable. A strong preference for fair elections can paradoxically make elections more difficult to monitor. Since fair elections are a public good, municipal election fraud result from Tiebout provision of this local public good. I offer several suggestions for organizations interested in facilitating the diffusion of democracy.Democracy; Election
summary: This paper investigates the provision of free and fair elections using a decision-theoretic model, where election observers provide noisy information regarding fraud. The author argues that monitoring elections is not always cost-effective, which can undermine the sustainability of democracy. Paradoxically, a strong preference for fair elections can make monitoring more challenging. The study posits that municipal election fraud may arise from Tiebout provision of this local public good. Several suggestions are offered for organizations aiming to facilitate the spread of democracy, highlighting the complex interplay of costs, information, and public goods in election integrity.

title: Garbled Elections

We provide a worst-case analysis of the majority rule with an optimally chosen majority threshold, assuming that voters have independent private valuations and are exante symmetric (provision cost shares are included in the valuations). We show that if the population is large it can happen that the optimal majority rule is essentially no better than a random provision of the public good. But the optimal majority rule is worst-case asymptotically efficient in the large-population limit if (i) the voters’ expected valuation is bounded away from 0, and (ii) an absolute bound for valuations is known.
summary: This study analyzes the effectiveness of majority rule in public good provision, acknowledging its typical failure to achieve efficient outcomes. The authors conduct a worst-case analysis of an optimally chosen majority threshold, assuming independent private valuations and ex-ante symmetric voters. They find that for a large population, the optimal majority rule can perform no better than random provision. However, it achieves worst-case asymptotic efficiency if voters' expected valuations are bounded away from zero and an absolute bound for valuations is known. This research contributes to understanding voting schemes and their efficiency limitations.

title: Endogenous Election Timings and Political Business Cycles in Japan
abstract: This paper constructs a theoretical model of political business cycles in a Parliamentary system and tests predictions and hypotheses of a theoretical model against the post-war Japanese data. Unlike in a presidential system, the timing of a general election is an endogenous policy variable in a parliamentary system. Thus, one of the interesting questions in a parliamentary system is whether elections cause business cycles or economic expansions trigger general elections. Empirical analyses of the post-war Japanese experience strongly indicate that the Japanese government did not manipulate policies in anticipation of approaching elections as political business cycle theories in a presidential system indicate. Instead, general elections were usually held during times of autonomous economic expansion. In other words, the Japanese government opportunistically manipulated the timing of elections rather than the economy.
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Business Cycles, Parliamentary Systems, Japanese Politics, Economic Cycles, Election Timing
summary: This paper develops a theoretical model of political business cycles specifically for parliamentary systems, differing from presidential systems where election timing is endogenous. The study empirically tests its predictions using post-war Japanese data, investigating whether elections cause business cycles or if economic expansions trigger elections. The findings strongly suggest that the Japanese government did not manipulate policies anticipating elections; instead, general elections were typically held during periods of autonomous economic expansion. This indicates an opportunistic manipulation of election timing rather than economic policy manipulation, contributing to political economy and business cycle theory.

title: DO ELECTIONS SLOW DOWN ECONOMIC GLOBALIZATION PROCESS IN INDIA? IT’S POLITICS STUPID !
abstract: I investigate whether timing of the elections impact economic globalization process or not in India. In other words, do elections slowdown economic globalization process? The theoretical underpinning is that, policies of economic globalization lead to economic and social hardships in short run but benefit the economy in the long run. The motto behind slowing down the economic globalization process before elections is that it leads to polarization of voters and thus negatively affects the incumbent government. I make use of Axel Dreher’s economic globalization index and construct ‘instrumental electoral cycle’ to capture the scheduled and midterm election cycle. Using time series data for India for the period 1970 – 2006, I find that scheduled elections are associated with slow down in economic globalization, whereas midterm elections are not. Replacing Dreher’s economic globalization index with our modified globalization index does not alter the results. I also find that slow down in economic globalization process is responsive to the propinquity to a schedule election year. Meaning, as incumbent government nears the schedule elections, economic globalization process keeps slowing down, while this is exactly opposite during the early years of incumbent government in office. These results suggest that elections generate “electoral globalization cycle” in developing democratic country like India.Economic globalization; Election cycles; India
summary: This study investigates whether election timing impacts economic globalization in India, theorizing that globalization policies cause short-term hardships but long-term benefits, and slowing them before elections prevents voter polarization. Employing Axel Dreher’s economic globalization index and an 'instrumental electoral cycle,' the research uses time series data for India (1970-2006). Findings indicate that scheduled elections are associated with a slowdown in economic globalization, a result robust to using a modified globalization index. The slowdown intensifies as incumbent governments approach scheduled elections, suggesting an "electoral globalization cycle" in developing democracies like India.

title: The Pressure is On: Organizing Without the NLRB
abstract:
[Excerpt] Ask the typical union organizer to define success and he or she will probably say,  Winning elections.  Many labor organizations, including ours, have found out that winning a National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) election does not mean that the workers involved are going to receive the benefits of a union contract. One third of representation elections won by unions do not result in a collective bargaining agreement.
In fact, just winning an NLRB election is a tough proposition. In 1990 the union win rate was only 47.6%. Even more alarming is the drop in the number of elections held in 1990 — 3,423, the lowest since 1984. In the 1960s and \u2770s, there were twice this number of elections each year. This trend is truly alarming when you consider that at the end of 1990 unions represented only 16.1% of the nation\u27s workforce — quite a drop from 35% of workers with a union contract in the mid-1950s. What can the labor movement do to reverse the trend of fewer and fewer workers being represented by unions
summary: This article examines the challenges faced by labor organizations in the United States, highlighting that winning National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) elections often does not lead to collective bargaining agreements. It notes a significant decline in union win rates and the number of elections held, alongside a substantial decrease in union representation among the workforce since the mid-1950s. The author explores alternative organizing strategies beyond traditional NLRB elections, suggesting methods to pressure non-union employers to improve working conditions and wages. The article advocates for a renewed focus on direct organizing tactics to reverse the trend of declining unionization.

title: POLITICAL ELECTIONS FOR MARKETERS
summary: This text examines political election campaigns from a marketer's perspective, dividing them into two main phases. The first phase focuses on developing an election strategy through sociological service, collecting regional social information, electorate expectations, and candidate perceptions to identify strengths and weaknesses. The second phase involves implementing the strategy, correcting the candidate's image, engaging with media, launching advertising, organizing voter meetings, monitoring competitors, and conducting anti-propaganda. This systematic approach, which includes continuous monitoring and rapid response, is recognized internationally as highly effective for political campaigning.

title: The politics of strategic budgeteering
abstract:
This paper analyzes how opportunistic governments choose between alternative fiscal policies

in order to increases their chances of re-election. To increase the provision of public goods

shortly before elections – and thus, to generate a fiscal political business cycles –

governments may either increase deficits or redistribute governmental resources from longterm

efficient sources to short-term efficient public programs. We argue that incumbents who

face highly competed elections principally have an incentive to spend more on public goods

even though these investments are not efficient in the long term. In principal, they would do

so by increasing the deficits (with re-balancing the budget after the election). However, our

model demonstrates that incumbents would even electioneer at the cost of long-term

investments if the extent of fiscal transparency does not allow them to finance the provision of

public goods with higher deficits. In other words, if elections are close and voters may

observe the governmental deficit, then governments tend to increase the provision of public

goods – and consequently, their electoral prospects – by a redistribution of budget resources

from long-term efficient investment to a short-term provision of public goods. We test the

predictions with new data on the composition of government consumption for 17 OECD

countries over 35 years. The preliminary findings suggest that governments indeed reshuffle

resources from long-term efficient investment to short-term public goods before elections

especially if elections are contested
publisher: Department of Economics, University of Warwick
summary: This paper analyzes how opportunistic governments choose between alternative fiscal policies to increase their re-election chances, focusing on generating fiscal political business cycles. The authors argue that incumbents facing highly competitive elections have an incentive to spend more on public goods, even if not long-term efficient. The model demonstrates that if fiscal transparency limits deficit financing, governments redistribute budget resources from long-term investments to short-term public goods to improve electoral prospects. This study tests these predictions using new data on government consumption composition for 17 OECD countries over 35 years, with preliminary findings suggesting such resource reshuffling, especially in contested elections. Keywords: fiscal policy, political business cycles, elections, public goods, government spending, fiscal transparency, OECD.

title: Income and vote switching between local and national elections: evidence from New York State
abstract: Between 1994 and 2004, New York State voters returned a Republican governor but always cast a majority of the popular vote in favor of the Democratic candidate in the presidential election. This paper exploits those elections in an effort to understand voters' motivations to switch party allegiances from presidential to gubernatorial elections. We argue that voters are likely to switch political allegiances between gubernatorial and presidential elections because they understand that the purpose of these elections is different. Using individual-level data, we find that low-income individuals are the main source of the switch in the vote.
summary: This paper investigates voter motivations for switching party allegiances between presidential and gubernatorial elections in New York State between 1994 and 2004, a period marked by a Republican governor and a Democratic majority in presidential votes. The authors argue that voters perceive different purposes for these elections, influencing their choices. Using individual-level data, the study identifies low-income individuals as the primary source of this vote switching behavior. Key methods include exploiting election data and individual-level analysis to understand political allegiance shifts, voting patterns, and socioeconomic influences on electoral outcomes.

title: Why Local Party Leaders Don't Support Nominating Centrists
abstract: Would giving party leaders more influence in primary elections in the United States decrease elite polarization? Some scholars have argued that political party leaders tend to support centrist candidates in the hopes of winning general elections. In contrast, the authors argue that many local party leaders - especially Republicans - may not believe that centrists perform better in elections and therefore may not support nominating them. They test this argument using data from an original survey of 1,118 county-level party leaders. In experiments, they find that local party leaders most prefer nominating candidates who are similar to typical co-partisans, not centrists. Moreover, given the choice between a more centrist and more extreme candidate, they strongly prefer extremists: Democrats do so by about 2 to 1 and Republicans by 10 to 1. Likewise, in open-ended questions, Democratic Party leaders are twice as likely to say they look for extreme candidates relative to centrists; Republican Party leaders are five times as likely. Potentially driving these partisan differences, Republican leaders are especially likely to believe that extremists can win general elections and overestimate the electorate's conservatism by double digits
summary: This study investigates whether increasing party leaders' influence in U.S. primary elections would reduce elite polarization, challenging the common assumption that leaders support centrists to win general elections. The authors argue that many local party leaders, especially Republicans, may not believe centrists perform better. Using an original survey of 1,118 county-level party leaders, experiments reveal that leaders prefer candidates similar to typical co-partisans, strongly favoring extremists over centrists (Democrats 2:1, Republicans 10:1). Republican leaders particularly believe extremists can win and overestimate the electorate's conservatism. This suggests local party leader involvement may not curb, but rather exacerbate, polarization.

title: Competition of Politicians for Incentive Contracts and Elections
abstract: When politicians have lower discount factors than voters, democratic elections cannot sufficiently motivate politicians to undertake long-term socially beneficial projects. When politicians can offer incentive contracts which become effective upon reelection, the hierarchy of contracts and elections can alleviate such inefficient decision-making in politics. This mechanism still works if the public cannot commit itself to a reelection scheme or if the public is unsure about the politicians’ time preferences. In the non-commitment case, incentive contracts may need to include a golden parachute clause.Keywords: Incentive contracts, politicians, long-term policies, elections and contracts, golden parachute clauseIncentive contracts, politicians, long-term policies, elections and contracts, golden parachute clause
summary: This paper investigates how incentive contracts can address the problem of politicians having lower discount factors than voters, leading to insufficient motivation for long-term socially beneficial projects. The authors propose a mechanism where politicians offer incentive contracts that become effective upon reelection, suggesting that this hierarchy of contracts and elections can improve political decision-making. The study also examines scenarios where the public cannot commit to reelection schemes or is uncertain about politicians' time preferences, noting that 'golden parachute' clauses may be necessary in non-commitment cases. This work is relevant for understanding long-term policies and the interplay between elections and contracts in governance.

title: Job Growth and Elections
summary: This article explores whether strong job growth is the best predictor of an incumbent president's re-election chances, or a challenger's success. It challenges the conventional wisdom that "people vote their pocketbook," citing examples of presidents who lost despite double-digit job growth. The author argues that electoral outcomes are influenced by a complex interplay of factors beyond economic stewardship, including inflation, interest rates, consumer confidence, and the prevailing societal context, such as war or calls for reform. Ultimately, many dimensions like vision, character, political skills, and leadership in a crisis contribute to voters' choices in presidential elections.

title: Haiti's Fatally Flawed Elections
abstract: This report describes the results of an independent recount of vote tally sheets from Haiti's November 28 presidential election. These 11,181 election tally sheets from across Haiti were posted online by Haiti's Provisional Electoral Council (CEP). It finds that for some 1,326 voting booths, or 11.9 percent of the total, tally sheets were either never received by the CEP or were quarantined for irregularities. This corresponds to about 12.7 percent of the vote, which was not counted and is not included in the final totals that were released by the CEP on December 7, 2010 and reported by the press. It also found many more tally sheets that had irregularities in the vote totals that were sufficient to disqualify them, and a large number of clerical errors that further undermines the credibility of the vote count. The report finds that based on the numbers of irregularities, it is impossible to determine who should advance to a second round. If there is a second round, it will be based on arbitrary assumptions and/or exclusions
publisher: Center for Economic and Policy Research
summary: This report presents an independent recount of 11,181 vote tally sheets from Haiti's November 28 presidential election, aiming to assess the credibility of the Provisional Electoral Council's (CEP) official results. The analysis reveals that 1,326 voting booths (11.9% of the total), representing 12.7% of the vote, were either unreceived or quarantined due to irregularities. Furthermore, numerous other tally sheets contained disqualifying irregularities and clerical errors. The findings suggest it is impossible to definitively determine who should advance to a second round, implying any such decision would be based on arbitrary assumptions. Keywords: Haiti, presidential election, vote recount, electoral irregularities, Provisional Electoral Council (CEP), election credibility.

title: Incumbency, Party Identity and Governmental Lead: Evidence for Heterogeneous Incumbency Effects for Germany
abstract: Do incumbents in an election have an advantage, and if so, are these advantages heterogeneous across parties or government and opposition? We first present a theoretical discussion on the possible heterogeneity of incumbency effects in a pure two-party system. Then, we estimate the incumbency effect for the direct district candidates in German federal and state elections using a regression discontinuity design (RDD). When studying the heterogeneity in these effects, we find that incumbents from both large parties, the center-right CDU and the center-left SPD, have an advantage only if the SPD is in government. This effect is robust and shows even in state elections that are unrelated to federal elections - calling into question the findings of average incumbency effects in the literature. Because this effect is stronger in the East than in the West and only shows post reunification, we hypothesise that the emergence of the socialist party "The Left" may be behind this heterogeneity.incumbency advantage, regression discontinuity design, federal elections, state elections
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Elections, Public Policy, Political Science
summary: This paper investigates the heterogeneity of incumbency effects in German federal and state elections, using a regression discontinuity design (RDD). The study theorizes on incumbency advantages in a two-party system and empirically finds that incumbents from both the CDU and SPD parties benefit only when the SPD is in government. This robust effect, observed even in unrelated state elections, challenges existing literature on average incumbency effects. The researchers hypothesize that the emergence of "The Left" party, particularly after reunification and with a stronger effect in East Germany, contributes to this observed heterogeneity. Keywords include incumbency advantage, regression discontinuity design, federal elections, and state elections.

title: Election Day Registration: A Study of Voter Fraud Allegations and Findings on Voter Roll Security
abstract: The specter of fraud in American elections has pervaded our political and media landscape for a long time. In recent years it has been raised again as a key lever in arguments for or against certain state or federal election reforms -- in legislative and judicial bodies, and in the media. Allegations of voter fraud in elections have been widely publicized, but the question of whether voter fraud threatens the integrity of elections in the United States has long been neglected by serious researchers. This report draws on my research into the scale and scope of the problem of voter fraud and the politics of election reform. Here I look at the question of voter fraud in states with Election Day Registration (EDR), a vital reform which, like other procedures that lower barriers to the vote, has been resisted based on unfounded allegations of fraud
summary: This report investigates the pervasive allegations of voter fraud in American elections, a topic often neglected by serious researchers despite its prominence in political and media discourse. The author examines the scale and scope of voter fraud, particularly in states with Election Day Registration (EDR), a reform frequently resisted due to unsubstantiated fraud claims. By drawing on existing research, the study aims to assess whether voter fraud genuinely threatens the integrity of U.S. elections and informs debates on state and federal election reforms. Key terms include voter fraud, election reform, Election Day Registration, and election integrity.

title: POLITICAL ELECTIONS FOR MARKETERS
abstract: SrFe12O19 coatings, intended as electromagnetic wave absorbers, were produced by atmospheric plasma spraying (APS) using two different kindsof feedstock powders: spray-dried agglomerates of micrometric SrFe12O19 particles (type-A) or spray-dried agglomerates of raw materials (SrCO3,Fe2O3), reactively sintered at 1100 ◦C (type-B).During spraying, type-A agglomerates either remain unmelted, producing porous coating regions where crystalline hexaferrite is retained, orare disrupted into smaller granules which melt completely, resulting in dense coating regions with no crystalline hexaferrite.The sintered type-B agglomerates possess higher cohesive strength and do not fall apart: the finer ones melt completely, whereas, in the largerones, the outer region melts and infiltrates the porous unmelted core which retains crystalline hexaferrite. Dense coatings can therefore be obtainedwhile preserving high amounts of crystalline hexaferrite even inside the dense areas. Such coatings show magnetic properties that are promisingfor electromagnetic wave absorption applications
summary: This text examines political election campaigns from a marketing perspective, outlining a two-phase strategy. The first phase involves sociological research to gather regional social information, assess electorate expectations, and identify candidate strengths/weaknesses for tailored messaging. The second phase focuses on developing and implementing the campaign model, adjusting the candidate's image, engaging media, launching advertising, organizing voter meetings, and monitoring competitor activity. This comprehensive approach, utilizing sociological services and strategic marketing, is presented as an internationally recognized effective method for political campaigning.

title: Aggregating Dependency Graphs into Voting Agendas in Multi-Issue Elections
abstract:
Many collective decision making problems have a
          combinatorial structure: the agents involved must
          decide on multiple issues and their preferences over
          one issue may depend on the choices adopted for
          some of the others. Voting is an attractive method
          for making collective decisions, but conducting a
          multi-issue election is challenging. On the one hand,
          requiring agents to vote by expressing their preferences
          over all combinations of issues is computationally
          infeasible; on the other, decomposing the
          problem into several elections on smaller sets of
          issues can lead to paradoxical outcomes. Any pragmatic
          method for running a multi-issue election will
          have to balance these two concerns. We identify
          and analyse the problem of generating an agenda
          for a given election, specifying which issues to vote
          on together in local elections and in which order to
          schedule those local elections
summary: This paper addresses the problem of collective decision-making in multi-issue elections, where agents' preferences are interdependent across issues. The authors highlight the computational infeasibility of expressing preferences over all combinations of issues and the risk of paradoxical outcomes when decomposing problems. They propose and analyze a method for generating an optimal agenda for such elections. This involves specifying which issues to group for local elections and the optimal order of scheduling these local elections, balancing computational demands with avoiding undesirable outcomes. Key concepts include combinatorial structure, multi-issue elections, voting agendas, and collective decision making.

title: Loss Aversion, Presidential Responsibility, and Midterm Congressional Elections
abstract: I explore a behavioral model of political participation, first introduced by Quattrone and Tversky [1988], based on the primitives of prospect theory, as defined by Kahneman and Tversky [1979]. The model offers an alternative explanation for why the President’s party tends to lose seats in midterm congressional elections. The model is examined empirically and compared against competing explanations for the “midterm phenomenon”.Loss aversion, midterm elections, congressional elections, negative voting, midterm effect
