summary: This paper explores a behavioral model of political participation, building on Quattrone and Tversky's 1988 work and Kahneman and Tversky's 1979 prospect theory. The model aims to provide an alternative explanation for the

title: IS THERE ELECTORAL CYCLES IN GLOBALIZATION PROCESS? EVIDENCE FROM 78 DEMOCRATIC COUNTRIES, 1975 – 2006
abstract: I investigate whether timing of the elections impact globalization process or not in democratic countries across the globe. In other words, do elections slowdown globalization process? The theoretical underpinning is that, globalization process lead to economic and social hardships in short run but benefit the economy in the long run. The motto behind slowing down globalization process before elections is that it leads to polarization of voters and thus negatively affects the incumbent government. I make use of Axel Dreher’s comprehensive globalization index as proxy for overall globalization process; economic globalization index for economic globalization policies and restrictions index as proxy for removal of trade and financial restrictions. I then construct ‘instrumental electoral cycle’ to capture the scheduled and midterm election cycle. Using cross-sectional time series data for 78 democratic countries for the period 1975 – 2006, I find that scheduled elections are associated with slow down in all the three forms of globalization process, whereas midterm elections are not. Replacing all three Dreher’s indices with our modified indices does not alter the results. I also find that slow down in globalization process is responsive to the propinquity to a scheduled election year. Meaning, as incumbent government nears the scheduled elections, globalization process keeps slowing down, while this is exactly opposite during the early years of incumbent government in office. These results suggest that elections generate “electoral globalization cycle” in democratic countries.Globalization; Election cycles
summary: This study investigates whether the timing of elections impacts the globalization process in democratic countries. Utilizing Axel Dreher's globalization indices and a constructed 'instrumental electoral cycle,' the research analyzes cross-sectional time series data for 78 democratic nations from 1975 to 2006. The findings indicate that scheduled elections are associated with a slowdown in economic, overall, and trade/financial globalization. This slowdown is more pronounced as scheduled elections approach, reversing in the early years of an incumbent government. The study posits the existence of an 'electoral globalization cycle' driven by the need to avoid voter polarization before elections.

title: Posturing by Romania’s political parties ahead of December elections shows that they are not just competing for power, but for their own survival
abstract: This month has seen massive rallies for Romania’s political parties ahead of parliamentary elections in December, with the European People’s Party holding its congress and the ruling USL alliance hosting an 80,000 strong rally. Clara Volintiru looks at this political posturing between the rival factions of the President and Prime Minister, and argues that these rallies ignore the general political disenchantment of most Romanians, and that there is a real risk of significant voter apathy come the December elections
publisher: Blog post from London School of Economics & Political Science
summary: This analysis examines the extensive political rallies held in Romania ahead of the December parliamentary elections, involving the European People's Party and the ruling USL alliance. Clara Volintiru argues that these displays, from rival factions of the President and Prime Minister, largely disregard the widespread political disenchantment among most Romanians. The paper highlights a significant risk of voter apathy in the upcoming elections, potentially replicating past uncertainties and exacerbating a national crisis with lasting economic and governance damages. Key themes include Romanian politics, parliamentary elections, voter apathy, political parties, and political posturing.

title: Illinois Government Research no. 43 1976: As Goes Illinois... The State as a Political Microcosm of the Nation
abstract:
The old saying has it that in presidential elections "as
goes Maine, so goes the nation." While this statement may
have once been valid, over the last forty years the bellwether
nature of the state of Maine has been open to serious
challenge. In fact, in the last ten presidential elections
Maine has cast its electoral vote for the losing candidate
six times. The question of which state most closely follows
national patterns in presidential elections is an interesting
one, however, especially in this presidential year. If one
could find a state in which national presidential returns
were closely mirrored over a period of years ??? and if one
had some idea why this state-national parallelism existed ???
that state's returns would provide not only a clue to the
national outcome, but also some reasons for it.published or submitted for publicatio
publisher: Institute of Government and Public Affairs. University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign.
summary: This study challenges the traditional notion that "as goes Maine, so goes the nation" in presidential elections, noting Maine's frequent misalignment with national outcomes over the past forty years. It proposes Illinois as a more accurate political microcosm of the United States. The research analyzes Illinois's electoral and popular vote patterns from the twentieth century, finding a strong correlation with national presidential election results. It examines socioeconomic and political mobilization factors contributing to Illinois's competitive and mirroring electoral behavior, suggesting that while the state currently reflects national trends, future political changes may alter this parallelism. Keywords: presidential elections, electoral patterns, political microcosm, Illinois, national politics.

title: Marine Le Pen’s result in last Sunday’s French elections confounded the experts but does not signal the rise of the far right in Europe
abstract: Pollsters often get election results wrong, and this week’s French elections were no exception, with Front National candidate Marine Le Pen gaining more votes than was widely expected. As part of our continuing series on the French elections, Marley Morris reflects on the result, finding that while we should be careful to not exaggerate the success of Le Pen, the result puts her and not left-winger Mélenchon in the spotlight
publisher: Blog post from London School of Economics & Political Science
summary: This reflection analyzes the unexpected success of Marine Le Pen in the 2012 French elections, where her Front National party garnered more votes than polls predicted, confounding experts. The author, Marley Morris, cautions against exaggerating the far-right's rise in Europe but highlights Le Pen's increased prominence over left-winger Mélenchon. The article discusses reasons for polling inaccuracies, including assumptions about voter siphoning and Le Pen's campaign, while noting her 17.9% vote share was the party's highest. Key terms include French elections, Marine Le Pen, Front National, polling, far-right politics.

title: The Elections Performance Index 2012: The State of Election Administration and Prospects for the Future
abstract: In 2012, The Pew Charitable Trusts unveiled the Elections Performance Index, or EPI, an online tool that provides the first comprehensive assessment of election administration in all 50 states and the District of Columbia.The revised interactive adds data from the 2012 elections and makes it possible for the first time to compare performance across two presidential election years. Users can get the broad national picture by reading the brief here and visit the website for additional fact sheets
summary: This document introduces the 2013 edition of The Pew Charitable Trusts' Elections Performance Index (EPI), an online tool offering a comprehensive assessment of election administration across all 50 U.S. states and the District of Columbia. The updated index incorporates 2012 election data, allowing users to compare performance across two presidential election years (2008 and 2012) and against other states and national averages. Key findings indicate an overall improvement in election performance in 2012 compared to 2008, with fewer voters reporting deterrence due to illness, disability, or registration issues, and an increase in online voter registration options. The EPI aims to clarify leading state practices to help others improve. Keywords: Elections Performance Index, EPI, election administration, voter turnout, online registration, Pew Charitable Trusts, U.S. elections.

title: A new view into political business cycles: Household expenditures in Albania
abstract: Over the last decades, there has been plenty of research and articles on Political Business Cycles (PBC), aiming at analyzing and explaining the use of fiscal and monetary instruments to stimulate economic growth before elections, to impress the voters. Following other researches for PBC in Albania, in which there was found clear evidence of fiscal expansion before elections, but no significant changes in inflation and GDP, as theory predicts, we analyze the peoples' expectations related to elections outcomes, and the way these expectations influence their decisions to spend, and consequently the macroeconomic variables. --Political Business Cycle,Household Behaviour,Albanian
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Business Cycle, Household Behaviour
summary: This research examines Political Business Cycles (PBC), which involve using fiscal and monetary policies to stimulate economic growth before elections to influence voters. Following prior research in Albania that showed fiscal expansion before elections but no significant changes in inflation or GDP, this study analyzes how people's expectations regarding election outcomes affect their spending decisions and, consequently, macroeconomic variables. The paper aims to provide a new perspective on PBCs by focusing on household behavior and its impact on economic indicators in Albania.

title: Democratic dawn? : Civil society and elections in Myanmar 2010 – 2012
abstract: While the general elections in Myanmar in November 2010 were widely condemned, both national and international actors approached the by-elections of April 2012 as a political rite-de-passage to improve relations between the government and the opposition inside, and between the former pariah state and the international community outside the country. An undercurrent to the government-led transition process from an authoritarian to a formally more democratic regime was the development of a politically oriented civil society that found ways to engage in the electoral process. This article describes the emerging spaces of election-related civil society activism in the forms of civic and voter education, national election observation, and election-related agency in the media. Noting that, in particular, election observation offers connections for civil society to regional and international debates, the paper draws preliminary conclusions about further developments ahead of the general elections in Myanmar expected for 2015
summary: This article examines the role of an emerging politically oriented civil society in Myanmar's electoral processes between 2010 and 2012. While the 2010 general elections were condemned, the 2012 by-elections were viewed as a critical step in improving relations between the government and opposition, and with the international community. The paper describes civil society activism through civic and voter education, national election observation, and media engagement, noting the connections election observation offers to regional and international debates. It draws preliminary conclusions about future developments ahead of the 2015 general elections, focusing on civil society's engagement and political transition.

title: Stylized facts in Brazilian vote distributions
abstract:
Elections, specially in countries such as Brazil with an electorate of the
order of 100 million people, yield large-scale data-sets embodying valuable
information on the dynamics through which individuals influence each other and
make choices. In this work we perform an extensive analysis of data sets
available for Brazilian proportional elections of legislators and city
councillors throughout the period 1970-2012, which embraces two distinct
political regimes: a military dictatorship and a democratic phase. Through the
distribution $P(v)$ of the number of candidates receiving $v$ votes, we perform
a comparative analysis of different elections in the same calendar and as a
function of time. The distributions $P(v)$ present a scale-free regime with a
power-law exponent $\alpha$ which is not universal and appears to be
characteristic of the electorate. Moreover, we observe that $\alpha$ typically
increases with time. We propose a multi-species model consisting in a system of
nonlinear differential equations with stochastic parameters that allows to
understand the empirical observations. We conclude that the power-law exponent
$\alpha$ constitutes a measure of the degree of feedback of the electorate
interactions. To know the interactivity of the population is relevant beyond
the context of elections, since a similar feedback may occur in other social
contagion processes.Comment: 8 pages, 8 figures, a version with some modifications was published
  in PLoS ON
summary:
This work analyzes large-scale datasets from Brazilian proportional elections (1970-2012) to understand voter dynamics and influence. Focusing on the distribution P(v) of votes, the study found a non-universal, electorate-characteristic power-law exponent "alpha" that typically increases over time, reflecting distinct political regimes. A multi-species model of nonlinear differential equations with stochastic parameters is proposed to explain these empirical observations. The power-law exponent 
"alpha" is identified as a measure of the electorate's feedback degree, with implications for understanding social contagion processes beyond elections. This research offers insights into election dynamics, social influence, and complex systems.

title: Electoral reform in local government: alternative systems and key issues
abstract: The Government plans a full modernisation of local government, including annual elections and a stronger scrutiny role for elected representatives. Such a programme must also consider reform options which improve the match between votes and seats, revitalise local electoral dynamics and strengthen links between councillors and constituents. This research, by Patrick Dunleavy and Helen Margetts, investigates a key possibility for such an agenda: changing the local electoral system. The researchers simulated local elections under five alternative electoral systems to first-past-the-post
summary: This research by Patrick Dunleavy and Helen Margetts investigates alternative electoral systems for local government in England, aiming to improve the match between votes and seats, revitalize electoral dynamics, and strengthen links between councillors and constituents. By simulating local elections under five alternative systems to first-past-the-post using data from 12 localities, the study found that Alternative Vote or Supplementary Vote would ensure majority support for councillors but not improve vote-to-seat proportionality. List Proportional Representation and Single Transferable Vote would generally produce proportional outcomes but require larger wards and pose implementation challenges, particularly for annual elections and independent candidates.

title: The Right Look: Conservative Politicians Look Better and Their Voters Reward It
abstract: Previous research has established that good-looking political candidates win more votes. We extend this line of research by examining differences between parties on the left and on the right of the political spectrum. Our study combines data on personal votes in real elections with a web survey in which 2,513 non-Finnish respondents evaluated the facial appearance of 1,357 Finnish political candidates. We find that political candidates on the right are better looking in both municipal and parliamentary elections and that they have a larger beauty premium in municipal, but not in parliamentary, elections. As municipal candidates are relatively unknown, the beauty-premium gap indicates that voters – especially those to the right – use beauty as a cue for candidate ideology or quality in the municipal elections.beauty, elections, political candidates, appearance, ideology, parties
summary: This study examines the relationship between candidate appearance and electoral success, extending previous research by analyzing differences across the political spectrum. Utilizing data from real elections and a web survey of 2,513 non-Finnish respondents evaluating 1,357 Finnish political candidates, the authors find that right-leaning candidates are generally considered better-looking. Furthermore, these candidates exhibit a larger "beauty premium" in municipal elections, where candidates are less known. This suggests that voters, particularly those on the right, may use physical attractiveness as a heuristic for candidate ideology or quality in less prominent elections. The study explores beauty, elections, political candidates, appearance, ideology, and parties.

title:
From 2000 Bush-Gore to 2006 Italian elections: Voting at fifty-fifty and
  the Contrarian Effect
abstract:
A sociophysical model for opinion dynamics is shown to embody a series of
recent western hung national votes all set at the unexpected and very
improbable edge of a fifty-fifty score. It started with the Bush-Gore 2000
American presidential election, followed by the 2002 Stoiber-Schr\H{o}der, then
the 2005 Schr\H{o}der-Merkel German elections, and finally the 2006
Prodi-Berlusconi Italian elections. In each case, the country was facing
drastic choices, the running competing parties were advocating very different
programs and millions of voters were involved. Moreover, polls were given a
substantial margin for the predicted winner. While all these events were
perceived as accidental and isolated, our model suggests that indeed they are
deterministic and obey to one single universal phenomena associated to the
effect of contrarian behavior on the dynamics of opinion forming. The not hung
Bush-Kerry 2005 presidential election is shown to belong to the same universal
frame. To conclude, the existence of contrarians hints at the repetition of
hung elections in the near future.Comment: 17 pages, 8 figure
summary: This study introduces a sociophysical model for opinion dynamics to explain a series of unexpectedly close "hung" national elections in Western countries, including the Bush-Gore (2000), Stoiber-Schröder (2002), Schröder-Merkel (2005), and Prodi-Berlusconi (2006) contests. Despite predictions for clear winners, these elections consistently resulted in near fifty-fifty splits. The model suggests these outcomes are not accidental but deterministic, driven by a universal phenomenon: the effect of contrarian behavior on opinion formation dynamics. The research also extends this framework to the Bush-Kerry (2005) election, implying that contrarian voters predict future hung elections. This work is significant for understanding political outcomes, opinion dynamics, and voter behavior.

title: The Looks of a Winner: Beauty, Gender and Electoral Success
abstract: We study the role of beauty in politics. For the first time, focus is put on differences in how women and men evaluate female and male candidates and how different candidate traits relate to success in real and hypothetical elections. We have collected 16,218 assessments by 2,772 respondents of photos of 1,929 Finnish political candidates. Evaluations of beauty explain success in real elections better than evaluations of competence, intelligence, likability, or trustworthiness. The beauty premium is larger for female candidates, in contrast to findings in previous labor-market studies.Beauty; Gender; Elections; Political candidates; Beauty premium
summary: This study examines the role of beauty in political elections, focusing on how men and women evaluate male and female candidates and how candidate traits correlate with electoral success. Researchers collected over 16,000 assessments from nearly 3,000 respondents on photos of Finnish political candidates. The findings indicate that evaluations of beauty are a stronger predictor of success in real elections than competence, intelligence, likability, or trustworthiness. Notably, the "beauty premium" for female candidates was found to be larger, a contrast to previous labor-market studies. Keywords: beauty, gender, elections, political candidates, beauty premium.

title: Budget structure and reelection prospects: Empirical evidence from French local elections
abstract: This paper is a study of the influence of economic and political conditions on the results of incumbent parties' candidates in local elections in France. The large sample used covers 586 towns and two elections (2001 and 2008). It explicitly deals with the specificities induced by the tworound process of the French electoral rule, and results are provided for both the reelection probability and the share of votes. It is shown that the budget structure, and notably equipment expenditures, has a strong impact on the incumbent party's share of votes. Political variables also play a role, as do the number of candidates, and national partisan waves. --Local elections,Visible expenditures
summary: This paper analyzes the impact of economic and political conditions on incumbent party candidates' performance in French local elections. Using a large sample of 586 towns and data from 2001 and 2008 elections, the study accounts for the specificities of France's two-round electoral system. It reveals that budget structure, especially equipment expenditures, significantly influences the incumbent party's vote share. Political variables, candidate numbers, and national partisan trends also play a crucial role. This research provides insights into factors affecting reelection probability and vote shares in local French elections, with keywords including local elections and visible expenditures.

title: Moderating Political Extremism: Single Round vs Runoff Elections under Plurality Rule
abstract: We compare single ballot vs dual ballot elections under plurality rule, assuming sincere voting and allowing for partly endogenous party formation. Under the dual ballot, the number of parties is larger but the influence of extremist voters on equilibrium policy is smaller, because their bargaining power is reduced compared to a single ballot election. The predictions on the number of parties and on policy volatility are consistent with data on municipal elections in Italy, where cities with more (less) than 15,000 inhabitants have dual (single) ballots respectively.run-off, municipal elections, political bargaining, property
fieldOfStudy: Politics, run-off, municipal elections, political bargaining, property
summary: This paper compares single ballot versus dual ballot elections under plurality rule, assuming sincere voting and partly endogenous party formation. The authors find that dual ballot systems lead to a larger number of parties but reduce the influence of extremist voters on equilibrium policy by diminishing their bargaining power. These predictions are consistent with data from municipal elections in Italy, where dual ballots are used in cities with over 15,000 inhabitants and single ballots in smaller cities. Keywords include run-off, municipal elections, and political bargaining.

title: Scaling laws and universality in the choice of election candidates
abstract:
Nowadays there is an increasing interest of physicists in finding
regularities related to social phenomena. This interest is clearly motivated by
applications that a statistical mechanical description of the human behavior
may have in our society. By using this framework, we address this work to cover
an open question related to elections: the choice of elections candidates
(candidature process). Our analysis reveals that, apart from the social
motivations, this system displays features of traditional out-of-equilibrium
physical phenomena such as scale-free statistics and universality. Basically,
we found a non-linear (power law) mean correspondence between the number of
candidates and the size of the electorate (number of voters), and also that
this choice has a multiplicative underlying process (lognormal behavior). The
universality of our findings is supported by data from 16 elections from 5
countries. In addition, we show that aspects of network scale-free can be
connected to this universal behavior.Comment: Accepted for publication in EP
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Social and Economic Systems, Complex Systems, Statistical Mechanics
summary: This study applies a statistical mechanical framework to analyze the choice of election candidates, an open question in social phenomena. The research reveals that beyond social motivations, the candidature process exhibits features of out-of-equilibrium physical phenomena, including scale-free statistics and universality. Key findings include a non-linear (power law) correspondence between candidate numbers and electorate size, and a multiplicative underlying process (lognormal behavior). The universality of these findings is supported by data from 16 elections across 5 countries, connecting aspects of network scale-free behavior to this universal pattern. This work integrates physics principles with election dynamics and complex systems.

title: Split Cycle: A New Condorcet Consistent Voting Method Independent of Clones and Immune to Spoilers
abstract: We introduce a new Condorcet consistent voting method, called Split Cycle. Split Cycle belongs to the small family of known voting methods satisfying independence of clones and the Pareto principle. Unlike other methods in this family, Split Cycle satisfies a new criterion we call immunity to spoilers, which concerns adding candidates to elections, as well as the known criteria of positive involvement and negative involvement, which concern adding voters to elections. Thus, relative to other clone-independent Paretian methods, Split Cycle mitigates “spoiler effects” and “strong no show paradoxes.
summary: This paper introduces Split Cycle, a new Condorcet consistent voting method that satisfies independence of clones and the Pareto principle. Unlike other methods in its family, Split Cycle is immune to spoilers, a new criterion concerning adding candidates to elections, and also meets known criteria of positive and negative involvement related to adding voters. This research aims to mitigate "spoiler effects" and "strong no show paradoxes" in voting systems, making it a significant contribution to social choice theory and election integrity. Keywords include Condorcet method, clone independence, spoiler effect, and voting systems.

title: Review of NLRB on Election Campaigns, 1979
abstract: Includes consideration of the NLRB standards for representation elections, 101 LRR pp.170-172
summary: This article reviews the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB) standards for representation elections, as documented in the Labor Relations Reporter. Focusing on the 1979 review, it considers the legal obligations of employers to bargain with unions, especially concerning the effect of "zipper clauses" or "complete agreement" clauses on this duty during the term of a collective bargaining agreement. The work explores the implications of such clauses on mid-term bargaining over various subjects, examining specific cases and the scope of bargaining permitted by existing agreements. This analysis is crucial for understanding labor law and union-management relations.

title: 2002 parliamentary elections in Ukraine
summary: This document analyzes the 2002 parliamentary elections in Ukraine, focusing on the unexpected results where the centrist-rightist coalition around Viktor Yuschenko achieved significant popular support but the "party of power," backed by President Leonid Kuchma, secured more seats due to the mixed electoral system. It details the vote percentages and seat distribution for key parties like Yuschenko's Block, the Communist Party, and "For One Ukraine." The analysis highlights how the electoral regulations favored certain blocks and discusses the enduring influence of the President's Administration, a relic of the Soviet system, amidst growing oligarch dissatisfaction. It also touches upon the slow development of democratic attitudes in Ukrainian society and among its political elite, while noting sufficient support for democratic mechanisms to prevent authoritarian rule.

title: Decentralization, local government elections and voter turnout in Pakistan:
abstract: "Decentralization has the potential to improve the accountability of government and lead to a more efficient provision of public services. However, accountability requires broad groups of people to participate in local government. Thus, voter turnout at local government elections is an important component of government accountability. This study used survey data on the 2005 local government elections in Pakistan to analyze the impact of electoral mechanisms, the credibility of elections, and voters' socioeconomic characteristics on voter turnout. The rational-choice perspective is applied to develop the specifications of the empirical model. The empirical analysis is based on a series of standard and multilevel random-intercept logistic models. Our important findings reveal that (1) voter turnout is strongly associated with the personal and social gratifications people derive from voting; (2) the preference-matching ability of candidates for local government positions is marginal; and (3) the introduction of direct elections of the district nazims—a key position in local government—might improve electoral participation and thus create a precondition for better local government accountability. The findings also suggest that less educated people, farmers, and rural people are more likely to vote." Authors' AbstractDecentralization, local government elections, political participation, voter turnout, Public service provision, Governance,
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Public Service Provision, Governance, Political Participation, Elections
summary: This study analyzes the impact of electoral mechanisms, credibility, and socioeconomic factors on voter turnout in Pakistan's 2005 local government elections, using survey data and rational-choice theory for empirical modeling. Employing standard and multilevel random-intercept logistic models, key findings indicate strong associations between turnout and personal/social gratifications from voting, marginal preference-matching ability of candidates, and potential improvements in participation from direct district nazim elections. The research suggests that less educated, rural, and farming populations are more likely to vote, highlighting preconditions for improved local government accountability through increased participation.

title: Protecting the Viability of the Small Donor in Modern Elections
abstract: Campaign finance reform stands as one of the most important issues in today’s modern elections. From national to municipal contests, the influx of large donations places wealthy individuals—and interests—at odds with the average voter. Over the years, volumes of academic and legislative reforms have been proposed that encompass a wide range of electoral subject matter. From Citizens United to Federal Elections Commission (FEC) control mechanisms, solutions on how to change our campaign finance regulatory regime cover a large and diverse area of law and policy. However, the central theme throughout these reforms is maximizing transparency and curbing the undue influence of candidates through large donations
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Campaign Finance, Law and Policy, Political Economy
summary: This article examines campaign finance reform as a critical issue in modern elections, highlighting how large donations create disparity between wealthy interests and average voters. It explores various academic and legislative proposals, from Citizens United to FEC control mechanisms, all aimed at maximizing transparency and curbing undue influence. The paper specifically investigates small-donor matching programs, arguing they are a viable solution within the current framework for enhancing voter participation, encouraging direct engagement between candidates and diverse constituencies, and amplifying the political voice of the average donor.

title: The Cowl - Special Elections Issue - Apr 26, 1995
abstract: The Cowl - student newspaper of Providence College. Special Elections Issue - April 26, 1995. 4 pages
summary: This Special Elections Issue of The Cowl, Providence College's student newspaper from April 26, 1995, urges students to participate in class elections to help shape the future of their college. It highlights the responsibilities of elected officers, including planning events and serving as a liaison to faculty and administration. The article emphasizes the importance of student voices in decisions regarding curriculum, academic calendar, and new minors/majors. It calls for all students to vote on April 27 and lists candidates for President, Vice-President, Secretary, Treasurer, and Representatives across the classes of 1996, 1997, and 1998.

title: Granite Staters Split On Races In First And Second Congressional Districts 4/26/2012
abstract: The elections for New Hampshire‚Äôs U.S. Representatives remain wide open. Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Kelley Ayotte continue to receive generally positive favorability ratings
publisher: University of New Hampshire Scholars\u27 Repository
fieldOfStudy: Politics, public opinion, elections, political polling
summary: This poll, conducted by the University of New Hampshire Survey Center, investigated the political landscape in New Hampshire, focusing on the U.S. Representatives' elections and the favorability ratings of Senators Jeanne Shaheen and Kelley Ayotte. Based on interviews with 538 randomly selected New Hampshire adults in April 2012, the findings indicate that elections for the First and Second Congressional Districts remain competitive. Senator Jeanne Shaheen showed particularly strong favorability, leading other members of the state's congressional delegation. The poll provides insights into voter sentiment and congressional races.

title: Elections and strategic positioning games
abstract: We formalize the interplay between expected voting behavior and stragetic positioning behavior of candidates as a common agency problem in which the candidates (i.e. the principals) compete for voters (i.e. agents) via the issues they choose and the positions they take. A political situation is defined as a feasible combination of candidate positions and expected political payoffs to the candidates. Taking this approach, we are led naturally to a particular formalization of the candidates’ positioning game, called a political situation game. Within the context of this game, we define the notion of farsighted stability (introduced in an abstract setting by Chwe (1994)) and apply Chwe’s result to obtain existence of farsightedly stable outcomes. We compute the farsightedly stable sets for several examples of political situations games, with outcomes that conform to real-world observations
publisher: University of Warwick, Department of Economics
summary: This paper formalizes the interaction between expected voting behavior and candidate strategic positioning as a common agency problem. Candidates compete for voters through their chosen issues and stances. The study introduces the concept of a "political situation game" to model candidates' positioning behavior. Within this framework, the authors define and apply the notion of farsighted stability, drawing on Chwe (1994) to demonstrate the existence of farsightedly stable outcomes. The research computes farsightedly stable sets for various examples of these games, yielding results consistent with real-world political observations. Keywords include farsighted stability, political common agency games, elections, and strategic positioning.

title: Divided Government versus Incumbency Externality Effect: Quasi-Experimental Evidence on Multiple Voting Decisions
abstract: This paper explores the interdependency of political institutions from the voter's perspective. Specifically, we are interested in three questions: (1) Does the partisan identity of the local mayor influence the voter's decision in the subsequent town council election?; (2) Does this partisan identity influence in ensuing higher level elections?; and (3) Do voters condition their vote for the mayor on the result of the last council election? We collected a unique data set for Germany in which we link election results for different political institutions at the municipal level. To identify causal effects, we rely on a regression discontinuity design focusing on close election outcomes. We find that the party of the mayor receives a bonus of 4-5 percentage points in vote share in the subsequent town council elections if, and only if, mayoral and council elections are held simultaneously. With regard to higher level elections, we find no effect for the party identity of the mayor on federal and European election outcomes. Using run-off mayor races, which are held shortly after council elections, we show that voters punish parties that performed strongly in the council election. To explain our empirical findings, we explore two mechanisms from the theoretical literature. We conclude that there is evidence both for an incumbency externality effect as well as a preference for divided government effect in opposite directions.Regression discontinuity design, municipality data, local election results, divided government effect, incumbency externality effect
summary: This paper investigates the interdependency of political institutions from a voter's perspective, focusing on whether a local mayor's partisan identity influences subsequent town council and higher-level elections in Germany. Using a unique dataset linking municipal election results and a regression discontinuity design, the study finds that the mayor's party receives a 4-5 percentage point bonus in town council elections only when held simultaneously. No effect is observed for higher-level federal and European elections. Voters are shown to punish parties that performed strongly in preceding council elections during run-off mayor races. The findings provide evidence for both incumbency externality and preference for divided government effects. Keywords: regression discontinuity design, municipality data, local election results, divided government effect, incumbency externality effect.

title: Sincere Scoring Rules
abstract: Approval Voting is shown to be the unique scoring rule that leads strategic voters to sincere behavior of three candidates elections in Poisson Games. However, Approval Voting can lead to insincere behavior in elections with more than three candidates.Sincerity, Approval Voting, Scoring rules, Poisson Games
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Sincerity, Approval Voting, Scoring Rules, Poisson Games
summary: This paper investigates strategic voter behavior in elections, focusing on scoring rules within Poisson Games. The core finding is that Approval Voting uniquely encourages sincere behavior in three-candidate elections. However, the study reveals that Approval Voting can lead to insincere behavior when more than three candidates are involved. The research utilizes constrained minimization problems and concepts like the Magnitude Equivalence Theorem (MET) and Dual Magnitude Theorem (DMT) to analyze pivot outcomes. Key terms include sincerity, Approval Voting, scoring rules, and Poisson Games, which are crucial for understanding voting dynamics and rule design.

title: Renowned Political Scientist Christopher Achen to Visit RWU on Oct. 26
abstract: Community invited to President’s Distinguished Speakers Series event featuring world-renowned scholar of elections and public opinion
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Science, Public Opinion, Elections
summary: This news article announces that renowned political scientist Christopher Achen will visit Roger Williams University on October 26 as part of the President's Distinguished Speakers Series. Achen, a leading scholar of elections and public opinion, will discuss his research on how voters are influenced by partisan beliefs, identity groups, and external events rather than solely by informed policy choices. The lecture, which is free and open to the public, aims to enrich the intellectual lives of students, faculty, staff, and the local community by bringing in thought leaders from various disciplines. Attendees will have the opportunity to engage with Achen's insights into political behavior and voter decision-making.

title: Mugar Greene Scholars "Elections" posters
abstract: Posters to encourage voting for the 2016 United States election
summary: This document comprises a collection of posters created to encourage voter participation in the 2016 United States election. These visual materials, likely used for public awareness campaigns, aimed to motivate citizens to cast their votes. The collection originates from Boston University's OpenBU archive, specifically within the Mugar Greene Scholars' blog and social media archive, highlighting efforts in political engagement and civic duty during a significant national election cycle. Keywords: voting, election, 2016, United States, political engagement, civic duty, posters, Boston University.

title: Multiwinner Elections with Diversity Constraints
abstract:
We develop a model of multiwinner elections that combines performance-based
measures of the quality of the committee (such as, e.g., Borda scores of the
committee members) with diversity constraints. Specifically, we assume that the
candidates have certain attributes (such as being a male or a female, being
junior or senior, etc.) and the goal is to elect a committee that, on the one
hand, has as high a score regarding a given performance measure, but that, on
the other hand, meets certain requirements (e.g., of the form "at least $30\%$
of the committee members are junior candidates and at least $40\%$ are
females"). We analyze the computational complexity of computing winning
committees in this model, obtaining polynomial-time algorithms (exact and
approximate) and NP-hardness results. We focus on several natural classes of
voting rules and diversity constraints.Comment: A short version of this paper appears in the proceedings of AAAI-1
fieldOfStudy: Politics, computational social choice, algorithmic game theory
summary: This paper introduces a model for multiwinner elections that balances committee quality, measured by performance metrics like Borda scores, with diversity constraints based on candidate attributes (e.g., gender, seniority). The goal is to elect a committee achieving high performance while satisfying specific diversity requirements, such as minimum percentages of junior candidates or females. The authors analyze the computational complexity of determining winning committees within this framework, presenting polynomial-time algorithms (both exact and approximate) and NP-hardness results. The research focuses on various voting rules and diversity constraints, contributing to understanding fairness and efficiency in electoral systems. Keywords: multiwinner elections, diversity constraints, computational complexity, Borda scores, voting rules.

title: Defending Elections Against Malicious Spread of Misinformation
abstract:
The integrity of democratic elections depends on voters' access to accurate
information. However, modern media environments, which are dominated by social
media, provide malicious actors with unprecedented ability to manipulate
elections via misinformation, such as fake news. We study a zero-sum game
between an attacker, who attempts to subvert an election by propagating a fake
new story or other misinformation over a set of advertising channels, and a
defender who attempts to limit the attacker's impact. Computing an equilibrium
in this game is challenging as even the pure strategy sets of players are
exponential. Nevertheless, we give provable polynomial-time approximation
algorithms for computing the defender's minimax optimal strategy across a range
of settings, encompassing different population structures as well as models of
the information available to each player. Experimental results confirm that our
algorithms provide near-optimal defender strategies and showcase variations in
the difficulty of defending elections depending on the resources and knowledge
available to the defender.Comment: Full version of paper accepted to AAAI 201
summary: This paper investigates a zero-sum game between an attacker spreading misinformation (e.g., fake news) and a defender attempting to limit its impact on democratic elections. The study addresses the challenge of computing equilibrium in such games, where strategy sets are exponential. It proposes provable polynomial-time approximation algorithms to determine the defender's minimax optimal strategy across various population structures and information models. Experimental results confirm these algorithms provide near-optimal defender strategies and highlight how defender resources and knowledge influence the difficulty of safeguarding elections against misinformation, supporting efforts to secure election integrity through algorithmic defense.

title: DO ELECTIONS ALWAYS NOTIVATE INCUMBENTS? LEARNING VS CAREER CONCERNS
abstract: This paper studies a principal-agent model of the relationship between officeholder and the electorate, where everyone is initially uninformed about the officeholder’s ability. If office-holder effort and ability interact in the determination of performance in office, then an office-holder has an incentive to learn i.e. raise effort so that performance becomes a more accurate signal of her ability. Elections reduce the learning effect, and the reduction in this effect may more than offset the positive “career concerns” effect of elections on effort. Moreover, when this occurs, appointment of officials may welfare-dominate elections.Career Concerns ; Elections ; Citizen-Candidate ; Learning ; Effort ; Incomplete Information
summary: This paper examines a principal-agent model to study the relationship between officeholders and the electorate, where initial information about the officeholder's ability is absent. It investigates how officeholder effort and ability interact to determine performance, creating an incentive for officeholders to increase effort to make performance a more accurate signal of their ability. The authors find that elections may reduce this "learning effect," potentially offsetting the positive "career concerns" effect on effort. Consequently, appointing officials might lead to better welfare outcomes than elections in certain scenarios. Key concepts include career concerns, elections, learning, effort, and incomplete information.

title: Rafael Torres, Jr. - Does the United States Supreme Court decision in the \u3cem\u3eCitizens United v. the Federal Election Commission\u3c/em\u3e case affect the voluntary departure of United States Senators
abstract: The United States Supreme Court decision in the case of Citizens United v. the Federal Election Commission raised concerns about how unlimited independent expenditures by organizations would influence campaigns and elections. This concern has been expressed through media and politicians, but research on the subject is conflicting. One argument is that protecting unlimited contributions as free speech gives a disproportionate amount of speech to non-voting entities. The other argument is that speech does not directly influence elections and it is ultimately the voter\u27s decision on which candidate to choose. Laws that affect elections also affect departures. The connection between campaign finance and Senate departures is that a change in the law will affect election outcomes causing more Senators to voluntarily depart from Congress in anticipation of a contentious election. I am studying the 108-113th Congresses to determine if there is a difference in Senate departures before and after the decision. Voluntary departure includes retirement, resignation, and moving to another public office. The differences in departure will be determined by changes in the rate of departure and the profiles of voluntarily departing Senators. If the court\u27s decision has made elections more competitive then there should be an increase in Senate departures. The study examines the differences before and after the Citizens United ruling based on age, the number of years of service in the Senate, and the last election win margin. I will lastly discuss possible future empirical research on Congressional retirements as well as post-Senate career profiles.https://epublications.marquette.edu/mcnair_2013/1003/thumbnail.jp
summary: This study investigates whether the United States Supreme Court's Citizens United v. Federal Election Commission decision, which allowed unlimited independent expenditures, influenced voluntary Senate departures. The research analyzes the 108-113th Congresses, examining changes in departure rates and profiles of Senators (age, years of service, last election win margin) before and after the ruling. The central hypothesis is that if Citizens United made elections more competitive, an increase in Senate departures would be observed. Voluntary departure includes retirement, resignation, and moving to another public office. The findings could inform future empirical research on Congressional retirements and post-Senate career profiles, linking campaign finance reform to legislative tenure.

title: Money, Politics, and Impartial Justice
abstract: A centuries-old controversy asks whether judicial elections are inconsistent with impartial justice. The debate is especially important because more than 90 percent of the United States\u27 judicial business is handled by state courts, and approximately nine in ten of all state court judges face the voters in some type of election. Using a stunning new data set of virtually all state supreme court decisions from 1995 to 1998, this paper provides empirical evidence that elected state supreme court judges routinely adjust their rulings to attract votes and campaign money. I find that judges who must be reelected by Republican voters, especially in partisan elections, tend to decide cases in accord with standard Republican policy: they are more likely to vote for businesses over individuals, for employers in labor disputes, for doctors and hospitals in medical malpractice cases, for businesses in products liability cases and tort cases generally, and against criminals in criminal appeals. Judicial behavior is correspondingly liberal for judges facing reelection by Democrats. Moreover, I find evidence that judges change their rulings when the political preferences of the voters change. In addition, my analysis finds a strong relationship between campaign contributions and judges\u27 rulings. Contributions from pro-business groups, pro-labor groups, doctor groups, insurance companies, and lawyer groups increase the probability that judges will vote for the litigants favored by those interest groups. The results suggest that recent trends in judicial elections-elections becoming more contested, competitive, and expensive-may have upset the delicate balance between judicial independence and accountability. I discuss various policy solutions for reforming states\u27 systems
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Law, Judicial Behavior, Elections, Campaign Finance
summary: This paper investigates the long-standing controversy regarding the consistency of judicial elections with impartial justice, focusing on state supreme court judges in the United States. Utilizing a comprehensive dataset of state supreme court decisions from 1995 to 1998, the study empirically demonstrates that elected judges routinely adjust their rulings to attract votes and campaign contributions. Findings indicate that judges facing Republican electorates tend to issue conservative rulings, while those facing Democratic electorates lean liberal. Furthermore, the analysis reveals a strong correlation between campaign contributions from interest groups (e.g., pro-business, pro-labor) and judicial decisions favoring those contributors. The research suggests that increasing contestation and expense in judicial elections may jeopardize the balance between judicial independence and accountability, prompting a discussion of potential policy reforms.

title: Implementation of the Quota System in the Regional Assembly Elections: the Analysis of Electoral Results in the Context of Women’s Epresentation on Electoral Lists
abstract: The following article concerns selected aspects of the implementation of the quota system in elections to the regional assemblies (Sejmik wojewódzki) in Poland. This comparative analysis concerns two elections: in 2010 (before the quota system was introduced) and in 2014 (after its introduction). The key questions the authors would like to address involve the number of women represented on the electoral lists in 2010 and 2014 respectively, and the number of mandates in regional assemblies awarded to women before and after the quota system was introduced, as well as the relationship between the position on the electoral list and mandates awarded to female candidates. The authors also focus on the personnel policies of political parties. Out of all regional elections, the regional assembly elections were characterized by the highest level of party dependency. Introducing the quota system resulted in an increase in the number of women represented on electoral lists, yet it did not help increase the number of mandates awarded to female candidates. One of the reasons for this situation was the strategy adopted when the positions on the electoral lists were awarded by the parties with the largest political support. The representation of women on the upper positions of the electoral lists is smaller than the quota of female representatives imposed by the electoral law, and the larger number of women on the positions further below on the electoral lists translates into smaller chances of these candidates gaining a mandate. The source data for this research analysis comes from the National Electoral Commission
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Electoral Systems, Gender Quotas, Political Parties, Regional Assemblies
summary: This article analyzes the implementation of a quota system in Polish regional assembly elections, comparing 2010 (pre-quota) and 2014 (post-quota) results. The study examines the number of women on electoral lists, mandates awarded, and the impact of list position and political party personnel policies. While the quota system increased the representation of women on electoral lists, it did not significantly raise the number of mandates secured by female candidates. This was primarily attributed to political parties strategically placing women in lower, less electable positions on lists, despite the overall increase in female candidates.

title: Effects of candidate position on ballot papers: Exploratory visualization of voter choice in the London local council elections 2010
abstract: The relationship between candidates’ position on a ballot paper and vote rank is explored in the case of London local council elections. A design study uses information visualization techniques to identify patterns and generate hypotheses. Using clustered bar-charts and spatial treemaps, the effects of ballot ordering are shown. Visual evidence is presented to suggest that the order of placement of the names of candidates acts to bias voters towards those whose names are towards the top of the ballot paper. The findings of this research have significant implications for the design of ballot papers and the conduct of fair elections
summary: This research explores the relationship between candidate ballot position and vote rank in London local council elections, using information visualization techniques to identify patterns. Through clustered bar charts and spatial treemaps, the study reveals that the order of candidate names biases voters towards those at the top of the ballot paper. These findings have significant implications for the design of ballot papers and the conduct of fair elections, highlighting the importance of ballot ordering, voter choice, and election integrity.

title: When Inertia Generates Political Cycles
abstract: In this note, we propose a simple infinite horizon of elections with two candidates. We suppose that the government policy presents some degree of inertia, i.e. a new government cannot completely change the policy implemented by the incumbent. When the policy inertia is strong enough, no party can win the elections a consecutive infinite number of times.Policy inertia
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Cycles, Policy Inertia, Elections
summary: This study proposes an infinite horizon model of elections with two candidates, investigating how government policy inertia can generate political cycles. The research assumes that a new government cannot fully alter the incumbent's policy. The main finding suggests that when policy inertia is sufficiently strong, no single party can continuously win elections indefinitely, thus leading to a cyclical alternation of parties in power. This model extends Downs (1957) by incorporating fixed party programs and policy implementation imperfections. This work contributes to understanding political turnover and cycles in modern democracies.

title: Winners and Losers of Early Elections: On the Welfare Implications of Political Blockades and Early Elections
abstract: We develop a dynamic model of political competition. Each party has a policymotivated ideological wing and an office-motivated opportunistic wing. A blockade arises if inner-party conflict stops policy implementation. We use this model to study whether early elections should be used to overcome a blockade. They have the advantage that urgent decisions are no longer delayed, and the disadvantage that unsuccessful governments gain additional time in office. This may give rise to a time inconsistency. Voters are in favour of a constitution without early elections. However, in the middle of a political crisis, they are willing to abandon it.early elections, political blockades, ideological rigidities
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Political Blockades, Early Elections, Ideological Rigidities
summary: This study develops a dynamic model of political competition where parties have ideological and opportunistic wings. It investigates whether early elections can resolve political blockades arising from inner-party conflict. The model explores the trade-offs: early elections prevent delays in urgent decisions but may extend the tenure of unsuccessful governments, creating a time inconsistency. While voters initially favor constitutions without early elections, they are willing to abandon this stance during political crises. Key findings include the dynamics of political blockades, the implications of early elections, and voter preferences regarding constitutional stability versus immediate crisis resolution.

title: From foot-slogging to call centres and direct mail: A framework for analysing the development of district-level campaigning
abstract: Drawing upon ideas formulated with national-level campaigning in mind and also analyses of district or local-level campaigning, a conceptual framework to assist in analysing the development of district-level campaigning is presented. The proposed framework is further amplified, explained and tested using quantitative and qualitative data collected at British General Elections between 1992 and 2005. Various aspects of district (constituency) campaigning in Britain are examined and the extent of change over four General Elections analysed. In broad terms, the data show a good fit with the framework, which offers a useful way of thinking about developments in campaigning both within and across countries
summary: This paper introduces a conceptual framework for analyzing the evolution of district-level political campaigning, drawing from national and local campaigning ideas. The framework is explained and tested using quantitative and qualitative data from British General Elections between 1992 and 2005. It examines various aspects of constituency campaigning in Britain, analyzing changes across four general elections. The findings demonstrate a strong fit with the proposed framework, offering a valuable approach to understanding developments in political campaigning within and across different countries. Keywords: political campaigning, district-level campaigning, constituency campaigning, British General Elections, electoral studies.

title: Elections, Contracts and Markets
abstract: As the performance of long-term projects is not observable in the short run politicians may pander to public opinion. To solve this problem, we propose a triple mechanism involving political information markets, reelection threshold contracts, and democratic elections. An information market is used to predict the long-term performance of a policy, while threshold contracts stipulate a price level on the political information market that a politician must reach to have the right to stand for reelection. Reelection thresholds are offered by politicians during campaigns. We show that, on balance, the triple mechanism increases social welfare.elections, threshold contracts, democracy, information markets, triple mechanism
summary: This paper proposes a triple mechanism to address the issue of politicians pandering to public opinion when long-term project performance is not immediately observable. The mechanism involves political information markets to predict long-term policy performance, reelection threshold contracts stipulating a market price level for reelection eligibility, and democratic elections. Politicians offer these reelection thresholds during campaigns. The study demonstrates that, on balance, this triple mechanism significantly increases social welfare. Key concepts include elections, threshold contracts, democracy, information markets, and the triple mechanism.

title: Vote expectations and pre-electoral tariff cuts in Flemish municipalities
abstract: Using data covering 3 election moments (1988-2000) for 294 Flemish municipalities we examine whether the decision to cut tariffs before elections depends on the government’s expectations of staying into office. Election moments are central to both the political budget cycle literature and the strategic debt models. The combination of both theories could suggest that, at least in theory, both winning and loosing governments seem to benefit from pre-electoral tariff reductions and as such we expect to find a great many municipalities to engage into tariff cuts. The dataset however shows this is clearly not the case. We argue that the differences in the fiscal policy reaction of governments facing elections might have to do with their expectations of staying into office. In our analysis we make the decision to change tariffs dependent on the expected vote percentage of the government party (parties). As we do not possess reliable ex ante data on the perceived re-election probability, we estimate a vote-function to predict the percentage of votes. Our analysis shows that tariff reductions in election years are more prone when governments expect not to reach majority again in next elections
summary: This study investigates whether Flemish municipalities' decisions to cut tariffs before elections depend on the incumbent government's expectations of retaining office. Analyzing data from 294 municipalities across three election cycles (1988-2000), the authors challenge the assumption that both winning and losing governments universally benefit from pre-electoral tariff reductions. By making tariff changes contingent on the government party's expected vote percentage, estimated via a vote-function, the research reveals that tariff reductions in election years are more prevalent when governments anticipate not securing a majority in the subsequent elections. This work contributes to the political budget cycle literature and strategic debt models.

title: The Disadvantaged Incumbents: Estimating Incumbency Effects in Indian State Legislatures
abstract: This paper estimates the effect of a candidate’s incumbency status on his or her chances of winning using a large dataset on state legislative elections in India during 1975-2003. I use an innovative research design, called Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD), that provides unbiased estimate of the effect due to incumbency by comparing the candidates in closely fought elections, and find that incumbency has a significant negative effect on the fortunes of incumbent candidates in India and the incumbency effect has decreased further in the last decade. Also, the variation in the incumbency effects across Indian states depends on the differences in levels of public good provision such as the health facilities, rates of employment and poverty, and state per capita income.Anti-incumbency; Indian elections; regression discontinuity design (RDD)
summary: This paper investigates the effect of incumbency on winning state legislative elections in India from 1975-2003. Utilizing a Regression Discontinuity Design (RDD) to compare candidates in closely contested elections, the study finds a significant negative effect of incumbency on candidate fortunes, a trend that has further intensified over the last decade. The research also reveals that variations in incumbency effects across Indian states correlate with differences in public good provision, such as health facilities, employment rates, poverty levels, and state per capita income. Keywords: anti-incumbency, Indian elections, regression discontinuity design, RDD, political science, electoral studies.

title: The 2004 Elections in Northern Ghana
abstract: A study of the presidential and parliamentary elections of 2004 in Ghana, focusing on the particular issues that led to the three Norethern Regions defying the  nnational trend and voting for the opposition NDC.  The study reveals that the key factors behind this were local and traditional rather than regional or national.  This indicates the continuing importance of inter and intra-ethnic rivalries in those regions
summary: This study analyzes the 2004 presidential and parliamentary elections in Ghana, focusing on why the three Northern Regions diverged from the national voting trend and supported the opposition NDC. It reveals that local and traditional issues, rather than broader regional or national concerns, were the primary drivers. This highlights the enduring influence of inter- and intra-ethnic rivalries within these regions, which continued to shape political outcomes and defy national political shifts. Key findings include the importance of localized grievances and traditional loyalties in Ghanaian elections.

title: Crimean elections after March 31, 2002
fieldOfStudy: Politics, Elections, Ukrainian Politics, Crimean Politics
summary: This document analyzes the results and political dynamics of the Crimean elections held after March 31, 2002. It highlights similarities with other Ukrainian regions, noting the widespread use of administrative resources and political technologies, including a significant presence of Russian political strategists and pro-Russian slogans. The study reveals a shift in political preferences, with the Communist Party receiving fewer votes and the Social Democratic Party of Ukraine (United) significantly increasing its influence. It also discusses the ongoing challenges in forming stable parliamentary majorities in Crimea and the potential for continued aggravation of relations between the Verkhovna Rada and the Crimean authorities, emphasizing the region's moderate opposition to Kyiv.

title: Pessimistic Foreign Investors and Turmoil in Emerging Markets: the case of Brazil in 2002
abstract: Using survey data, we document that foreign-owned institutions became more pessimistic than locally owned institutions about the strength of the Brazilian currency around the 2002 presidential elections. As a result of their relative pessimism, foreign-owned institutions made larger forecast errors. Consistent with the emergence of their relative pessimism, foreign investors heavily sold Brazilian stocks and the Brazilian currency in futures markets ahead of the 2002 elections. Periods of stronger foreign sell-off were associated with larger equity price declines and larger depreciation of the Brazilian Real in spot and futures markets. These results are consistent with foreign investors’ relative lack of knowledge of Brazilian institutions contributing to the sharp depreciation of the Brazilian currency and stock market ahead of the 2002 presidential elections.
summary: This study investigates the behavior of foreign-owned financial institutions in Brazil around the 2002 presidential elections using survey data. It reveals that foreign institutions became significantly more pessimistic about the Brazilian currency's strength than local ones, leading to larger forecast errors. Consistent with this pessimism, foreign investors heavily sold Brazilian stocks and currency in futures markets before the elections. These sell-offs correlated with greater equity price declines and Brazilian Real depreciation in both spot and futures markets. The findings suggest that foreign investors' relative lack of knowledge about Brazilian institutions contributed to the sharp depreciation of the currency and stock market during this period.

title: Voter Sovereignty and Election Outcomes
abstract: APPROVAL VOTING; ELECTIONS; CONDORCET WINNER/LOSER; NASH EQUILIBRIUM.
summary: This paper investigates voter sovereignty and election outcomes, particularly under approval voting (AV). It examines how voters' ability to express approval for candidates impacts election results. The authors argue that while AV maximizes voter sovereignty, it can lead to a wide range of outcomes and even the election of Condorcet losers. The core claim is that voters' judgments on candidate acceptability should take precedence over conventional social-choice criteria. Key concepts include approval voting, Condorcet winner/loser, and Nash equilibrium in the context of elections.

title: A Citizen's Guide to Redistricting
abstract: Provides a detailed overview of states' rules and processes for redrawing federal, state, and local legislative districts. Illustrates possible motives behind redistricting, effects on elections, implications for legislation, and reform recommendations
publisher: Brennan Center for Justice at New York University School of Law
summary: This guide from the Brennan Center for Justice provides a comprehensive overview of states' rules and processes for redrawing federal, state, and local legislative districts. It explores the various motives behind redistricting, its significant effects on elections and implications for legislation. The document also presents reform recommendations aimed at ensuring fair and equitable redistricting procedures. Key themes include democracy, voting rights, electoral reform, and legislative policy, with examples from Arizona, California, and Ohio discussed.

title: Pakistan, politics and political business cycles
abstract: This paper studies whether in Pakistan the dynamic behavior of unemployment, inflation, budget deficit and real GDP growth is systematically affected by the timing of elections. We cover the period from 1973-2009. Our results can be summarized as follows: 1. Unemployment tends to be lower in pre-election periods and tends to increase immediately after elections, perhaps as a result of politically motivated employment schemes. 2. In ation tend to be lower in preelection periods, perhaps as a result of pre-electoral price regulation. 3. We find election year increases in the governmental budget deficit, financed by heavy government borrowings from the central bank and banking sector. 4. Real GDP growth and real governmental investment growth declines during pre and post election terms. --Opportunistic Political Business Cycle,Fiscal Policy,Macroeconomics,Elections,Asia,Pakistan
summary: This paper investigates the dynamic behavior of unemployment, inflation, budget deficit, and real GDP growth in Pakistan concerning the timing of elections from 1973-2009. The study reveals that unemployment and inflation tend to be lower in pre-election periods, potentially due to politically motivated employment schemes and price regulation. Conversely, election years show increases in governmental budget deficits, financed by central bank and banking sector borrowings. Real GDP growth and governmental investment decline during pre- and post-election terms, indicating an opportunistic political business cycle. Keywords: political business cycle, fiscal policy, macroeconomics, elections, Pakistan.

title: Appendix I: References Cited
abstract: Annual summary of field crop insect management trials, Department of Crop Services, University of Illinois. Providing accurate and unbiased evaluations of insect control products and management strategies to assist growers in Illinois.University of Illinois Extension and Department of Crop Science
publisher: University of Illinois Extension and Department of Crop Sciences
summary: This annual summary from the Department of Crop Services, University of Illinois, details field crop insect management trials. Its primary purpose is to provide Illinois growers with accurate, unbiased evaluations of insect control products and management strategies. The document references methodologies like the node-injury scale for corn rootworm larvae and discusses economic thresholds for pests such as the soybean aphid. Key concepts include insect management, crop science, pest control, and agricultural extension services.

title: Assessment of environmental flows for river health
summary: This document highlights the strategic role of environmental flow (E-flow) assessments in developing countries for maintaining river health and achieving water-related Sustainable Development Goals. Supported by the International Water Management Institute (IWMI), countries utilize E-flow calculators for water resource management in river basins and improved SDG reporting. IWMI has refined E-flow determination over 15 years, including a 2004 global assessment and a 2007 partnership with WWF-India for the Ganges River, employing the Building Block Methodology to define river flow regimes based on timing, duration, frequency, and magnitude. This research is crucial for sustainable water management and ecosystem health.
